name: Presidente. –
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's declaration on the rule of law in Malta, following recent revelations about the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia (2019/2954(RSP)). I remind everyone that it is possible to request the cards for the "catch the eye" and "blue card" procedures, either through traditional registration or through the electronic system. I, as usual, did not consider the blue card in the first round of interventions by the political groups, but for the following interventions the blue card procedure is open.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to thank you for putting the situation of the rule of law in Malta on today’s agenda. It is essential that all EU institutions contribute, within their respective roles, to upholding the rule of law in the EU. In this regard, the recent visit of Parliament’s delegation to Malta and today’s debate are of great importance. As President von der Leyen made clear, she is concerned by recent developments in Malta. The Commission has been following the developments in Malta very closely. The Commission condemns the assassination of the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia. Her murder was an attack on the free media and is of grave concern to Europe as a whole. Media freedom is the foundation of our free and democratic society. Journalists must feel safe to work in Europe. If not, democracy as we know it will be under threat. It is not the Commission’s role to comment on ongoing national investigations, but we have said very clearly, many times, that we expect a thorough and independent investigation, free from any political interference. I repeated this message directly to the Maltese ministers I spoke to recently. Europol is in Malta and has supported the investigations in Malta as a top-priority case, with experts on the spot and from Europol headquarters. The support activities are ongoing and will continue. It is crucial that all those responsible are brought to justice as soon as possible. The people of Malta – and first and foremost, the family of Daphne Caruana Galizia – demand truth and justice, and we stand with them. I also made this very clear during my visit to Malta in June 2018. Our role – the role of the Commission – is to address more structural and systemic issues, in particular in the area of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and money laundering, and we have done just that. The Commission has already been clear on the issue. There are a number of structural reforms that Malta is undertaking or needs to undertake. This was clearly stated in the European Semester country-specific recommendations, which were adopted by the Council on 9 July 2019. The Commission also brought infringement procedures regarding the incomplete transposition of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and adopted an opinion on measures to be taken by the Anti-Money Laundering Supervisor following the adoption of a finding of breach of Union law by the European Banking Authority. And we are not the only ones on whose advice Malta can rely. In its opinion of December 2018, the Venice Commission and, in its evaluation report on Malta in April 2019, the Group of States Against Corruption of the Council of Europe also raised a number of concerns in line with those of the Commission. The Commission is in regular contact with the Maltese authorities and will continue working with the authorities to accelerate these reforms. I will, in particular, highlight the following priorities for urgent action. One of the top priorities for Malta is to strengthen the independence of the judiciary, in particular the safeguards for judicial appointments and dismissals, and to establish a separate and fully-independent prosecution service. There is also a need to strengthen efforts to detect and prosecute corruption and the enforcement of the anti-money laundering framework. I am aware that the Maltese authorities have, on several occasions, expressed their intention to proceed with the necessary reforms in the areas of concern I have mentioned, but there is still a lack of significant progress. The latest developments show that no further time should be lost. The Commission has underlined that any reform must comply with EU law and European standards relating to the rule of law. We have strongly encouraged Malta to properly consult the Venice Commission. As regards the prosecution services, Malta adopted the State Advocate Act in July 2019 and appointed its first State Advocate. However, concerns remain as regards, among others, the lack of checks and balances in the appointment procedure of the Attorney General, which, in practice, is still under the power of the Prime Minister. The Commission expects the Maltese authorities to implement in full the recommendations of the Venice Commission and to follow up on the findings and recommendations of the European Commission. We are in contact with the authorities. Commissioner Reynders and I both talked with Justice Minister Bonnici last week, and we will continue to insist on the need to accelerate the reforms. Just yesterday, Commissioner Reynders sent a letter to the Maltese authorities outlining the concerns and need for speedier reforming. Let me emphasise that the rule-of-law issues are European issues. The EU is built on mutual trust among its Members, and each European citizen deserves justice. This is why we will continue to closely follow the situation. We stand ready to work with the Maltese authorities on all these aspects and to provide support where necessary. More generally, we will soon put in place a new rule-of-law mechanism covering all Member States, including Malta, to improve prevention, dialogue and monitoring. This will cover judicial independence, as well as anti-corruption and aspects of media pluralism relevant to the rule of law. Honourable Members, I can assure you that the Commission will not hesitate to take measures as necessary.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Daphne Caruana believed that there was no place for injustice, abuse of power and impunity in Malta. She believed that no one was above the law, not an ordinary citizen, not the wealthiest and the powerful, not even the Prime Minister. She fought until the end for what she believed was right. Those who planned her assassination may have silenced her voice, but they inspired thousands of people to speak out, and thousands can’t be silenced.  Something is wrong when those who promised to serve the people use the institutions against the people. Something is wrong when a democratic government is under suspicion of covering up the assassination of a journalist. Something is wrong when the freedom of expression is not freedom anymore, but a deadly risk. The Union cannot afford a country in economic ruin. How can we afford a government in moral ruin?  From here I call on you directly, Prime Minister Muscat: the eyes of all journalists across Europe are on you. I call on you directly: every day that you remain in office is a shame for democracy and an offence to the memory of Daphne Caruana. I call on you directly: every day you are in power is a slap in the face of thousands of Maltese people asking for justice and truth. Prime Minister Muscat, if your office – the office of the Prime Minister – has been involved in a murder, what else do we still not know? You must step down, Prime Minister Muscat. This is not about you anymore: it’s about Malta.  In this dark moment of the history of Malta, the European Parliament and the EPP stand together with the Maltese people. You are not alone. Truth will be revealed. Justice will be done.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Malta is still investigating the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, who was murdered as a result of her investigation. This murder has deeply shaken us all and there can be no doubt that the perpetrators and those behind it must be prosecuted.  At the same time, it is about corruption and, therefore, about the state of the rule of law as a whole. Last but not least, the opinion of the Venice Commission has made it clear that the constitution, laws, procedures for the designation of persons in public authorities, which have been in place since Malta's independence, need to be revised in order to ensure the separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary. This is a difficult task in a country of about half a million people, where close ties between officials are almost inevitable. Developments in recent years have created a deep distrust in parts of the population. A particular challenge also for the investigation, in particular for the right balance between information to the public on the one hand and confidentiality of investigations on the other. Nevertheless, there are initial successes: perpetrators have been arrested, a suspected middleman and one or at least one of the perpetrators of the murder has been identified. The support of Maltese authorities by Europol, the FBI and the Dutch authorities was and is welcome and helpful. The reform of the Constitution and the judicial system is also the first positive development involving the government, the opposition and the civilian population, and if possible accompanied not only by the Venice Commission, but also, of course, by our European Commission. What happens next? The investigation into the murder and, in particular, the connection with corruption and the sale of citizenships is far from complete and must continue intensively. For at the moment, Malta is a symbol of corruption for many, and it should be our joint responsibility to change that, there should be no such thing in the middle of Europe.  Investigations must continue, objectively in tone, consistently in action and always in compliance with all rules and rights of the rule of law. In addition to the wider investigations and procedures in Malta, however, we should also use the experience to take a preventive look at the sale of citizenship, including in other Member States.  Of course, we finally need to launch the EU-wide rule of law mechanism for all states and, finally, finally, to re-establish confidence in democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights – that must be our common objective.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I thank the Commissioner. We are here today not just to condemn a murder, but to discuss the response of the EU institutions. And in that context I note that once again the Council is absent, and that is significant – they’re not taking responsibility for any of this. We visited Malta two weeks ago and what we saw has not reassured us; it has basically fanned our concerns. I’m also deeply concerned about the lack of urgency that I sense in the Council in particular, and to a lesser degree in the Commission. I welcome that this Commission is at least taking steps – in contrast to the previous Commission that was completely silent – but we have to realise that we are dealing here with hard-nosed criminals who are literally ready to kill. They’re not going to be terribly impressed by a bureaucratic response, or by the Venice Commission, or by infringement procedures. They are criminals: that’s what we’re dealing with. And what is more worrying are the connections between those criminals and politics, all the way up to the Office of the Prime Minister. That is what we are talking about and this is part of the fabric that is the European Union.  Now the question is, at the end of this will we be able to look ourselves in the eye? Will we be able to look into the eyes of the family of Daphne Caruana Galizia and say that we have done everything in our power – everything? Yes, Ms Sippel, within the limits of the rule of law, but the presumption of innocence should never become the pretence of innocence.  First of all there is the immediate term, and that is to safeguard the integrity of the murder investigation. I note here that, although it is not our task to call for the resignation of the Prime Minister – that is the duty of the Maltese parliament and it should not be absolved of its responsibility – I do think that we should point out here that his continued presence in the Office of Prime Minister is cause for grave concern, because if there is a risk – real or perceived – of meddling with the investigation, basically we are eroding trust in the investigation, trust in the authorities and trust in the rule of law. Therefore, I would like to really urge the European Commission to immediately start the dialogue in the framework of the rule of law, and I’m glad that the Commission sent a letter yesterday.  The Council should be deeply ashamed of itself – the government leaders who are sitting at the table with the Prime Minister of Malta refusing to even discuss what is going on. It is deeply shameful. They should take responsibility for the integrity of the European Union.  Of course, in the longer term, there is the rule of law reforms, the constitutional reforms, banning corruption, money laundering, ending the sale of passports and all the rest of it, but, in conclusion, we have to recognise that this is not a technocratic issue, nor is it just a legal issue: this is an issue of taking political responsibility for the health of the democratic rule of law in the European Union as a whole, because if we don’t – and don’t now – this disease will spread. So let’s act now.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We were in Malta with a group of MEPs two weeks ago and what we have seen is progress in investigating the murder, but at the same time an alarming stalemate in the investigation and prosecution of money laundering, from corruption to the highest circles. We cannot afford a culture of gridlock within the European Union in the prosecution of corruption and money laundering. The weakest link in the Union is always our common problem. That is why it is crucial that the European Commission now uses all the means of the rule of law to change these conditions, which we see not only – but in particular concentration – in Malta. I would warn against one thing: we should not be blinded by the arrests and progress made in the Caruana Galizia murder case. What we are seeing in Malta is a long list of high-level allegations of corruption, right up to the President's office, in the area of corruption and money laundering. We do not see any consistent investigations there and certainly no corresponding arrests and convictions.  That is why it is now up to the Commission to put in place the measures that we have in legal terms: the European Union is a community of law and must also abide by the law when changing circumstances in Member States. But we can do much more than the old Commission did. In essence, despite two important resolutions by the European Parliament, the old Commission has put its hands in its lap and has done little. What is preventing you from opening infringement proceedings under Article 43 against all States that sell passports for refusing to cooperate loyally between Member States?  What is preventing you from ensuring that, in a Member State such as Malta, public procurement systems are regularly used for corruption, to initiate infringement proceedings for breaches of procurement rules in Europe?  What is preventing you from ensuring that the planning law sector in Malta, which, incidentally, also destroys the environment, finally tackles corruption there? What prevents you from opening infringement proceedings in the area of anti-money laundering policy, not only on individual specific issues, but also because of the systematic non-application of the law?  In other words, we have a long list of possible infringement procedures, including in the area of infringement of the separation of powers, where the current Maltese Government is not seriously implementing the recommendations of the Venice Commission. So you are launching infringement proceedings and ensuring that the first steps are taken in the context of the rule of law procedure, which systematically tackles the problems of the rule of law in Malta. So it is up to you, the European Commission, that together we can help to change the situation in Malta and elsewhere.

name: Marco Dreosto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my first thoughts are with Daphne Caruana Galizia and her family. As the Commissioner rightly said: no journalist can die because he has done his job well. Daphne Caruana was investigating corruption in Malta, a country that has seen a worrying increase in illegality in recent times. Briefly, I would like to remind you of what was reported in the press.  The Schengen visa scandal, which would also have been sold to Libyan citizens, including potential jihadists, in order to be able to move freely around Europe. The scandal of the so-called golden passports, sold would appear to be EUR 650 000, and reports by Europol denouncing how money was obviously laundered on the island from illegal events, not to mention all the Maltese amnesia on immigration.  In these cases, all criticism was directed against Italy and against the then minister Matteo Salvini. But how many times has Malta not worked, I repeat, not to rescue migrants at sea, who were then transported to Italy by NGOs?  We would like to remind you that among the great supporters of the Maltese Prime Minister there are many European socialist governments, including the former government of a gentleman named Matteo Renzi, an Italian. Let us remember how Matteo Renzi tweeted his support and said: the man who solved the migrant affair is a premier, but he is not Conte, he cheers Milan, but he is not Salvini, his name is Joseph Muscat and he is the premier of Malta.  It is no coincidence that Salvini attacks him because Muscat is a leader, not like him. Using a euphemism we could say that the former prime minister could have done better to think well before expressing these reflections, given the serious news events that then happened on the island.  But I would also like to point out that another man from the Italian left, the former Under-Secretary for European Affairs, Sandro Gozi, who was a candidate with En Marche in the last European elections – and who will perhaps soon sit on these benches in the Renew Group – and former adviser to the Elysée Palace on European affairs, was also an adviser to the Maltese Government, it seems that he resigned in October 2019. I see, therefore, ladies and gentlemen, a great deal of hypocrisy on the benches of this House, where we have never missed the opportunity to criticise, for example, Italy, Matteo Salvini, but also our Hungarian friends for wanting to stop illegal immigration, for wanting to defend Europe's Christian roots in order to stand up against a European Union of banks and democracy. Perhaps, before criticising anyone else, some groups would have done better to check the situation within their political family, so as to avoid bad figures. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that the spirit of Advent will bring greater coherence, greater serenity and, above all, greater justice to all. Best wishes to everyone for a holy and serene Christmas.

name: Assita Kanko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, a free press keeps us free. It shines a light on the darkest and most corrupt corners of our societies. It holds politicians, governments, but also businesses, accountable. It keeps the eyes of our citizens wide open. From where I come from, I had never imagined that modern—day Europe, the continent of enlightenment, would become the home to corruption, to press intimidation and to the assassination of journalists; that serious concerns about a criminal investigation, the independence of a criminal investigation, or serious concerns about the independence of government action would weave itself around the roots of our democracies. If Europe is to speak with authority and credibility on governance, on freedom and on the fundamental rights, then Europe must become the best it can be. If we are to win back the trust, and retain this trust, of our citizens, then we need to keep ourselves to the highest standards. Daphne Caruana Galizia was a mother and a wife who will not be going home on Christmas Eve to hug her sons or smile to her husband because she did her job as a journalist. And this family of hers cannot mourn because there is no justice yet. Not only must there be justice for Daphne and her family but also justice for our press for the sake of our democracy. We need to look into the mirror, and there face what we might become if we do not make that justice happen.

name: Stelios Kouloglou
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, a terrible crime has been committed in Malta, and the responsible for the crime must be brought to justice and the political responsible must also resign. So Mr Muscat, with his chief of staff being allegedly involved in the crime, must go right now, because we are afraid he’s going to put obstacles in the investigation up to the moment when he wants to leave in January. For once, we agree with the EPP that Mr Muscat must go, but I hope, dear colleagues, that you will display the same straight courage and you will be as adamant as that when we will speak about Mr Orbán and the violations of rule of law, not only about Malta anyway. Because in Malta, a crime has been committed, but this is not the only place that crimes are committed. It is not the only place that there is corruption. It is not the only place there is a fiscal paradise. No, please let me finish. I hope you will display the same straight and adamant character when we will talk about violations of the rule of law in Hungary and other countries where governments of yours are in place. So, there is a problem in different countries. Malta is not the only fiscal paradise in the European Union; there are a lot of them. It is not the only country that is giving golden visas and golden passports. No, there are other countries. There are other countries that, at the same time, are denying the refugees and immigrants visas while the rich people from everywhere can have a visa and a passport. That’s the same. That’s against the values of the European Union. Malta is the symptom, not the cause. Something is rotten in the Kingdom of the European Union, and we have to correct it.

name: John David Edward Tennant (NI).
text: – Mr President, in Malta you may well be right to say that the independence of the judiciary needs to be protected. You may well be right that the outgoing Prime Minister should in fact be outgoing right now, rather than next year. Our hearts should, must, and do go out to the family of Daphne Galizia, and Maltese internal democratic processes need to stop governments from covering up. But be careful. History teaches us that whenever the European Union sits in judgment over its Member States, it almost invariably makes things worse. Just in the last few years the EU has messed up its response to Catalonia, Poland, Hungary, and of course my own country, the United Kingdom. Funny isn’t it? When a Member State shows self-determination, whether rightly or wrongly, the EU applies pressure and interference. When an EU27 interferes in an EU1, it rarely ends well. Merry Christmas!

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we should not have to be debating this today. Malta should not have to spend the run—up to Christmas on the streets and Daphne Caruana Galizia should still be writing. But we have been forced to stand up to face down a criminal network that has seized control and chipped away at the pillars of our republic, protected by a Prime Minister who refuses to resign immediately.  And this is not hyperbole. For years, our Prime Minister and his paid envoys have conducted a taxpayer-funded disinformation campaign of vitriol, targeting anyone and everyone who dared to stand up to them. They tried to intimidate, threaten and silence by calling rallies to denounce us as traitors, but we knew then what the world knows now and we refused to give in.  Now we want the world to know that we are not all cut from the same cloth as Joseph Muscat and the criminals that he empowers because, when the world looks at Malta, they should see our face, a people standing up. They should see people like Michael and Rose, Peter and Matthew, Andrew and Paul, Daphne’s family whose search for justice sparked a light that even the darkest of forces could not extinguish.  We are closer to justice than ever before but we are not there yet. Muscat is still trying to cling to power for at least another 30 days of chaos – interfering, influencing and contaminating the investigation. He must resign immediately if my country stands any chance of moving forward.  This must be a catalyst for change. We need a new rule of law mechanism that looks at the situation in every Member State, and we needed it yesterday. People fighting corruption, abuse of power and criminality should never be faced with shrugs of shoulders, inaction or excuses that protect political allies. We need the whole truth, we demand justice, we must have accountability, and then we need a massive programme of reforms because, after Joseph Muscat, nothing can ever be the same again.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia was an act of terror that rocked my country, and as I have insisted before, I will insist again today: justice must be done and seen to be done. Since day one, the Maltese authorities sought the assistance of international specialists, including the FBI and Europol, and tangible results were achieved. Action has to be taken against whoever is responsible, whoever those persons may be. Malta is currently experiencing unprecedented circumstances that shook the whole society, and we want these realities to be addressed in a constructive manner. Several recommendations have been made. Some of the judicial changes proposed have already been carried out. Others, including recommendations by the Venice Commission and Country Specific Recommendations, are in the process of being carried out, and they will continue to be carried out. As the Maltese S&D delegation, we are committed to ensure that the reforms our country has started to implement will continue at a speedier pace so that there are no doubts cast on the impartiality of our institutions. We want to make sure that checks and balances will be ingrained at all levels. We are confident that the process under the oversight of the President of Malta to propose constitutional reforms will yield results. In the meantime, all alleged cases of corruption must be thoroughly investigated. No one is above the law, and the fact that time-barring on cases of political corruption was removed should ensure a judicial process in all cases, whenever they happened. Currently there are five ongoing magisterial inquiries on cases of alleged corruption, and yes, we want these inquiries to be concluded as soon as possible, for the benefit of all. Malta is currently going through a period of political transition until a new Prime Minister is appointed, and it would be counterproductive if this Parliament rushes into prejudgments that can also prejudice the ongoing investigations. I’m here to speak up for a country that showed that it listens; a country that is open to the recommendations made; a country that implements; and yes, to respond to those who find it convenient to harm Malta and its people at this hour. One final comment to the European Commission. Ms Jourová referred to this, but I urge you to propose, as quickly as possible, a rule-of-law mechanism made up of independent experts that monitors all the Member States in an objective and fair manner. It is what we really need, because conclusions that are not objective do not help anyone. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – I’m afraid that things are not as described by my colleague from the S&D, because reports continue coming that supporters of the Socialist Party in Malta are intimidating and deriding civil society activists and family members of Daphne Caruana Galizia. One Socialist minister has actually said that activists are acting in a provoking manner. Is this to you an acceptable statement from a minister within your political family?

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I have always been in favour of protests that are peaceful and non-violent. I think this is something that this House agrees on. A lot of protests have been going on and I do not find myself comfortable condemning any protests that are peaceful. Not so ever. There were also citizens in the office of the Prime Minister. I think that goes to show that protests are being carried out and that they are being carried out with all due respect to the process.

name: Michal Šimečka (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament delegation has indeed brought a threatening report from Malta on the state of the rule of law and the links between the oligarchy, the judicial system and the highest policy. And that's exactly the kind of corrupt system that allowed Daphne Caruana Galizia to be murdered and obstructed her investigation for years. As in Slovakia, this corruption system allowed the murder of Ján Kuciak and his fiancée. Indeed, it is incomprehensible today that, despite everything we know about the situation in Malta, the European Council cannot move or even provoke a political debate with Prime Minister Muscat, let alone some clear political stance. And governments and their leaders in the European Council must realise that the European Union will not survive if its values do not start to be taken seriously, if they themselves do not start to take its values seriously, because without mutual trust, that states and their leaders respect the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, neither the single market nor cohesion policy nor free movement will work. Indeed, values in this sense are not a luxury, but they are also the basis for the practical functioning of the European Union. It is therefore high time that their monitoring became an integral and firm part of the European project, on which all the institutions must work together, not only Parliament, not just the Commission, but above all the Member States themselves. We therefore need to set common criteria that apply equally to everyone, not as a substitute for Article 7 or other mechanisms, but as a complement to them. So that there can no longer be a corrupt system in any member country that allows a journalist to be murdered.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, two years ago, a courageous and determined woman, Daphne Caruana Galizia, an investigative journalist, was murdered for revealing corruption cases in the heart of the Maltese state. It was not aimed at any political party over another; it was not driven by partisan beliefs; she had no personal interest; it was just trying to reveal the extent of a widespread system of corruption in an island less populated than some French cities, where almost everyone can benefit from the system. Today, what she had discovered and these links between politics, government and corruption are coming to light and, worse, her murder seems to have been covered at the highest level of power. This concerns us, the Commission, Parliament and the Council, not only because the rule of law is a foundation of our European democracy - we regularly remind us in the case of Hungary, Poland and other states that break the rules of law - but also because this explosive situation in Malta has been able to develop because of the shortcomings of the European Union in terms of the rules against tax havens. Malta is not the only tax haven in the European Union; it should not be possible in the European Union to buy a citizenship at a price of gold. We cannot simply disapprove of it by saying,'"Certainly, it is immoral, but it is legal." No, it must no longer be legal, and if we can't do anything about it because it is the responsibility of the States, we should at least think about decoupling national and European citizenship in these specific cases of passport purchases. An entire culture in Malta was built on easy money, hosting oligarchs, hiding money laundering, and this seems to have rotten the institutions at the grassroots level. The systemic risks are immense today. Whatever the political colour of the government, we do not have to distribute good points and bad points between the different political forces here at European level. We need to challenge the overall golden passport process. We must also reaffirm the need for the rule of law in our European democracy, and this is the second lesson of this tragic history. The Commission proposes to create a rule of law mechanism which would include, among other things, an annual report on the rule of law in each Member State. This is an essential step, because the rule of law would finally become a priority for the European Union. Today, at Council level, at Commission level and for a decade, it is budgetary rules and monetary controls that are the only real requirements we have for the Member States. It is time for the rule of law to be as important to us as the structural adjustments of the Member States. We therefore expect the Council and the Commission to have the same courage on this issue and the same determination as investigative journalists and human rights defenders across Europe.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Mr President, we were all shocked by the murder of Daphne Caruana, who was killed in a car explosion on 16 October 2017. She had signed many articles, very fair, denouncing the endemic corruption in her country. Today, the noose has tightened around the socialist prime minister, Joseph Muscat, and the roguery that surrounds him - because it is indeed a rogue that surrounds him. Suspected of protecting his plan in the case of the journalist's murder, the Prime Minister on Sunday announced his resignation, which will not be effective until January. It is known that he interfered in the investigation. And yet we hear little of the condemnations of the Socialists in this Chamber. They should denounce this violation of human rights more strongly. As for the French socialists, eternal lecturers, almost radio silence. It is easy for the group to come to terms with the presence of the corrupt Maltese Labour Party. It is this government, this majority, this party that trades in passports, choosing an immigration of dubious billionaires or almost terrorist essence. But it is not Article 7, an illegitimate instrument of federalist essence, that will enable a resolution of this crisis. It's the people on the street. It is up to the Maltese people to choose their destiny. That this majority does not take advantage of a serious and real crisis to advance a federalist project rejected by the people, as the British vote last Thursday recalled. The Maltese Prime Minister has resigned; his whole government must do so, driven by the people. And new free elections, without the tutelage of the European Union, are to be held in Malta.

name: Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová (ECR).
text: – Mr President, when we talk about Malta, we also need to talk about Slovakia, how much it costs to murder a journalist. In Malta 150 thousand, in Slovakia 70 thousand EUR. The murders of Daphne Galizia and Ján Kuciak only revealed what you are constantly turning a blind eye to. And that is that the rule of law in these countries, the Member States of the European Union, has been dismantled literally into parts by mafia governments. While Brussels sends delegations and writes resolutions, corrupt politicians in these countries are using the time for disinformation campaigns. They blame Soros, they blame the outside world, and they make people feel that the truth is no longer worth it. In Slovakia, the Socialists, together with the fascists, have only recently enforced a 50-day electoral moratorium, and the President of the European Committee is already quite openly promoting communism there. Malta and Slovakia have one thing in common: they are ruled by parties belonging to the European Socialist family. Brussels must stop alibiistically protecting mafia governments in its own states, in its own Member States. We owe it to all decent Citizens of the Union to whom corrupt politicians have stolen their own state.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, some members of this Parliament had the opportunity to meet Daphne Caruana Galizia before she was murdered, when we were working in a parliamentary committee of inquiry where forms of opening accounts in tax havens were revealed by the Prime Minister's Chief of Staff by the now-resigning minister. Daphne Caruana Galizia collaborated with this Parliament and cooperated with one of the parliamentary committees and when she was murdered it was a part of the rule of law in Malta that was murdered as well. In fact, what we have in Malta is an open door to corruption, either through tax havens or through Gold visas. And, as I have just said, the fact that we do not have the necessary protection for investigative journalism is a guarantee that democracy does not work. We have a battalion of journalists who seek to protect democracy. We need to have a battalion of governors who defend investigative journalism and defend journalists. The presence of these members in the Government until about two weeks ago, muscat's presence in government, gives us no guarantee that there will be an impartial investigation into the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. And in that sense, we must appeal. Not in the sense of interference, but in the sense of respect and protection of the rule of law. Let Mr. Muscat retire. And, ladies and gentlemen, we must give ourselves respect. It's not a race to the bottom. It is not knowing who has the worst case, whether it is Malta, whether it is Hungary, if it is Poland, if it is Slovakia. It is the rule of law that is being buried in the European Union and that, yes, should concern us, that should bring us together to defend democracy.

name: Ignazio Corrao (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two years ago, immediately after the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, we held a debate here in the European Parliament. I would remind you that both Parliament, through the then President Tajani, and the European Commission, through Vice-President Timmermans, undertook to clarify what had happened.  I remember in my speech talking about the mafia method used to kill Daphne Caruana Galizia, because it was a very clear signal that no one should ever snoop on that kind of interest again. Now, after two years, where have we come? An entrepreneur has been arrested, other people have been arrested, it is clear that the government is involved, but it is not clear how the various Muscat, Mizzi and various other representatives are actually involved.  What is still unclear are also the causes that led, what Daphne Caruana Galizia was talking about, what she was talking about recycling, she was talking about corruption, she was talking about dirty interests, but she was also talking about projects in which there is funding from the European Commission, energy projects, power lines, gas pipelines, projects that are still financed by the European Commission, through the CEF and through the list of projects of common interest. That is why we still have to try to clarify matters. There are journalists who were detained a few weeks ago by the government, even if temporarily. It still seems to me that there is not too much desire, and so I hope that after this debate we can really insist and restore the rule of law to a State of the European Union.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Joseph Muscat and his government must resign immediately after the vote in this House.  The vote on our resolution will be a kind of European mistrust of its work and the work of its government. But Muscat must also resign in order to make it easier for the police and the judiciary to act, so that we can find out how far daphne Caruana Galizia's accomplices and sponsors and murderers had gone, to find out whether there were the ers of this horrific murder in the government building. The second reason is that it must resign in order to restore dignity to a country that cannot be regarded as the place where illegal trafficking takes place, where passports are sold to Russian tycoons, where dirty money is laundered. Malta is not that. Malta is a country that we all love and needs to have its dignity restored since the resignation of the Prime Minister.  And then his resignation must also tear up a veil over complicity in more or less lawly affairs with countries of our European Union, with the governments of our European Union, with fellow party members, former prime ministers.  And the European Union must do more than it has done to date. I also remember the defence in this Chamber in Muscat. The confrontation I had with the European Commission on this matter. The Commissioner was right to send a letter calling for the rule of law to be re-elected in Malta and for proper action to be taken.  Well, we want clarity, we want all countries to be treated in the same way, because a journalist was murdered in Malta. There is not only a normal violation of the rule of law, there is something even more serious, the murderers were hiding with complicity in the government building. That's why we need to resign. That is why it is only, Mr President, by restoreing dignity to Malta, by doing justice, that we will not make daphne Caruana Galizia's sacrifice in vain.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Jourová, Commissioner Reynders, it has been more than two years since the entire European Union accused shockingly of the knowledge of the brutal, levous and mafia murder of an investigative journalist in Malta, Daphne Caruana Galizia. We have paid tribute to his memory in this European Parliament on numerous occasions, but the story is not over. In the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which I have the honour to preside over, we heard the testimony of their three children—Andrew, Paul, and Matthew—and offered them our commitment, first of all, for justice to be done. Justice must be done. We've got to see that justice is done.  And that means entrusting that the police investigations involving the FBI, Europol and Interpol will completely lead to the clarification of all responsibilities falling, and that, of course, the judiciary will do its job in Malta. But there is more to it: the European message - in Malta and throughout the European Union - of the fight against corruption must be underlined in order to end the sale of golden passports, which open up access to the free movement of mobsters. In the European Union as a whole, in Malta and everywhere, money laundering from illicit businesses must be ended, and with collusion between political power and money, especially in a country that turns out to be a hard-hit territory, the smallest country in the European Union, with the smallest population in the entire European Union. But above all, we need to ensure that we are finally going to establish a rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy mechanism, which we have asked for time and time again in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. We support the missions that the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has deployed in Malta; the last one, urgently, resciently, just a week ago. And all its conclusions are made by us, but the rule of law mechanism must ensure that all The States of the Union regularly submit, on a regular basis, on a stable basis, in a safe manner, without criticism of political bias, to compliance with the founding parameters and values of the rule of law in the European Union, of the independence of justice in the European Union. And we also need to ensure that access to European Union funds and budgets is strictly contingent on compliance with the rules of the rule of law. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I believe that we all share in the House – and it has been said several times by the Socialist speakers – that the services must investigate, that we have confidence in the authorities, that they must investigate. And that there must be no prejudgment by us as European institutions, yes. But the political assessment has already been made. The Prime Minister has voluntarily submitted his resignation. The political assessment has already been made. That is why I cannot understand why the Socialist Group is still sticking with Muscat. I believe that Muscat must now clear the way to make it clear that the authorities can investigate independently. That is why the only demand that is still in the room is that he should not remain in office for another 30 days, but that he should now immediately submit his resignation. That would be the question for the Social Democrats: why are you not prepared to support this demand?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Weber, all the Member States of the European Union that stylating parliamentary democracy have their mechanisms for the purification of responsibilities, and it is for Malta to purge the responsibilities of its prime minister, but it has also been done, and the Prime Minister has offered his resignation. On that, however, it must be ensured that the rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy mechanism is complied with by all Member States and that strict anti-corruption requirements are strictly met that end the collusion between political power and money, in Malta and everywhere.  The prime minister is going to resign, he has offered his resignation, he has made it clear; and I can only say that, in this case, political responsibilities have been ventilated at the highest level. I said " whoever falls". Can something higher than the prime minister's office fall in Malta? This case has been charged, but the lessons to be debugging go much further: combating corruption and compliance with the rule of law, in Malta and everywhere.

name: Presidente. –
text: There were other blue card requests, but as is practical, and for time management, we will accept only one blue card per intervention.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Mr President, two years have passed since Daphne died. It has been too long and it has been too much. When this happened, 751 letters should have left this House to go to the Prime Minister’s office in Malta with one single question: who ordered Daphne Caruana Galizia’s murder and why? None of those ministers at the European Council should have shaken Muscat’s stained hands. Every single hour which passes with Muscat still in office, after everything that has happened, means defiance to the Maltese people and lack of respect towards the European values. Every single day which passes without us having European legislation to protect investigative journalists and to properly finance their projects and to protect them means a lost day. If we have a mission in this House, then this mission is to defend the rule of law, to defend justice and to stand up for those who actually fight for justice and finding the truth.  Poplu Malti, aħna magħkom. Ġustizzja għal Daphne.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galicia was a brutal attack on the freedom of media and the rule of law that she herself sought to protect. The fact that political figures seemingly enjoyed impunity in this case for a long time shows how dysfunctional the system of criminal justice and the rule of law in Malta has become. The murder and the lack of follow-up therefore exposed the deep crisis of the rule of law in a broadened sense and thus a serious problem with Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Yet over the past few years, the European Commission and the European Council refused to take any measures against the Maltese Government, and even now the Council remains silent.  Let us be very clear: the case of Daphne is not just a concern for national authorities. If all persons responsible for this crime are not brought to justice and if the complicity at the highest level and systematic corruption is not fundamentally solved, our shared system of fundamental values is failing. So it’s high time for the EU to speak up and send a clear message to all journalists in Europe. We will protect the much-needed checks and balances within each society, including the work of journalists and the freedom of media. We will make sure that this murder will not silence actors who want and who need to speak up. So my question to the Commission is: what will be the concrete steps of the new Commission towards the Maltese Government to ensure a due and independent process in this case? And will it make sure that, if Malta fails to correct its rule-of-law weaknesses and reform its judicial and institutional system, it will intervene? And isn’t it time that Member States became more vocal in addressing rule-of-law violations, not only in political dialogues but also by using the legal means they have at their disposal, such as state actions brought before the Court of Justice?

name: Isabella Tovaglieri (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the barbaric murder of the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia has brought to light at international level the system of illegality and corruption present in the institutions of a Member State of the European Union. A state certainly not led by a Conservative majority, often accused of being authoritarian and liberticidal, but by a Labour prime minister, who after the first burning investigations of the journalist Daphne resigned and called new elections to be re-elected and preserved, certainly not the public good, but corruption and malfeasing. Finally, that Prime Minister resigned, but certainly not because he was driven by his conscience, but by the incredible wave of popular protests and journalistic investigations, including by prestigious international newspapers, which continued the work of his colleague. Almost every day today, the Maltese people take to the streets and, for the first time in their history, they do so without party flags, but only and exclusively to demand that the Prime Minister leave office immediately before 18 January as announced, but above all to demand that politics change and that the institutions be drastically reformed.  Well, we must be at their side. For far too long, the European Union has not raised its voice sufficiently against a country in which the fundamental principles on which Western civilisation, freedom, democracy and respect for the law are deliberately violated.  Finally, a few days ago, a delegation from this Parliament was in Malta and found a serious danger to the rule of law. Not only have serious restrictions on the freedom of the press been established, a basic principle on which the democracy of each State is based, but also the risk to the autonomy and independence of the judiciary and, above all, violations of European and international money laundering laws.  It is no mystery that today a simple click of the computer is enough and in less than three days you can set up a company in Malta, with huge tax advantages. It is no coincidence that in Malta, there are more than 70 000 offshore companies, which are certainly not all illegitimate, but which are all too often used to circumvent and evade tax laws.  Europe has guaranteed the free flow of money between Member States, but it has yet to adjust the flow of information between police forces, especially with regard to financial and tax offences. It is no coincidence that many of the crimes reported by Daphne had a European dimension and involved several Member States.  Well, this situation in Europe can no longer be tolerated. For its part, the European Parliament is endeavouring to introduce a mechanism for monitoring the rule of law in its Own Member States, but it is essential that the Commission also intervenes with the right measures and, if necessary, with the necessary sanctions.

name: Dace Melbārde (ECR).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr I hope that dafnes' murderer will receive the punishment he has earned, and I hope that Malta will ensure an independent investigation and legal action so that the perpetrators of the crimes discovered by the journalist are brought to justice. The killing of a Maltese journalist forces us to think and take action to improve the legal framework, to strengthen media support so that journalists in Europe can do their job safely and independently. The European Commission must come up with proposals not only to prevent money laundering and corruption, but also to proposals that prevent strategic legal proceedings against journalists. We must also give legal support to journalists who, as a result of their professional activities, suffer physical attacks, unjustified legal proceedings and investigations, denigration campaigns and internet abuses, and unfortunately Malta is not the only case in this regard. The physical safety of journalists in Europe must be self-evident, but it is also important to ensure the social security of journalists. Measures to support quality journalism and the media should therefore be strengthened.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the case of Daphne Caruana is the visible face of a problem that has several faces. Not only could we be faced with a state assassination, but above all, his death sought to cover up a system of tax evasion and avoidance by large corporations. Daphne investigated the fabric of the so-called "Panama papers", involving not only the Government of Malta, but also billionaires and multinationals from all over Europe. What Daphne revealed was not a Maltese problem, but also a web of abuse and impunity of corporate power with the collusion of public authorities. A problem that overflows Malta's borders and also forces us to focus on the European Union as a whole. What Daphne Caruana denounced in the "Panama papers" and her murder remain unsolved.  This Parliament cannot look only at the specific case of Daphne and Malta. We must also address what Daphne Caruana he he denounced in her investigations. Justice for Daphne and her threatened family is also about doing justice against a state in the service of corporate power and impunity. It is urgent to take action in defence of the informants so that we do not have another Daphne Caruana case again. There are many Daphne Caruana in Europe. They need to be protected. It's urgent not to have such a murder again.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this Parliament took political leadership last year to protect journalists after the murders of Ján Kuciak and Martina Kušnírová in Slovakia. That was an extremely important step, and let me tell you, justice in Slovakia hasn’t yet been done. This is why it’s so important that everybody in this House exerts pressure for political change in Malta, because only with that political change can we create space – real space – for justice to be done. That’s why it is essential and that’s why we are here today, to be the leader of political change. But our voice is not enough. We need the Member States and we need the Commission to support the people of Malta, who deserve to know the truth. And that is going to take time, but the first step is political change. Prime Minister Muscat has said he will resign. Well, he should go now. He should resign now. This is the key message, and this is a message we are sending from this Parliament right here and right now. In addition to that, of course, we do need major changes in the way we discuss the rule of law in this House and in the European Union. We need a comprehensive mechanism that prevents events such as the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, and we need to work on it right now. We need to protect journalists and we need preventive measures. We can’t discuss crisis management after the murders happen, and that’s why we need the answers from the Commission, but also from the Member States, right now.

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D).
text: – Sur President, jien kburi li jien Malti. Kburi b'pajjiżi u mhu ser na大ikeetta qatt illi minħabba l-allegat għaġir tal-ftit, pajjiżi kollu, Malta sħiħa, tiġi ttimbrata daqslikieku kienet xi stat mafjuż. Mill-ewwel ġurnata wara dan id-delitt, il-Gvern ta l-għodda kollha lill-awtoritajiet u l-istituzzjonijiet tagħna sabiex ikollhom ir-riżorsi biex dan l-assassinju jiġi riżolt. Il-Pulizija – assist mill-Europol, assist mill-FBI – għamlet investigazzjoni b'reqqa kbira. U llum għandna l-allegati qattiela u l-allegat mandant illi qegħdin jaffa大大jaw il-ġustizzja. Is-serjetà li ħadmet biha l-Pulizija ġiet ikkonfermata wkoll mill-kap tad-delegazzjoni tal-Parlament Ewropew illiġimgħatejn beauty kienet f'pajjiżna. Aktar minn hedge, il-qrati qed jagħmlu xogħolhom b'libertà assoluta abbażi tal-pr大inipju fundamentali tas-separazzjoni tal-poteri u tas-saltna tad-dritt. Dawn huma kollha sinjali ħadd sabiex fl-aħħar mill-aħar il-ħħar il-ħizzja ssir u dan il il-każ jiġi riżolt. Għalhekk nemmen, li din ir-riżoluzzjoni li għandna quddiemna hija waħda inġusta ħafna mas-sitwazzjoni preżenti f'pajjiżi. Nirrikonoxxu li l-ebda sistema mhi perfetta, l-ebda pajjiż m'huwa perfett. U għaliex jiena Malti u għaliex inħobb lil pajjiżi, nifhem u nemmen bis-sħiħilli għandna xi ntejbu wkoll. Imma l-Gvern għamel u qed jagħmel ħafna xogħol sabiex jiġu attwati u implimentati r-rakkomandazzjonijiet kemm tal-Gumsjoni Venezja kif ukoll tal-Kunsill Ewropew. Sal-ġimgħa li għaddiet stess, waħda mir-rakkomandazzjonijiet ewlenin rigward il-poteri tal-Avukat Ġenerali ġiġiġet implimentata b'mod sħiħ. Il-ġustizzja nipproteġuha billi nsaħħu l-istituzzjonijiet u nħalluhom jaħdmu fil-libertà. Dan hu dak illi għamilna, dan hu dak illi ħa nkomplu nagħmlu. (Il-kelliem a大大etta li jwieġeb mistoqsija "karta blu" (Artikolu 171(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: blue card question. Mr President, because we in the European People's Party are truly Europeans and want a strong European Union, we defend the rule of law regardless of colour and ideology and we do not discriminate against anyone. We are proud as Europeans and proud of our member countries. Malta and the Maltese people are not being called in at the moment. He is currently being called in because he is exposing the country and the proud Maltese people, his government. How comfortable do you feel and how proud do you feel when it emerges, from the court evidence, that even the head of the Prime Minister's personal office is involved in the case and continues to remain at large? As does the Prime Minister of the country, who, two years later, has not been able to work out, since the investigations have not progressed, this brutal murder which is smearing not only Malta but also the European Union itself?

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D)
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Jiena kburi b'pajjiżi, collode dejjem u kullimkien. Niskanta li llum il-Grupp PPE uża enerġija kbira f'dan id-dibattitu. F'dibattiti oħrajn fejn pereżempju jkun hemm dibattiti fuq l-istat tas-saltna tad-dritt fl-Ungerija, il-ħeġa li market dik il-ġurnata tkun afħna u ħafna inqas, qalbħ taraqkom ħafna u ħafna inqas. Jiena kburi għal raġuni waħda: kburi għar-raġuni li l-istituzzjonijiet f'pajjiżna qegħdin jaħdmu u mhu qed iħarsu lejn wiħadd sabiex fl-aħħar mill-aħħar dak illi jixtieq kull Malti, dak illi jixtieq hawk wieħed go jseħħ – illi naraw dan il-każ illi xxokkja lil kulħadd fl-aħħar mill-aħħar jingħalaq billi ssir ġustizzja li ma tareħs lejn大ħħa ħadd. Dak li qed isir bħalissa. U għalhekk, nerġa' ngħidlek, iva għalhekk kburi b'pajjiżi!

name: Anna Júlia Donáth (Renew).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Daphne Caruana Galizia had to die to avoid revealing that corruption and the concentration of power in Malta had reached the highest levels of government. However, with his death, he managed to start something indirectly, highlighting a systemic problem and the fact that it really does affect the highest levels of political governance. It has now become clear that they have intervened from the highest levels of government in the investigation of the Galizia murder, as well as the fact that Maltese law enforcement authorities have not been functioning properly in cases of corruption and money laundering. This raises very serious rule of law problems. I welcome the fact that Commissioner Reynders has written to the Maltese Government to speed up judicial reform, but I would nevertheless ask the Commission to follow this reform process and raise its voice on every single systemic issue and error, be braver and clearer than its predecessors. I would also like to ask, as a Hungarian and European citizen, that we should not allow the government of any Member State to interpret the rule of law issues at the will of any Member State. It is in our common European interest that we all pay attention to them, whether it is Hungary, Poland or Malta, this is not an internal private matter of the Member States, it is our common European matter.

name: Alice Kuhnke (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Defending journalists' ability to scrutinize us politicians and other powers should be part of our DNA. It is precisely for this reason that it is a shame that the Maltese Government has acted inadequately following the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. And it is another disgrace that politicians and political groups in here, who claim to be Democrats, are acting with their willingness to hold those responsible to account.  The fact that you have lost your moral compass in pursuit of your own gain is truly a disgrace. Not only because Malta is a Member State, but also because every single politician, in every single assembly that undermines the rule of law, at the same time undermines democracy and trust between us politicians and the citizens, which is at the very heart of a democratic society.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Mr President, the highest peak of the Maltese state has been wet for two years now in a case of corruption and the murder of a whistleblower journalist, Daphne Caruana Galizia. A case that revealed the close links between the authorities and mafia organisations, but also the total bankruptcy of a Member State's judicial system. While the European Union and the Commission are usually so quick to react and punish states when they are reluctant to implement their policies, which are imposed on them, and when they refuse to submit to your dictates, their reaction has been so delayed in this scandal... Panama Papers, tax evasion, money laundering, passports of convenience: there is no shortage of failures in Malta, and cannot be summed up in this one sordid and extremely serious case. As you focus your attention on the so-called populist, democratically elected governments, you turn a blind eye to the mafia practices of certain leaders of Member States and react only when popular and media pressure obliges you to do so. This case should encourage you to be cautious about the integration procedures within the Union of new states where corruption, trafficking of all kinds and mafia are notoriously part of the scene. It should also encourage you to think about better protection for whistleblowers. Edward Snowden or Julian Assange have been able to see the cowardice of some governments and European institutions in this area. We remain defenders of state sovereignty. The Maltese people, who have shown their courage for several months on the streets of the country, are the only legitimate way to democratically sweep away those in power who continue to engage in such practices.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The case of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, back in 2017, has proved to be a political soup that reaches all the way up to Prime Minister Joseph Muscat. The investigation has been dragged out and time has been taken, but finally it is clear that this has links right up to prime minister level. Unfortunately, the EU is then a toothless tiger with no claws and power, but at least we Members can show our support and demand justice for Galizia, her family and, not least, democracy. I myself come from a country with a hard left-wing journalistic corps. But we must never, ever accept that journalists are murdered when they do their work as investigative journalists. I would therefore like to say to Malta and perhaps especially Prime Minister Muscat: take your responsibility now and let Daphne Galizia and her family have justice.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate our colleagues on the far right, who are true Tartuffes of press freedom and who today give us great lessons. "Without corruption, Daphne would still be alive": these are the words of the murdered journalist's husband, Daphne Caruana. We all agree here that we need to shed some light on this matter. But beyond the violation of the fundamental rights of the independent press, it is to his family that I would like to think, who is waiting for answers. We all share the responsibility for this murder, ladies and gentlemen. Our collective renunciation in the face of corruption also killed Daphne. Do we still have to have journalists dying for us to talk about it here? Who remembers that a very close political advisor to Prime Minister Édouard Philippe, also a Maltese political advisor, resigned to protect Édouard Philippe? He will soon be an MEP. Who remembers that Malta is governed by a government of a so-called socialist party, a member of the PES, and whose members sit in this Chamber? How long are we going to give lessons backwards, instead of taking urgent measures to curb the corruption that threatens and democracy, and the free and independent press, and the lives of whistleblowers? I ask you, ladies and gentlemen: how long will we have to accept that journalists die to highlight the failures of our rulers?

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Sur President, nibda billi nitlob skuża, skuża għall-mod kif aġixxa u għadu qed jaġixxi l-Gvern Malti. Onestament, qatt ma emmint illi nista' nasal biex nistħi mill-Gvern ta' pajjiżi daqskemm qed nistħi llum. St. Nistħi mill-click ta' kriminali li ħadu l-Gvern Malti f'idejhom. Stħi mill-istituzzjonijiet ta' pajjiżi li m'għamlux xogħolhom. Nistħi li qatlu lil Daphne Caruana Galizia. Però, il-Gvern Malti mhuwiex Malta. Dawn il-ftit kriminali i jirrappreżentawx flower-poplu Malti u Għawdxi. Il-poplu Malti u Għawdxi ta' veru qiegħed fit-toroq jipprotesta f'pajjiżi. Poplu reżiljenti, poplu b'saħħtu, poplu li huwa kuraġġuż. Dawn huma l-vera Maltin ta' pajjiżi. U filwaqt li l-Gvern Malti jġiegħlni nistħi, il-poplu Malti lili jagħmilni kburi. Kburi li aħna i nħallux lil min ikasbarna. Kburi li aħna nagħrfu li fost l-aqwa ġurnalisti li kien hawn f'dan il-kontinent, Daphne hija waħda minnhom. Daphne hija l-vera Maltija. Issa però, irridu azzjoni fuq livell Ewropew. Daqshekk kliem vojt, sentenzi vagi, u wegħdiet ta' monitoring. Azzjoni issa mill-Kunsill li huma assenti llum u mill-Rubber biex taqdu dmirkom. Qumu minn hemm u pproteġu flower-poplu Malti u Għawdxi. A大大eraw illi l-istituzzjonijiet tagħna jkunu fuq in-naħa taħa-ikeittadini. Il-poplu Malti u Għawdxi għandu d-dritt għal dan kollu. Jien kburi li flimkien ma' Roberta (Metsola) ninsabu mal-poplu Malti u Għawdxi. Kburi li jien parti minn din il-familja hawnhekk illi dejjem, dejjem f'dawn is-sentejn kienet favur il-poplu Malti u Għawdxi!

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are principles that must never and anywhere be compromised. At a time when we are seeing more and more countries disregarding our common values, the reaction must be even more pressure on the Member States to immediately change their course and respect them again. Nothing else is acceptable. We must have a system in which countries cannot act without consequences. Murder, violence and intimidation against journalists are a despicable way of silencing dissidents and preventing scrutiny. It has no place in Europe or anywhere else in the world. The investigation into the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia is therefore of the utmost importance and must therefore be allowed to continue in total independence until the murderers and all other those responsible are revealed and have their sentences. It is a question of fundamental human rights. It is a question of the rule of law. The assistance that has come from Europol and dutch police authorities has been important for the progress achieved so far, and it must be allowed to continue. Restoring public confidence requires decisive changes in Malta.  My own and my political group's basic position is crystal clear: fundamental rights and the rule of law should apply throughout Europe, in all Member States. Malta has received criticism in this area in the past from the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, an advisory body composed of independent experts on constitutional and international law. In December 2018, an opinion was adopted which identified shortcomings and proposed changes. I expect whoever takes over as Prime Minister of the country to continue the implementation of the necessary reforms soon.

name: Fabienne Keller (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Didier Reynders, Commissioner Vera Jourova, the murder of Maltese investigative journalist and blogger Daphne Caruana Galizia on 16 October 2017 in Valletta, close to her home, shocked all of Europe. Maltese citizens stood up to protest against this heinous act. Some Maltese colleagues remind us that they are still marching in their thousands to demand justice. Two years later, with the support of Europol, the investigation led to revelations last month about the involvement of the highest levels of the Maltese state, and in particular the Prime Minister, Joseph Muscat, in the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia. It was investigating, it should be remembered, cases of widespread corruption in Malta. Malta is a country of the European Union in its own right and these offences threaten the integrity of our entire space, as my colleagues, Sophie in't Veld and Anna Donth, have pointed out at the moment. Then I would have two questions for you. Here is the first: Parliament is closely following the progress of this investigation into journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia on the state of the rule of law. The same cannot be said of the Council, the empty seat of the Council this morning. Are you going to ask the Council to engage in such a debate? The second question is this: the Venice Commission, of the neighbouring Council of Europe, has already made recommendations to undertake in-depth institutional reforms in Malta, ensure press freedom, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption. What support do you intend to give to the Council of Europe, to the Venice Commission, to move forward with Malta and adopt these reforms?

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Daphne Caruana Galizia was murdered for doing her job as a journalist. She was killed for exposing gross corruption in Malta, and I would like to start by paying tribute to the dignified way in which Daphne’s family have continued their campaign for justice. We should honour them by rooting out corruption and ensuring that we act, as EU Member States, to uphold European values. The findings of the Parliament’s mission to Malta raise concerns about the progress of Daphne’s murder investigation, and our MEPs also found that other investigations into possible money laundering and corruption had either not started or are not being conducted vigorously enough. There are questions to be answered over the independence of the Maltese judiciary and allegations of corruption that extend to the highest levels of government. We cannot allow an EU Member State to operate like a mafia state. I’ve worked a lot on Latin America and witnessed the way that the corrupting influence of dirty money can undermine the rule of law and lead to impunity from justice. We’ve also failed in this Parliament to deal with money laundering and tax evasion adequately, and that’s something we really need to take seriously, because it can corrupt a democracy, undermine people’s confidence in democracy and, ultimately, undermine European institutions themselves. Daphne Caruana Galizia stood for the highest and finest European values. To honour her memory we must take all necessary action to uphold the rule of law in Malta.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the fight against corruption and organised crime is much more than a declarative commitment to transparency and better legal regulation, which we often witness in parliamentary life. As a member of the Croatian Parliament myself, I led the fight against narcotics on my island, so I felt on my skin all the dangers that a man and his family are threatening when exposed like that. Many have sacrificed the most valuable things in the fight for the public interest; your health, your life. We are eternal debtors to them and we must make every effort to fight crime so that their sacrifice is not in vain. Maltese journalist Daphne Galizia put the interests of Maltese society and the state ahead of her own. She paid the ultimate price for it and it would be truly shameful if the circumstances of her murder remain unresolved. I urge the Maltese authorities and the European institutions to do everything they can to ensure that this case is resolved as soon as possible, and everyone involved in the assassination brought to justice.

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, according to the Council of Europe’s Platform for the Protection of Journalism and Safety of Journalists, more than half of the cases of abuses against media professionals are committed by state actors. Daphne Caruana Galizia was assassinated on 16 October 2017, and two years later, every aspect of the case is susceptible to political interference from the Office of the Prime Minister. The Union must use all tools at its disposal to guarantee media freedom and the protection of journalists in its Member States. We need investigative journalism to learn about structural rule-of-law issues like the high-level corruption cases that Daphne was reporting. If the Union does not give due consideration to the calls of the Maltese citizens, the lack of public confidence will be transferred to the EU itself. And those tools and procedures at the disposal of the Commission to ensure full compliance with Union law must be deployed not only in Malta but also in the Member States, to respect human rights in the case of refugees who die in the Mediterranean Sea as well as the fundamental rights to political participation and the exercise of the right to decide of the peoples of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE)
text: blue card question. – A member of your group has just said that there are many Daphnes Caruanas in Europe. I have here the relationship of attacks by the terrorist gang ETA against media and journalists, including four murders and a thwarted murder. You have not condemned any of them, and not only have you not condemned them, but you have justified and supported them. You have the opportunity to say here today, before talking about freedom of expression, as you are doing, if you condemn all ETA crimes, including, of course, those who have been directed against journalists and the media.

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Look, Mr Zarzalejos, the death of any citizen, not only of the European Union, but of this world and, in particular, professionals of the media, is deeply mis-elected and, of course, will always have the consideration and commiseration of this parliamentarian, as I suppose that of the other members of this House. I would like to tell you that your intervention is entirely on your side. You have also been part of strategies that have closed media and that have acted directly against freedom of expression from instances such as the Spanish Government and at all I do not allow or grant you any ... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Andrzej Halicki (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab When I read these documents from Malta, I am shocked. Colleague Bilčík recalled Slovakia, but I have other associations – associations as worst. I am Polish, and I recall the journalists, social activists or priests who did not fit the power, killed by so-called unknown perpetrators. The power that covers up political murders cannot have acceptance among democratic governments. It cannot have partners, it cannot have approval in this House for a single day. Such power must go away. Moreover, no power that puts itself above the law can be accepted in the democratic community that we are.  The resolution that we will adopt tomorrow, I hope, will open a new chapter: free elections, a government of public confidence and then reforms that affect the justice system. In this House, I hope, without any political calculation, that we must speak unanimously tomorrow together with the Maltese people in full solidarity. We owe it to the Maltese people, because democracy and freedom in this House must be guaranteed precisely by resolutions such as tomorrow's.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the rules must be the same for all, especially when we are talking about justice, about the rule of law and especially when we are talking about people's lives. I am amazed and concerned that two years after this tragic death nothing has yet happened and that is why I think we need the same rules.  When we talk about people's lives, when we talk about states, about the rule of law, things have to be respected. And if we are talking about the CVM, about those cooperation and verification mechanisms, about what is happening in various European countries, the same Mechanism should work for each state, and those who are subject to evaluation should benefit from the same presumption of innocence, so that things are put into practice.
