I note important steps taken in Malta in terms of resolving this case and the fact that they are open to European collaboration. So, Madam President, honourable members, let us make the rules the same for all and every European state, every European citizen treated the same.

name: Antony Hook (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Daphne Caruana Galizia had a family and friends who mourn her and who must feel a pain that no one should ever have to experience. Some may say that this murder, in which it is alleged there was state collusion, is a matter for Malta only. They are wrong. The rule of law is vital for the freedom of every person. A threat to freedom in one place is a threat to freedom in every place. No country is immune to corruption, whether financial, violent or interference in criminal investigations. Daphne Caruana Galizia was investigating money laundering, tax evasion and other evils. Her murder was barbaric and futile because others will surely take up the challenge of exposing wrongdoing and there should be EU law to protect journalism.  It is clear that the mission from the European Parliament has taken the quest for truth forward. This should not be the last time the Parliament take such action. The EU is a set of promises, including a promise to the people of Europe that the rule of law will be upheld. It does not matter which Member State. It does not matter which political family politicians may come from. The only things that matter are truth and impartial justice.

name: Daniel Freund (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The longer the investigation in Malta continues, the more the extent of the rule of law crisis in Malta becomes clear: money laundering, tax evasion, the sale of citizenship to oligarchs, corruption all the way to the Prime Minister's office, a lack of separation of powers. I spoke last week with Daphne's son in Brussels, who once again described very impressively and emotionally the situation of a small corrupt elite taking over Malta. The EU cannot tolerate such a situation, because there is no democracy, there is no freedom of the press in the European Union when research into corruption ends with death. The corrupt take advantage of the freedom of money flowing, freedom of travel and the protection mechanisms of the rule of law. But we must ensure that the EU, the judiciary, the police work better together than the corrupt. That we coordinate better, that crime is also combated at European level and that we give ourselves the effective tools to deal with such situations. We urgently need a rule of law mechanism for the EU.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Madam President, 26 months ago the voice of Daphne Caruana Galizia was silenced: a brave and fearless voice dedicated to fighting corruption and to standing up for human rights – for our rights – and her assassination is a blow to us all. It strikes at the heart of our society. And therefore we must fight for justice for Daphne. The murderers, but also everybody else involved – the middlemen, the masterminds, those providing political cover – must be identified and prosecuted. Impunity must end in Malta. But how can we expect justice when there is no rule of law? How can we trust in an independent investigation as long as the Prime Minister continues to cling to power? Can we really expect the same people that have been obstructing justice for the past 26 months, the same people that have been demolishing the memorials that were erected in honour of Daphne’s memory – can we really expect these people now suddenly to lead the charge in seeking justice that the family of Daphne so deserves? How naive are we exactly supposed to be? The Venice Commission already concluded over a year ago that the wide powers of the Prime Minister create a serious risk for the rule of law, and we see that risk now in Malta day after day after day. And every minute longer this Prime Minister stays in the centre of power is a minute where justice can escape for us. Therefore, dear colleagues, let me finish with the only word in Maltese that I know. ‘Prime Minister Muscat: barra!’ (‘Get out!’)

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D).
text: – Sinjura President, jien Maltija u napprezza s-serjetà tar-rivelazzjonijiet tal-aħħħar ġimgħat u xxukkjata bħall-kumplament tal-pajjiż. Aħna l-Maltin impenjati li ssir ġustizzja ma' kull min kien involut. Ma jkunx ġust imma li l-għaġir ħażin ta' individwi jintuża biex jitfa' dell fuq l-Istat Malti kollu. Nispera li l-għan hu li nsaħħu l-valuri li jagħmluna Ewropej. Mhux li nieħdu pożizzjoni mgħaġġla għal skopijiet partiġjani meta l-investigazzjonijiet għadhom miftuħa. Hija riżoluzzjoni prematura biex tkun ta' min joqgħod fuqha. Niftakru li qegħdin f'dan l-istadju, għax kif ikkonfermat id-delegazzjoni tal-Kumitat LIBE stess, il-Pulizija Maltia wettqet xogħol serju flimkien ma' entitajiet bħall-Europol. Malta waqfet, fehmet u ddeảidiet. Misery proảess biex insaħħu l-istituzzjonijiet u mhux se nieqfu qabel ikollna r-riforma kostituzzjonali li hemm bżonn. Hekk qegħdin, b'mod sistematiku, inqawwu d-democracies f'Malta u mhux bil-kontra. B'responsabbiltà insostni li f'dan iż-żmien ta' tibdil, azzjoni fuq Malta la se tagħmel ġid u lanqas se tkun ġusta mal-poplu Maltai u Għawdxi.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: Mr President, I find it baffling that we should have this debate. Investigative journalist, blogger and mother of three, Daphne Caruana Galicia, was dastardly murdered simply because she did her job. Maybe it's because she was doing too well. We now know that corruption and organised crime in Malta are very closely intertwined with the highest political circles. And Malta is part of Europe, so what touches Malta affects the rest of Europe as well. I think you all agree with me when I say that Europe has the right to honest politicians and journalists who can do their work independently without being intimidated or threatened with death. Europe needs independent justice. I therefore urge you to react quickly and violently and to enter into dialogue with Malta – rather today than tomorrow.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: Madam President, following the arrest of a close associate of Prime Minister Muscat and the revelations of officials' involvement in the murder of journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, citizens are persistently calling for the resignation of the government and the Prime Minister. My fellow MEPs who visited Malta expressed strong concern about the developments, and European leaders are now called upon to take a stand. Despite escalating reactions and apparent disharmony between government and society, Prime Minister Muscat is now refusing to resign. Why doesn't he? Are those who think he is directing political interference in the work of justice wrong? Colleagues, when government officials are accused of covering up heinous crimes, mafia execution of a struggling journalist and widespread corruption, fundamental rights have been dealt a major blow. The refusal to resign by Prime Minister Muscat, which is interpreted as an attempt to prevent the smooth functioning of the institutions, is a major issue and concerns us all. The solidarity that we owe to every Member State now is more necessary than ever, because the rule of law, which in Malta today is being shaken every day, is the cornerstone of our values for the European Union. That is why it is our duty to stand vigorously, in practice, on the side of the Maltese people and to support their fight to restore democratic legitimacy.

name: Elena Yoncheva (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as a former investigative journalist, I cannot explain how much this discussion means to me, and I won’t try to hide my emotions. What happened in Malta is a huge tragedy and we need to ensure that justice will be served and Daphne Galizia won’t be forgotten. But, at the same time, we need to realise that many journalists in Europe are threatened and intimidated by people in power. In Bulgaria, for example, the index of media freedom is the lowest in the EU. Media pluralism is almost absent. Corruption at all levels is spreading.  I think it’s time to stop playing political games and start acting. We cannot pretend that what happened in Malta is an isolated national problem. There are similar symptoms in many Member States. We need to go much further than just condemning the situation in a resolution. We need a European mechanism that will allow us to identify the shortcomings in the system before we witness the next tragedy. I urge the Commission not to hide behind soft measures. We need comprehensive solutions and concrete proposals, and we need them now.

name: Caroline Voaden (Renew).
text: – Madam President, firstly might I congratulate our parliamentary delegation to Malta for ensuring that the corruption, scheming and impunity in that country is held under a spotlight. These things that undermine our democracies and the legitimacy of our political systems flourish in darkness. All involved have done well to shine a light on Malta. Parliament has done well to force the Council and the Commission to take note, but we must ensure that the Council and the Commission take firm action to guarantee the integrity of Malta and of all our democracies. As a former journalist myself, when I look at the situation for independent journalism across Member States, I shiver. Daphne Caruana Galizia is murdered, the Maltese Government has questions to answer and the S&D conveniently forget their voices. The EPP ignores and tacitly complies in the silencing of the Hungarian press and earlier this year in my own country, Lyra Mckee, a young LGBT journalist, was murdered in Northern Ireland. These are just a few examples of the situation across the continent. Colleagues, I urge all of you to apply the utmost passion in holding the Maltese Government to account, but do not stop there. Ensure that no journalist, no political or civil society activist dies in vain. I urge all of you to forget political convenience, forget the difficulties of taking action against a Member State and deliver strong, efficient legislation that delivers for all European citizens.

name: Karoline Edtstadler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Murder is not time-barred, every murder is a murder too much, and every murder leaves family and friends not only with their grief alone, but above all with the desire for full enlightenment. As a former criminal judge, I have experienced this up close on several occasions. But there are murders that have a far greater meaning. The cold-blooded murder of the Maltese investigative journalist is an attack on press freedom. It is an attack on our values in our united Europe. A woman's life is being wiped out because she never tires of fighting corruption and the rule of law. A woman's life must end because she is silenced and silenced forever, and the wire-pullers are in the Prime Minister's immediate vicinity. And now I ask you, ladies and gentlemen: what reason could it be not to demand the immediate resignation of the Prime Minister?  What is stopping the S&D from vehemently advocating this here in the plenary of the European Parliament and not paying lip service. The murder must be investigated and, in all its facets, also presented to the public. There is no doubt about that. However, the S&D Group's adherence to Muscat as Prime Minister, whether for one or three more days, is completely unworthy of our values in the European Union. Let us imagine that this had happened in another state outside the European Union! What kind of speeches we would hear here in the European Parliament, especially from the ranks of the S&D. I therefore call for immediate consequences, the resignation of Prime Minister Muscat, so that Malta is once again free to tackle the reforms that are necessary to establish the rule of law and an independent judiciary.

name: Katarina Barley (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, the organization Reporters Without Borders has drawn up its annual balance sheet for 2019. This year, 49 journalists have been killed worldwide in connection with their profession, 57 media professionals have been kidnapped, and 389 media professionals have been imprisoned for their work last year. A large proportion of these journalists have paid with freedom or even life for having stepped on the feet of the powerful in their work, for uncovering grievances, for threatening power. So did Daphne Caruana Galizia. The assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia was the second anniversary of the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia in October. As a journalist, she paid for her commitment to the truth with her life. Our solidarity is with her and her family. We owe them to act.  Daphne Galizia's fight for transparency and against corruption was not in vain. She must also be personally justice.  There are three things that apply. Firstly, we will do our part to ensure that all those responsible and complicit in her death and the crimes she wanted to expose are held accountable. The whole truth must come to light.  Secondly, we must ensure that journalists are able to carry out their work safely. A free press, which can also be a threat to the powerful, is fundamental to our society and a functioning rule of law in all EU Member States and worldwide.  We must fight the root of the problem. We must combat this, which is why Daphne Caruana Galizia was an investigative officer. We must not stand by when the values of the rule of law are trampled underfoot. We must stand up and act to combat corruption, to combat money laundering, to protect the independence of the judiciary and independent prosecution. We must examine the allocation of the so-called golden visas and passports, which exist in 17 Member States of the European Union, and impose rules on them.  We also need to strengthen a free and self-confident civil society that can speak out when fundamental problems arise. We need an early mechanism to combat the conditions we have now seen in Malta much earlier. We need the mechanism for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. We owe it to Daphne Caruana Galizia.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Madam President, journalists are pursuing a profession that aims to defend democracy and freedom, we should strive for the same. Truthful information and transparent action should be a matter of course. Yet we are faced with cases where investigative journalists lose their lives under unexplained circumstances. This is exactly the case with the Maltese journalist Daphne Galizia. It has been several years since this lady lost her life, and her relatives and friends, as well as colleagues, continue to live in the uncertainty of what actually happened. It is right that, at the end of the year, we have put this very item on the agenda. We mustn't keep quiet about the murders of journalists. The conclusions of the inquiry are still unclear, but we, as the European Parliament, should send out a clear signal that we want the murder to be explained and for anyone responsible for it to be responsible, even if it should perhaps hold high-ranking positions. Before the law, we're all equal. Ladies and gentlemen, I come from the Czech Republic and in our neighbouring country, Slovakia, a journalist, Ján Kuciak, was also murdered, as my colleagues from Slovakia have mentioned. I would like his name to be mentioned here, because both cases follow exactly the same line. I would very much like both cases to be properly investigated, not only so that their families can find peace, but to send a clear signal – we are allowed to tell the truth, we are allowed to write the truth, and none of us will be in any danger, let alone loss of life, because of it.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first I would like to say that today, in having this debate, we pay tribute to Daphne Caruana Galizia because she was – she is – a martyr for freedom in the European Union. Then I must say that I am ashamed because the Commission is too shy, the Council is too silent and some colleagues, especially from the S&D Group, do not have the courage to say what they would say if a journalist in Russia was murdered, or a journalist in Turkey who was murdered. If a journalist were to be persecuted in China, the S&D would have here a debate with all the courageous. And then, when we are in the European Union, in our smallest country, you don’t have the courage to say that this is a shame and this is against the rule of law.  If Mr Muscat is so democratic and so attached to the rule of law, why doesn’t he resign? He could do a service to democracy, to transparency and to a clean and serious investigation, but he doesn’t do it. He would serve the European Union, not only the Maltese people, if he resigned immediately, and that is the claim that I hope that the S&D can do now. If you have courage, please say to Joseph Muscat, ‘resign, and save the honour of the Maltese people and the honour of the European Union’.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Madam President, that Malta faces serious problems of governance is clear. They arose in the context of the horrendous murder of journalist Ms Caruana Galizia and also beyond. The murder has been duly investigated in past years and disclose the big result. There have been fatal failures of judgment even at the top level. The political price for them is being paid. The situation in Malta now is one of transition, both at the political level and that of the criminal investigation. What is needed is a dispassionate review of the situation, leading to reforms that will ensure no future repetition of past mistakes. True, the criminal investigation arrived at sensational findings, even more sensational allegations have been made on that basis. We have heard them being repeated during this debate, mostly for political jockeying. This runs contrary to the interests of the Maltese people whose commitment to European values is secure. When considering how European values are being respected, we must follow objective criteria applied, to all, by an institution that all can trust. The resolution on which we shall vote tomorrow combines findings, allegations, one sided interpretations in a statement that paints black everything Maltese. It also blacks out the economic, social and cultural progress achieved in Malta during the past years, which is not fair. Soon in Malta there will be a new Prime Minister, heading a new government. They will be committed to a new beginning on governance issues to correct the radical failures of the past, on meting out justice and punishment to all those responsible for the Caruana Galizia assassination, on ensuring a better separation of powers and governance, on combating corruption, on promoting transparency in government affairs. These objectives will be given total priority.  Such commitments will be carried out in all good faith by the Malta Government – that we guarantee.   The current transition should be given a chance to develop. Making premature judgments about it is not the right way. There has to be a right way for the Assembly to consider the affairs of Malta, one that will be applied equally to other Member States like Hungary or Poland. No matter how well intentioned, the direction in which this debate has been driven is not the right way. Not the right way for Malta, neither is it the right way for Europe, we need a better way.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Anyone who murders journalists is killing democracy. Because without freedom of the press, every freedom is nothing. That is why the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia is so dramatic, because it calls into question the freedom of the press and the rule of law, not only in Malta, but throughout Europe. I would therefore like to thank our colleagues in the European Parliament and, in particular, under the leadership of Sophie In 't Veld, for their on-the-spot investigation. And I would like to go along with her call for the Prime Minister to resign at long last so that the investigation there is not further jeopardised. Mr Muscat, resign! And dear S&D: finally join this demand. I do not understand at all the argument that the previous speaker has just invoked, that there will soon be a new government. Yes, then he can resign now and ensure that the investigation is not further jeopardized. That would be logical to demand this in this European Parliament at last. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which However, the situation also shows that we are now discussing the rule of law in Europe at various points, and this is not a geographical question of East or West, that is a question of Europe. We must protect fundamental values throughout Europe, we must protect freedom of the press throughout Europe, we must protect the rule of law throughout Europe and we must protect journalists in particular, and that is why this murder must finally be fully investigated and the rule of law restored in Malta.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia was a contract killing. There seem to be deep-seated structures of money laundering and corruption in Malta, whose entanglements extend to the highest circles of the socialist government and whose masterminds do not shy away from murderous violence. Two government ministers have already resigned and, as mentioned, the Prime Minister has announced his resignation. I ask: what is the Prime Minister waiting for? Muscat must resign immediately, signaling clearly that he is no longer standing in the way of the criminal investigation. Only if he resigns immediately can the suspicion that members of the government themselves are involved in the structures of organised crime and stand in the way of the necessary clarification. The European Union stands for the rule of law, and the rule of law is a great asset. There can be no doubt about what Europe stands for. Across the borders of all political camps, these scandalous events must be condemned and the protection of the rule of law must be put before any political interest.  I am also addressing our colleagues in the S&D and the Left. It is finally time to show tactical restraint and take a clear position. Mrs Sippel, Mrs Barley, I have listened to you: not a single word, not a single word about your party friend, about Mr Muscat. Not a single word that you also believe that action must be taken immediately.  I think this is a very implausible policy and I would be very grateful if you could perhaps speak out again today about the accusations that are in the air – and murder is murder.

name: Peter Pollák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the brutal murders of journalists in Malta and Slovakia have revealed how far corruption and the mafia can go to the highest levels in politics, the prosecution service, the courts, and how helplessly the European institutions are looking at this. The heinous murders of journalists Daphne Galizia and Ján Kuciak and his fiancée show us how weak Europe is. The task of the European Union, our European Community, is also to set up a mirror of its own. Even to those who are part of our community. Corruption problems are in many countries. In Malta and Slovakia, long before the murder of journalists, institutions should have set up a mirror for the governments that ruled there. They didn't set up this mirror. Two innocent people also died because of the indifference of many institutions. I call on all the European institutions to exert as much pressure as possible in the case of Malta so that the investigation of the case in Malta takes place without any influence from politicians, judges and prosecutors. For this reason, it is essential that everyone, including the Prime Minister of Malta, who may be soaked in this murder, should leave their posts. At the same time, let the case of Malta and Slovakia be a lesson to the European Union that, if it has clues and knowledge of corruption or mafia practices, it must not be weak and must take tough measures. In our home in Slovakia, but also in Malta, corruption and the mafia have gone so far that they have not only stolen but also murdered. We must return law and justice to the people. A state laundered by the people, not by the mafia.

name: Balázs Hidvéghi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, a word of respect for Daphne Caruana Galizia, for her sacrifice and her work. This is a cornerstone of democracy. Obviously we stand up for her and what she represented.  But what we see here today is really the hypocrisy of the left, and especially of the S&D Group, and I think this is outrageous. Instead of being clear about it and instead of calling on the Maltese Prime Minister to step down, they are wishy—washy about it. There is a lack of clarity and a lack of clear will to act on their side. This hypocrisy actually undermines anything, and especially credibility, when they talk about the rule of law elsewhere. They are busy now talking about Hungary and Poland. Well, I have to say it’s outrageous and ridiculous even mentioning in one sentence what happened in Malta and any political debate that we may have about things in Poland and in Hungary. We have to be very clear about it. We have to stand up clearly for these basic values.  Where is the S&D faction? They even tried to take this item off the plenary session agenda this week. Why? Where is the strength you show regarding these issues at other times? Where is your readiness to talk about these issues? You need to be standing up for values without any double standards, and with the same standard for everybody. So I’m looking for that commitment from the S&D Group.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D)
text: mistoqsija karta blu. – Jekk hawn naħseb xi ħadd illi qiegħed f'kontradizzjoni kbira huwa politiku mill-Ungerija mill-partit tal-Fidesz illi qed jipprova jattakka u juża l-argument tas-saltna tad-dritt. Id-differenza bejn Malta u l-Ungerija hija waħda: aħna qed nagħmlu l-emendi abbażi [dak] li qed jgħaddulna min-naħa tal-Kunsill Ewropew u tal-Kummisjoni Venezja – emendi ta' sistemi lihom ilhom in place mis-s sittninin, minn meta ħadna l-Indipendenza. Il-gvern tal-partit tiegħek qed jibdel il-liġijiet sabiex jimmina d-demokrazija he' pajjiżek, is-saltna tad-dritt ta' pajjiżek illum. Aħna qed nagħmlu bil-kontra, dik hija d-differenza tagħkom. Aħna qed mmexxu 'l quddiem emendi sabiex insaħħu s-saltna tad-dritt, il-partit tiegħek qed imexxi 'l quddiem emendi sabiex ikasbar u jnaqqas is-saltna tad-dritt f'pajjiżek.

name: Balázs Hidvéghi (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much. Well, very simply, it is just that this Prime Minister Muscat needs to go. He needs to go right away. There is a murder. Let me just repeat that. There is a murder of a journalist in Malta and there are links to the Prime Minister’s office.  I mean he should just simply resign. You should have new elections and asked the people of Malta to act. In Hungary, we may have a political debate, we may have a debate with the Commission at times – very well, that’s what Europe is about, political debate. It doesn’t even compare to what’s happened in Malta. This is outrageous and, again, the hypocrisy of the left is just outstanding in this matter.  (Applause)

name: Ralf Seekatz (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which "Murder plot in the anteroom of the Head of Government" was the title of the Neue Züricher Zeitung on 8.12. We know what this means and it has a very different quality, as the previous speaker from Hungary said. Defending the freedom of European citizens is the most important duty of this House, regardless of the colour of the government. This quote was made by Bullmann, then chairman of the S&D Group, in September 2018. The S&D has joined the discussion, now they are clinking up. The events in Malta are shocking. We should and must now do everything we can to ensure that a proper rule of law is finally provided for. I am deliberately not saying that we are returning to the rule of law, because we are still a long way from being in Malta, there is still work to be done. Now there must be a rigorous enlightenment. In order to allow for a full investigation, Muscat must, of course, resign directly so that further evidence and other things do not disappear. But one thing particularly shocks me here, and that is the behavior of the S&D. It is very, very worrying. Apart from general phrases and phrases, we have not heard anything from you in the discussion, but also really nothing at all, and that is shameful for such a large People's Party as the one to which the S&D belongs, ladies and gentlemen. I call on the Social Democrats: at last and unequivocally distance yourself from their party friend Muscat!

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a journalist was murdered, Daphne Caruana Galizia. We must first say, and I believe that we should say unanimously here our support to her loved ones, to her family, to all those who mourn her today. She died for telling the truth. We are all concerned, the European Union is not an international organisation like any other. We have in common a heritage, principles, an attachment to freedom of conscience and the search for truth. And when we talk about the rule of law, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this debate, we do not have the right to selective indignation, we do not have the right to 'double standards'. Sir, ladies and gentlemen, how dare you give more lessons when you have not been able to say what is essential: the Maltese Prime Minister must resign now. Because in this time interval, it can destroy evidence, it can slow down an investigation, as we know today. We must all be concerned about what is being played out here, the future of freedom, the future of press freedom. The Commission and the Council have a role to play in ensure that the rule of law is effectively guaranteed. Each of our colleagues should be able to speak clearly on a subject like this and I would like to ask our colleagues in the Renew Group as well. Among the future French MPs to be elected here after Brexit is a man who worked for Mr Muscat and had to resign from his post in France with the French Prime Minister. Can Mr Sandro Gozi really embody today the ideal of a rebirth of Europe? For my part, in the context we know, I am almost sure the opposite.

name: Λουκάς Φούρλας (PPE).
text: Madam President, as a combat journalist for 23 years, I am frightened and shudder at the idea that a colleague was murdered for doing her job. I am even more frightened because there are suspicions that high-ranking state officials are involved in this murder, and indeed at the highest level. I would like to state, with all the strength of my soul, that I support the efforts of maltese friends to shine the truth and to vindicate the unjust loss of my colleague Daphne Galizia. Corruption must be combated and the guilty must resign immediately and pay, no matter how high they may be. We stand next to those who fight against corruption, for the truth to shine. Today we're all Maltese.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, corruption, obfuscation, interference, lack of transparency, intimidation. All these things seem to have been in play at the highest level in Malta regarding the murder of the investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, but I want to draw attention to the unacceptable behaviour of the management of the state-appointed Valletta 2018 European Capital of Culture, who not only regularly dismantled the public memorialisation of Daphne, but also censored artists invited to the festival. This included a British theatre company who were offered an open-ended residency in the programme and invited to make work responding to their experiences. When it seemed their performance would include references to Daphne, they were asked to change their script.  Artistic censorship is totally unacceptable in our European Union and questions must be asked of the Commission officials regarding monitoring of the use of citizens’ money in a culture of state repression. I’d like to take this opportunity to thank PEN International for their work on this issue. Also the theatre artists Rebecca Biscuit and Louise Mothersole, who are now telling the story of how they were censored by the Maltese authorities, winning an Edinburgh Fringe Festival award in the process.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the murder of journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia: How long did it take to actually find the killer before the culprit was found? And that has not yet been proven. I would point out a parallel with Slovakia. In Slovakia, too, a journalist had to die in order for people to defy corruption at the highest levels. Do you think that if Prime Minister Fico and the Minister of the Interior had not left, the real background to the murder would have been revealed in Slovakia today? Wasn't! That is why it is clear that the people of Malta, therefore, it is clear that we, too, are calling for the resignation of the Maltese Prime Minister here in the European Parliament. If you want this murder to be solved with all the consequences and with all the backgrounds, so that the truth comes out, the judiciary, the police and the press cannot be controlled by the government that is connected to this murder. That is why we demand the resignation of the Prime Minister.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I really think that we can all agree that it is very bad news for democracy, if a journalist is murdered, it does not matter where. I think that all our States of the European Union are united, that we have problems to some extent, some more, some less with corruption. Sometimes we also have problems with speech, free speech of the media and so on. However, it must be said here that we must be helpful as European institutions so that the investigation can really continue objectively, impartially and independently of any political pressure. We hear calls for the resignation of the Maltese Prime Minister. As has been said, the Slovak Prime Minister has resigned in Slovakia and I do not think that this was the most important thing in this process. The most important thing is really to ensure that the investigation and that all the law enforcement agencies can act freely, independently of political power. And most importantly in Slovakia, this has already borne fruit in the direction that several people have already been charged, even those who ordered this murder of a journalist in Slovakia, Ján Kuciak. It must indeed be said that we, as institutions, must be impartial and strive not to influence the political struggle and abuse of such a subject for internal political struggles, and in this case, for example, to time the missions and the LIBE Committee at a time when this is not a political fight just before the elections.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, people's lives, whether they are journalists or any other profession, must be safe in the European Union. I don't think there's a colleague in the hemicicle who doesn't condemn the journalist's murder. I was there, in Malta, in a delegation and I could see the tragedy and grave of this journalist.  But let's think, Commissioner, are we doing the right thing here? I politicized a man's life around Christmas. I think we need to find measures, get to the cause. If it weren't for those situations that the journalist was investigating, would she have ended up being killed? We have new specific measures for all Member States to eliminate money laundering, corruption, so as not to put journalists in a critical situation - because in all the states there are journalists who are definitely threatened, some even killed, as we have had here and other cases in Slovakia?  I believe, colleagues and esteemed Commissioner, that we cannot interfere in the things that national parliaments must decide. Governments don't change their European Parliament, they change their national parliaments. We make no mistake in getting involved in this, but we are asking the Commission, I call on the Commission to find mechanisms at European Union level, mechanisms to avoid putting journalists in a situation similar to Daphne's. I regret and offer my sincere condolences to the family.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want first of all to thank you all for this debate and also for your support for an independent investigation after the murder of the journalist, Daphne Caruana Galizia. Justice needs to be done. The new Commission is very clear on such a need. In the two first weeks in office, the President of the Commission has sent a clear message to the Maltese authorities. We did the same in different phone calls from Vice—President Věra Jourová and myself to the Minister of Justice, Owen Bonnici, and I have sent a letter to the Minister of Justice yesterday. More than that, Europol is at the disposal of the Maltese authorities to take part in the investigations and we have seen some progress in the investigation due to the presence also of Europol and we will continue to follow the progress in the investigations. We need to do that, not only for Daphne Caruana Galizia, for her family, but to defend our values in the European Union. I want to say that the protection of journalists, because I have heard many questions about that, is first of all, of course, a competence of the Member States. But the Commission must also take some initiatives to support the media pluralism and to support also independent journalists that work in all the Member States. And we will continue to do that and maybe will enhance our capacities to do that. Then we need to control a correct implementation of justice reforms after the Country—Specific Recommendations adopted by the Council of 9 July 2019. In my letter, I have insisted on the independence of judiciary with safeguards for judicial appointments and dismissals with a real separate prosecutor’s office. The Commission will present an evaluation on the process reform and propose concrete actions. The Commission has a toolbox to address rule of law concerns and we are ready to make use of it. I recall that the Commission introduced infringement proceedings against Malta for non—transposition of the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive, with success. As the situation evolves we will consider which instruments are appropriate, including a possible application of the rule of law framework if it’s needed. And, of course, about all those reforms we encourage the Maltese authorities to consult the Venice Commission on all draft legislation. Third, about the Investor Citizenship Scheme, in the Supranational Risk Assessment, published in July 2019, the Commission highlighted that citizenship investment programmes and investor residence schemes – also known as golden passport and golden visas – entailed significant money laundering threats. The January 2019 Commission Report on Investor Citizenship and Residence Schemes in the European Union highlights that these schemes inherently raise money laundering concerns. Awarding citizenship is a prerogative of the Member States, however, Member States must when exerting their powers in the sphere of nationality, have due regard to European Union law. European Union citizenship brings together rights to all Member States providing solidarity. Together, Member States create the conditions for enjoying EU citizenship. This common achievement should not be exploited by individual Member States’ risky investor schemes. We evaluate if a legislation is needed to find against the abuse of golden passport and if we must introduce infringement proceedings.  To conclude, we need to enhance the culture of the rule of law in all the Member States in the European Union and if we want to speak about the rule of law outside the European Union, it’s necessary to deliver, to do the job at home. It’s the reason why the Commission will organise and will set up a new mechanism with an annual report on the rule of law in all the Member States without any discrimination. It will be the occasion of a real political debate in the Council and also in the Parliament. We have such a process about the budgetary situation of all the Member States. It’s time to have the same political debate about our values, about the values of the European Union. That doesn’t mean the abandon of all the other tools at our disposal. We will continue to introduce infringement proceedings, to organise dialogue on the rule of law, to push through the Article 7 procedures. And so, of course, it’s an important moment today in this debate because we follow very closely the investigations about the murder of a journalist, but I want also to thank you for your support, because we have a lot of things to do together to protect the rule of law, to defend our values.

name: President. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 December 2019. Can I just say that as we conclude our debate on the murder of the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, let us salute the courage of her family, even though their hearts are broken. (The sitting was suspended at 11.35)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we take a position. We must proceed with the election of the European Ombudsman. The procedure is a little complex, so I would ask for a moment's concentration.  The election will take place pursuant to Rule 231 of our Rules of Procedure.  I have received the following nominations: Mr Giuseppe FORTUNATO Mrs Julia LAFFRANQUE Mrs Nils MUIŽNIEKS Mrs Emily O'REILLY Mrs Cecilia WIKSTRÖM I would remind you that the vote shall be taken by secret ballot and that, in accordance with Rule 231(6) of the Rules of Procedure, the candidate must obtain a majority of the votes cast in order to be elected.  Abstentions shall not be considered as votes cast.  Since this is a secret ballot on your terminal, a blue light will be lit, regardless of how you voted.  Since, in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, before declaring the vote open, I must ensure that at least half of the Component Members of Parliament are present, we will proceed to a vote to check for at least 374 Members.  Then I'd do this attendance check right now.  (The President made sure that at least half of parliament's component Members were present) And so we have the presence, the number is enough.  A moment's more attention. Information on electronic voting has been distributed.  Firstly, after the opening of the vote, the following information appears on the screen: the subject of the vote and the list of candidates.  Place yourself on the name of the candidate of your choice by activating the blue keys at the bottom right of the screen and express your preference by pressing the "+" button (left button). The blue light will turn on and an asterisk will appear in front of the name of the selected candidate. To ensure the secret nature of the vote, the asterisk will disappear as soon as you move the cursor.  If you wish to express your presence during the vote without voting for a candidate, press the "0" button (center button). Before the vote closes, you have the option to change the choice made by repositioning yourself on the candidate's name and pressing the "0" button to cancel the yes vote. Then place yourself on another candidate's name and press the "+" button. Is everything clear? We shall then proceed to the first round of voting. The vote is open. Did everyone vote? The vote is closed.  (The results appeared on the President's screen.) I announce the result of the vote: Number of voters: 692 Abstentions: 103 Votes cast: 589 Absolute majority: 295 They obtained (The results appear on the President's screen) – Mrs Emily O'REILLY: 240 votes – Mrs Julia LAFFRANQUE: 162 votes – Mrs Cecilia WIKSTRÖM: 73 votes – Mr. Giuseppe FORTUNATO: 67 votes – Mr. Nils MUIŽNIEKS: 47 votes And therefore, since no candidate obtained a majority of the votes cast , a second round must be made.  The second round will take place tomorrow at 12.30 p.m.  The deadline for withdrawing applications, if applications are withdrawn, is set at 8.00 p.m. this evening.  * * * *

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to make a point of order. Yesterday, our colleague Angel Dzhambazki, from the ECR group, made statements on the mobility package, which, politically, can be explained, in which he characterized two of our colleagues, Karima Delli and Ismail Ertug, as French and German MPs of Turkish origin respectively. I think that this kind of characterisation is intolerable here: we are all Members of the European Parliament, we are all from different backgrounds, and therefore there is no question, there is no question of stigmatizing colleagues for their origin! We are all MEPs. I thank you and therefore I would like you to call Mr Dzhambazki to order. (Great applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the same sense as Mr Lamberts, this is the home of all Europeans and Europeans. And here are certain rules, which we cannot accept to be skipped. The views issued by a MEP of this Parliament on this matter by two colleagues , colleague and colleague - of this Parliament, Karima Delli and Ismail Ertug, is totally unacceptable. This Parliament is the home of all, and we cannot allow racist claims in this European Parliament. They're totally unacceptable. And I ask the President of Parliament to take the necessary measures to prevent this from happening again.

name: Presidente. –
text: It will be my responsibility to follow up your requests.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as always, I find myself asking why this decision has to be made at EU level. I’m not in any sense unsympathetic to the plight of Jordan. It has, on the one side, the continuing calamity of the Syrian war and, on the other, a disruption of its oil and gas supplies from Egypt. I wish that country well. I think that King Abdullah is a benign force in regional politics. But surely this is the sort of decision that could be made by elected national governments, each answerable to their own taxpayers. The difference between those governments and us in this Chamber is that there is no proper link here between taxation, representation and expenditure. We are spending money that we are not responsible for and, fundamentally, that weakens governmental accountability and the democratic process. We should be pushing power outwards and downwards to restore honour and purpose and meaning to the act of casting a vote.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this motion for a resolution for several reasons. I would like to follow up on my colleague Hannan, because we have been officially asked, as the European Union, to provide this additional set of assistance. I think that we are indeed obliged to help Jordan. It is our long-term partner and what it is experiencing in the context of the conflict in Syria, the number of refugees it hosts on its territory, it is 1.3 million people, it is essentially adhering to the pact with the European Union that we made last term. Five hundred million euros is a large amount, but I think this country really deserves it. I voted for it. Europe-wide action is important. I do not agree with my colleague Hannan, who spoke a moment ago precisely because only the Member States should do so. It is good that we have decided this as the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to give my full support to this approval of macro-financial assistance from the EU to Jordan in the form of loans in three instalments. Jordan has been a country heavily affected by unrest in its region in recent years. The Syrian conflict in particular and the movement of a large number of people across the border into Jordan has a significant financial impact on the country and its ability to provide the needed services and public infrastructure for its citizens. Jordan is an important ally of the EU in the Middle East region and a country that works to protect fundamental rights and freedoms. The EU’s previous macro-financial aid programmes to Jordan have aided the authorities in putting important structures for the protection of human rights in place. It is therefore vitally important that we continue to support the country to ensure its stability and, indeed, to maintain its continued democratisation process, and I welcome this important approval to this end today.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I also supported this macroeconomic financial support for Jordan. I think there are very clear reasons why the European Union should be interested in the stability of this country. It is a stable partner of the European Union in the Middle East, it is a country that is really plagued by a huge influx of refugees. It is in our geopolitical interest that this country continues to be stable, that Islamist tendencies are not strengthened there and that it continues to be our partner. This means that the financial loan that we are making is not just some handing out of European taxpayers' money, as one of my colleagues has indicated here, but there is a clear interest in Europe and the European Union having a stable, essentially democratic Jordan as a partner, one of the few countries on which we can rely unequivocally in the Middle East. So the support is in place here, and it has its geopolitical reasons.

name: Mikuláš Peksa (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to speak on behalf of the Pirate Delegation. First, it needs to be mentioned that we consider VAT fraud an important topic that needs to be addressed. In this regard, we are grateful that it is being worked on. However, we can’t support the way the issue is being handled. The whole concept of retaining huge amounts of data without any clear selection of what is really needed and what is thought unnecessary is problematic. At this moment, just 25 cross—border payments quarterly, including offline payments by credit card, are enough to store payees’ data, including credit card numbers, for up to five years. This will create huge amounts of data that will flow with little restriction through databases, seriously lowering privacy and incurring infrastructure costs for such databases, meaning that this whole solution is completely unproportionate to real VAT fraud checks. Yes, we need to use modern technologies to help fight tax fraud. However, in this case we are using a needlessly massive tool that is well capable of causing much more harm than good.

name: Mikuláš Peksa (Verts/ALE).
text: - I'm just going to repeat what I said in English about the previous report, because they're deeply related. I consider the fight against VAT evasion to be very important, like most other Pirates. At the same time, however, we think that the proposed solution is completely inadequate to the problem we are facing. With this solution, we would save all payments made by a payer who pays more than twenty-five payments within three months, which we consider to be a completely inadequate invasion of privacy. At the same time, such withered data will flow with very little restriction throughout Europe, there is a risk of leaking this very sensitive data, which is very telling about our citizens. With this in mind, we have decided to abstemed and we consider this appropriate given the complicated nature of the issue we have discussed here.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this proposal because administrative cooperation in the fight against tax fraud is really needed and necessary. Of course, the devil is in great detail, but the fact that e-commerce and available online services are gaining momentum is clear. Consumers take advantage of this possibility, so they can also buy very famous brands. To a certain extent, this limits the retail network, but I would like to stress that, at the same time, there is also an opportunity for fraudsters in the area of VAT.  It is estimated that almost one hundred and forty billion euros are lost annually by the European Union and its Member States, which is a huge amount, precisely in the area of VAT fraud. I think this requires European action, and I supported this proposal because it is going in the right direction. A number of amendments have been tabled and I am therefore satisfied with this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – In Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacú leis an tuarascáil seo. Agus, sa lá atá inniu ann, tá níos mó agus mó comhlachtaí ag obair ar líne. Tá níos mó saoránach ag díol agus ag ceannach ar líne. Mar a dúirt Coimisinéir Vestager ina héisteacht, tá dhá shaghas comhlachta ann anois; comhlachtaí atá ag obair ar lgue comhlachtaí a bheidh ag obair ar líne go luath.  Ach an bhfuil siad ag íoc a gcuid cánach? Níl a lán díobh. Cailltear €137 billiúin gach uile bhliain. Sin ailp uafásach mór airgid. Agus cé a íocann é sin? Saoránaigh mhacánta na. I know without ceart. Agus caithfear deireadh a chur leis. Agus má éiríonn le Coimisinéir Vestager chun a chinntiú go n-íocfaidh na comhlachtaí seo a gcuid cánach agus deireadh a chur le calaois VAT, beidh gaisce déanta ar son shaoránaigh na hEorpa agus beimid go léir faoi chomaoin aici.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on conflicts of interest and corruption that have a negative impact on the protection of the EU's financial interests in the Member States, by Monika Hohlmeier on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control (O-000041/2019 – B9-0061/2019) (2019/2963(RSP)). I would like to remind you that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous speeches and the use of the blue card, both in the usual way and through the electronic system.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Verfasserin. – Frau Präsidentin, Herr Kommissar, liebe Kolleginnen und Kollegen! Zunächst einmal ein herzliches Grüßgott. Madam President, the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has posed five questions to the Commission regarding measures against the misuse of EU funds in cases of conflict of interest and corruption affecting the protection of the EU’s financial interests in Member States.  Let me start by providing some context to the questions that we have posed to the Commission. In certain Member States, the systemic risk of semi—legal systems enabling conflicts of interest, irregularities, misuse of funds and fraud is widely present in important policy areas such as agriculture and cohesion. We have cases where politicians allegedly systematically use their power and the influence they have over the implementation of EU programmes in their countries to enrich their companies, friends, family, or themselves. Conflict of interest constitutes in itself a serious threat. We see cases of single bidding in public procurement companies building up monopolies because other companies are thrown out of the competition. We are now facing problems that are beyond project level, so we need to go above this level to tackle them. We need to establish a clear definition of what constitutes a systemic risk and conflict of interest. We need the same legal definition and uniform interpretation of conflict of interest and systemic risk at European and Member State level. These cases threaten to undermine citizens’ trust in the EU institutions and have a negative impact on the implementation of policies. Therefore, our credibility is at stake. European funds must benefit European citizens at large. Audit procedures concerning conflict of interest and other cases of corruption, fraud or systemic failures must be accelerated so that punishment follows swiftly. Additionally, preventive measures must be reinforced. Currently, there is a lack of preventive measures that are effective and in place. If national management and control systems fail, the Commission must receive the possibility to assume decision—making and impose corrections immediately. The CONT Committee has actively monitored the situation since its fact-finding delegation of April 2014 and has been expressing its serious concern about cases of conflict of interest. CONT repeatedly requested in its discharge resolutions and other oral questions, most recently in December 2018, that the Commission take action regarding cases containing risk of irregular use of EU funds in several Member States.  We welcome the fact that the Commission has carried out comprehensive audits regarding the application of EU law. We are alarmed that the auditors detected serious deficiencies in the functioning of the management and control systems and severe cases of conflict of interest. The audits carried out by the Commission confirmed Parliament’s position, laid out in its resolution on conflicts of interest and the protection of the EU budget in the Czech Republic in 2018. They welcome the fact that, since 2018, no payments from the EU budget and the European Structural and Investment Funds have been made to companies directly or indirectly owned by Prime Minister Babiš, following the alleged conflict of interest revealed by the Commission’s auditors. They found that Mr Babis is the beneficiary of funds received by the huge industrial conglomerate. Yes, I would like to underline that there are still open questions about subsidies in the area of agriculture. Furthermore, we cannot accept the fact that projects affected by serious, sometimes fraudulent, irregularities are simply withdrawn from EU funding. Yes, the EU budget is no longer directly affected, but the core problem has not been solved.  The local taxpayer has to foot the bill when contributing to the national budget. EU funds meant to help citizens should go where they are most needed and not into the pockets of oligarchs. CAP money belongs to those who farm the land. In the case of land grabs, when land is taken by force, there is clearly a rule of law issue.  Therefore, we attach great importance to the rule of law conditionality. Rule of law is the basis for shared management. All Member States signed the Copenhagen Criteria, and they must be dedicated to the rule of law. Threats to the independence of the judiciary system, arbitrary or unlawful decisions by public authorities, limited availability and effectiveness of legal remedies, and failure to implement judgment or limitations on effective investigation and prosecution should lead to the reduction or suspension of EU funding.  We call on the Commission to take all appropriate measures at its disposal to protect the EU budget, including the revision of current procedures to increase transparency and to be more effective. We urge the Commission to recover all funds that have been paid out illegally. We insist that the Commission should propose a specific mechanism to support farmers confronted with land—grabbing malpractices, giving them the opportunity to lodge a complaint with the Commission. In the context of the negotiation on the next Multiannual Financial Framework, we call on the Council to take all necessary and appropriate measures to prevent conflict of interest effectively. We call on the Commission and the Member States to fight all forms of conflict of interest and to evaluate the preventive measures taken by the Member States to avoid such a situation. We need to clearly define the minimum standards of the rule of law. Please let’s start to work on these serious issues.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: As a spokeswoman for the committee responsible, I have not interrupted this, even if it has been too long. May I just ask the interpreters to not make up for the lack of speaking time by speed. That is no longer the case for colleagues. I would like to extend a very warm welcome to Commissioner Johannes Hahn in his new role.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first, before I reply to the questions raised, let me underline and stress again that the Commission has zero tolerance for fraud and misuse of EU funds. Now about the questions, and maybe I will be a little bit longer, but in order to give a serious reply, I have to take the time. The first question was about misuse of EU funds in Member States involving established schemes, as well as high-level officials/office-holders. In the case of fraud and possible links to high-level officials/office-holders, financial corrections at European level and penal action at national level have been taken in order to protect the European Union budget and to ensure the rule of law. The Commission on National Audits also identified irregularities with some more systemic character in some Member States. However, such systemic irregularities don’t systematically indicate fraud and intentional misuse through the implication of high-level officials/office-holders. Second question: what measures does the Commission take to protect the EU’s financial interest? The Commission takes any allegation of suspicion of fraud and misuse of funds very seriously. It immediately addresses, to the European Anti-Fraud Office, any information pointing to allegations of fraud emerging from citizens, whistle-blowers, or from audits. A series of recent Commission initiatives have significantly strengthened the anti-fraud landscape – for example the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. The Commission adopted a new Commission anti-fraud strategy in April 2019. In 2018, financial regulation established a definition of conflict of interest applicable to funds under shared management. A further step is the proposal for protection of the Union’s budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in Member States. The Commission is also attentively following allegations of land—grabbing. If land is taken by force, then there is a rule—of—law issue, and the judicial system of the Member State should act. The Commission can assist the Member State, if necessary, by supporting Land Registry reforms. The rule—of—law proposal referred to above would provide an additional tool once adopted. Let me now come to transparency as regards the ultimate beneficiaries of EU funds. I limit my remarks to the funds of the common agricultural policy. EU rules impose that it’s the Member States who have to publish the beneficiaries of the CAP funds annually and ex—post. The responsible Commission services consider that the current publication by all Member States of the data on beneficiaries of the CAP fulfils the transparency requirements. The Commission closely monitors the implementation of relevant transparency requirements in all Member States. What is being done to prevent the artificial break-up of pig farms or enterprises into smaller ones under the same ownership just to avoid the capping threshold for direct payments? Answer: EU rules contain a circumvention clause. It requires that Member States don’t grant any advantage to natural or legal persons in cases where the conditions for obtaining this advantage were created artificially. This would be contrary to the objectives of the legislation. The management and control systems in the Member States are audited by independent certification bodies on an annual basis and by the Commission auditors on a risk basis. The auditors verify if the Member States have put in place controls to detect artificially—created conditions. What about Commission actions on cases that have been recently reported in the media? How to prevent a similar case in the future? In relation to the Czech Republic, the Commission has communicated its final audit results for the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund to the Member State. For the rural development investment measures, the Commission has communicated its latest findings to the Member State. A further question: what are the Commission plans on the basis of Article 61 of the Financial Regulation (2018/1046) on possible situations of conflicts of interest in the Member States? The Commission will follow up on information or complaints with respect to conflicts of interest in all Member States. Audits can also be carried out based on the Commission’s own risk assessment, as foreseen in the audit strategies of the concerned services. The Commission will continue to strengthen monitoring, as the rules applying to shared management have been clarified and strengthened by the new financial regulations. The Commission supports Member States in applying conflict-of-interest rules by preparing guidance, organising exchanges of good practice, and monitoring the national rules on conflicts of interest and their consistency with Article 61 of the Financial Regulation.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, let me start with one such question. Can you imagine Angela Merkel or Sebastian Kurz deciding on the future budget of the European Union and owning hundreds of companies with benefits and subsidies from the European Union budget? If not, I think we're right in this debate. It must be said that the person who distributes European subsidies cannot be a large beneficiary at the same time. This is, in fact, the main issue that is on the table here, it must be said that one who benefits from European funds cannot manage these European funds. I have been on several missions and this debate should be globally not only about the Czech Republic, but also about Slovakia, Romania, Bulgaria or Malta, where politics is really closely linked to corruption or even European subsidies. These European subsidies themselves bring huge opportunities, but they are also becoming the subject of different groups wanting to draw as much money as possible from them. My question is: how long will we continue to understand and support these groups and these organised individuals in the European Union? When are we going to stop them from receiving money?

name: Isabel García Muñoz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Commission has remained passive for too long, despite strong evidence of significant cases of conflict of interest in the implementation of the European budget. Parliament has been warning and addressing this problem regularly since 2014 without an effective solution to it.  Article 61(1) of the new Financial Regulation, in force since August 2018, provides that all participants in the implementation of the Union budget, including heads of government, are responsible for complying with the obligation to avoid conflicts of interest. This article also gives greater capacity for action to the Commission, which it has actually exercised, but which is not being sufficient. So it's time to act once and for all. It is clear that we must go all the way to the end of the cases we now have on the table, but one of the Commission's fundamental priorities must be to establish effective mechanisms to enable the active prevention of conflict of interest and, moreover, it is imperative that it be intervened when national authorities are not acting accordingly.  We cannot afford that any kind of conflict of interest could jeopardize the implementation of the European Union's budget and underscore the confidence of its citizens. We need a more ambitious strategy that gives all the guarantees of the correct use of the Union budget.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: for renew. – Madam President, I would like to start by saying just one thing, please, let us respect the rules and procedures and wait with all the courts when the ongoing checks are over. I believe that the Commission is aware and this debate proves that the European Parliament is also aware of this, how important and sensitive the protection of the financial interests of our citizens is. It is not only a question of how efficiently and effectively eu funds can be used, but also of Europe not losing its sense of purpose in the eyes of its citizens and losing credibility.  The issue of a potential conflict of interest in politics is something that affects all Member States in no way. We'll deal with it all the time. That is why we need to learn from the experience we have accumulated so far and to make clear rules. And when else should we start this than now? That is, at the moment when the rules for drawing European money for years to come are set. If we have discovered flaws in the system, now is the best time to do something about it. For this reason too, we are very much awaiting the results of the questionnaire survey on how individual Member States are how they are going with the new Financial Regulation. It has proved that its interpretation is not uniform in the European Union. In modern Europe, however, this cannot work. On the contrary, we need a comprehensible and concrete Europe-wide solution with a uniform methodology and interpretation. I would therefore like us to put off politicking for once and take a very serious look at how to better set the rules for the future. Rules that are simple, fair and have European added value and apply equally to everyone. Whether citizens, businesses, politicians, Member States or institutions. I take the situation extremely seriously and believe that this debate goes beyond any particular case. I still believe that the European Union is and will remain a union of equal states that are always committed to finding a solution together.

name: Viola Von Cramon-Taubadel
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Our EU budget finances oligarchs. We fund the people who abuse our system. Thanks to the excellent work of the media, science and NGOs, some of the names of the oligarchs who are particularly systematically plundering THE EU pots have become known. The most well-known of these is the representative of the Czech Republic in the European Council, Prime Minister Andrej Babic. But he is certainly not the only one. Under public pressure, the Commission has investigated a number of individual cases. However, in order to remain credible to EU citizens, it is essential that we increase the speed of our investigations: suspending payments alone is not enough. If projects have been certified by the Commission as ineligible, there must be consequences. There is an urgent need for transparency. Nevertheless, this issue is about more than individual misconduct: we need to change the incentive structures so that we do not continue to feed oligarchs, but strengthen democrats. The oligarchy is poison for democracy, especially in the structurally weak areas. If the powerful can undermine our democracy through political and economic access to EU funds and even evade the persecution of the rule of law, as seems to be the case in the Czech Republic, then the work of the European Public Prosecutor's Office should begin here. This newly created European Public Prosecutor's Office – and you too, Commissioner Hahn, have a responsibility – is absolutely essential for an adequate budget. We must significantly increase the budget estimates for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and at least double the number of prosecutors assigned in order to deal with the cases that arrive from the Member States. There is a great deal at stake here! Therefore, good money in the right places instead of continuing to send millions to corrupt oligarchs.

name: Joachim Kuhs
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Today's debate on 'conflicts of interest and corruption that have a negative impact on the EU's financial interests in the Member States' clearly shows that we have a fundamental problem with the EU construct. First of all, we are persuading the Member States with angelic tongues to provide us with over EUR 1 trillion for seven years in the expectation that we will distribute the money fairly – let us say cautiously – a large part of the money.  We are inventing wonderful programmes, feeding flowery funds with a lot of money and putting multiple incentives in place so that the Member States can then join in and implement the programmes. Hosts of officials take care of the applications, check the eligibility conditions and draw up any certificates and certificates, which are then checked again by other officials. We in Parliament – more specifically, the Committee on Budgetary Control – are seriously concerned when we see that the risk of illegal use of EU funds in important policy areas such as agriculture and cohesion is becoming apparent. Mrs Hohlmeier, you are right to point out that such cases jeopardise citizens' confidence in the EU institutions and have a negative impact on the implementation of policies. You also put good questions to the Commission. But, after all that I have heard so far, I do not have the impression that the EU's financial interests are now better protected from fraud and corruption than before. Let us be honest: we are only fighting the symptoms and not the causes. Because the system is so complex and because the control systems in the Member States are completely different, and because the interests of the Member States are often contrary to the noble ideas of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I therefore fear that we will achieve nothing by increasing the control burden.  We should fight corruption and fraud first and foremost by asking the systemic question in each funding programme, minimising or even eliminating the flow of money if necessary, and, in particular, by radically simplifying the rules and the conditions of support and making them completely transparent.

name: Bert-Jan Ruissen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, monitoring the use of European funds is emphatically a joint responsibility of the Member States and the Commission. At the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, we have a good system for this with recognised paying agencies and supervision by the European Commission and OLAF. So it is not for me to comment on individual issues. The crucial question is how to ensure that the money ends up in the hard-working farmer and not in the pockets of people who don't need that money at all. In this context, I would like to point out that China and other investors are in the process of buying up land in the European Union. In Romania, for example, 20 000 hectares of land are apparently owned by a Lebanese company. My question to the Commission is therefore: are you aware of such investments, which are also made through legal entities in the European Union? I find this a very undesirable development. Our land and food supply are of strategic importance and must be kept in their own hands. I would ask the Commission to investigate this issue in depth and to see whether the requirements under the common agricultural policy should not be adapted to this, so that at least no money is leaked to investors from outside the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, The New York Times article on CAP was not news to many people here. That makes it all the worse. EU citizens’ money is going where it should not be. Much of this is by design and not by accident. Convergence and a significant redistribution payment is the key to change. It is now the position of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI)  that countries will have to converge 100% internally on payments by 2027. This position must be supported in the plenary and be Parliament’s position going into trilogue negotiations. Two words in particular are important when it comes to convergence in the final text agreed on at trilogue: ‘shall’ or ‘may’. ‘May’ allows governments to continue with the very system which is so rightly criticised in The New York Times article. ‘Shall’ means they have no choice but to do the right thing. Yesterday, Ireland’s Minister for Agriculture announced a pause on convergence. This is a clear message on where he will stand during trilogue negotiations. He will demand a change to Parliament’s position so that Ireland will not have to fully converge on payments – and the great swindle that The New York Times article reports on would continue if he succeeds. Don’t let him succeed. I certainly won’t.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Madam President, we are discussing here basically two funds which have served the purpose of enhancing European competitiveness in the agricultural sector and elsewhere – the CAP and the Cohesion Fund. In contrast to the grand ideals, both have become hotbeds of corruption within the European Union and instruments in the hands of oligarchs and illiberal regimes, with the tacit agreement of EU decision—makers. Now if we are looking at the Common Agricultural Policy, which makes up over 40% of the total budget, we can see that in contrast to the aim of enhancing the competitiveness of the European agricultural sector, this area has become a hotbed of corruption, and here my colleague has referred already to The New York Times article which has demonstrated that the CAP is intentionally untransparent, contains loopholes and is prone to corruption, and undermines even the EU’s environmental objectives, and every reform which is proposed is basically sabotaged by the decision—makers.  When it comes to the Cohesion Fund, when we are looking at why the EU doesn’t want to put forward reforms, then we should refer to the cynical opinion of the previous Commissioner for the Budget, Günther Oettinger, who says that EU funds should not be used to sanction, because every single euro which goes from the donor states to the recipients basically goes back to the donor states because the recipients use these monies to buy goods and services from the donor states. So we should finish with this cynical type of programme and look at how corruption must be tackled at the heart.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Allow me to contribute to the debate with three very short statements.
