On the one hand, the wise Hungarian saying is well known that many speeches have a lot at the bottom, if the EU institutions had done half as much to protect the Union's financial interests, to detect conflicts of interest, to fight corruption, than they speak, we would have gone much further. I support action. Secondly, I believe that it is only possible to speak credibly about conflicts of interest in the Member States in the EU institutions if the functioning of the EU institutions is not affected by conflicts of interest. The situation at the moment, ladies and gentlemen, is that the European Commission is being given a mandate of hundreds of thousands of euros by a Hungarian family business that is a husband member of a Hungarian family business in the Hungarian Parliament, and his lovely wife is a Socialist MEP and a Vice-President of the European Parliament. This is more than a conflict of interest, and the EU institutions must first sweep around their own houses. (The speaker agrees to answer two 'Blue Card' questions (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "I have a question (I don't know if I'm going to ask this question procedurally well) to everyone who has talked about the earth. Mark Twain said, "Buy land, they don't produce it anymore." I have, if possible, a question for the Commissioner: would you be in favour of reviewing the land turnover in each of the countries of our European Union? ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The blue card means that you are asking a question to the previous speaker, not to the Commission.  If you have no question, we will leave it at that if you have not German a question to your colleague.

name: Sándor Rónai (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I would like to ask colleague Deutsch whether conflicts of interest, such as those justified by the procedure under Article 7, the Elios case in which Viktor Orban's son-in-law is suspected of stealing 13 billion dollars, or the case in which Viktor Orbán's childhood friend, Butcher Lawrence, is now richer than the British Queen, is considered a billionaire of more than billions of euros, became a Forbes billionaire. Do you think it is incompatible, does it not bother you that the president of your party, the Hungarian Prime Minister, and his family are directly involved in corruption? Talk about this, Congressman, rather than Ferenc Gyurcsány or Klara Dobrev.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. – Thank you very much, Congressman, for your question, I have not mentioned a single name, but if that is what the Member is interested in, I would like to confirm the serious conflict of interest that you are referring to. The European Commission commissions hundreds of thousands of euros for a Hungarian family business whose owner, Ferenc Gyurcsány, is Hungary former Socialist Prime Minister, is now leader of an opposition faction, and the other is owned and represented by Klára Dobrev, a Member of the European Parliament and a Vice-President of the European Parliament. This is a serious political conflict of interest, we have to sweep our own house first, we clean up, and then we have credibility to hold national conflicts of interest to account.

name: Lara Wolters (S&D).
text: Mr President, it is an ironic image: populists such as Viktor Orbán and Andrej Babiš are shouting loudest about the EU's shortcomings. However, it is the same Orbán and Babiš who use European taxpayers' money to enrich their own entourage. This abuse must stop and I think there are two ways to do so. Firstly, we need a modern common agricultural policy. We should not stick to an archaic system of paying per hectare, but switching to benefits on the basis of efficiency. If we go from quantity to quality, it also becomes much more difficult to cheat. Secondly, we need a rule of law mechanism that penalises the shortcomings of national authorities and stops them. However, the creation of such a mechanism is currently being blocked by the Member States, which is a bad thing. National leaders would rather call for the EU to be expensive than to sit down to negotiate fundamental agricultural reforms and new sanctions regimes. We have to change that, so that we can save and protect our taxpayers' money.

name: Sheila Ritchie (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the New York Times article brings shame on us all. The sale of state land to the cronies of European leaders with patchy records on the rule of law is a stain on our reputation, and it amounts to theft from small farmers and rural communities. But the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) itself corrupts our aims. We’re in the middle of CAP reforms which reduce the need for compliance checking when we can’t even adequately police corruption. What on earth makes us think that self-policing compliance is going to work? 80% of the CAP budget currently ends up in the hands of 20% of the EU’s farmers. It doesn’t deliver what society wants. The current reform is mere tinkering. We must move to a system with payments linked to the delivery of public goods. The CAP is the lifeblood of European farming, and the huge and continuing reduction in agricultural spending is no accident. The CAP no longer commands credibility.

name: Mikuláš Peksa (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the first audit prepared and still not published by the European Commission confirmed Andrej Babiš's conflict of interest. His construction of trust funds, which are controlled by close persons and which can be cancelled by Babiš at any time in order to return the property to him, simply did not stand up. In the subsequent discussion on how much is to be refunded, any distinction between Agrofert and the Czech State was completely wiped out. Agrofert's former managers are now ministers and MPs, but their tasks have not changed. The Prime Minister's firm is a matter of national interest, which makes the Prime Minister willing to lead the country into conflict with the rest of Europe. We are looking here at a demonstration of the systemic problem of controlling the use of common European resources. When designing it, the authors probably could not imagine that someone would be able to control the state apparatus in such a way that they would control themselves through it. Nevertheless, we are in Hungary, Malta and the Czech Republic in exactly this situation.  Today's debate is not just about money wrongfully misused from the European budget. Today's debate is mainly about Andrej Babiš using the Czech state as a money-laundering fund in his own pocket and then financing his other political campaigns with this money. We must find a systemic solution, whether through the strengthening of the European public prosecutor or the reform of the common agricultural policy. The European Commission should declassify the remaining documents and put forward a proposal for measures to prevent Andrej Babiš from further abusing European money through the European Council.

name: Hélène Laporte (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, behind the protection of the financial interests of the European Union there is another subject, that of consent to European tax. Does the way the European budget is spent strengthen the confidence of our fellow citizens in the project defended in this Chamber? The answer is no, as evidenced by a Eurobarometer survey in which less than one in three French people say they have confidence in the European Union. Moreover, Mrs Hohlmeier makes this very clear by denouncing, and I quote, 'the numerous cases of irregularities which threaten to reduce citizens' confidence in the Union's institutions'. And for good reason, in its resolution of 26 March 2019, the European Parliament points in particular to the administrative complexity, which generates payment deadlines that are seriously damaging for the beneficiaries of European funds. How do you want a small business or a local authority to apply for European funding if late payments call into question the viability of their investment? The French, who are already subject to one of the heaviest taxes in Europe, do not want to be further burdened by the creation of a new European tax, especially if this tax funds expensive and flawed policies.

name: Veronika Vrecionová (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the discussion of this point is, of course, also related to what is happening in the Czech Republic, where the Prime Minister is also one of the largest recipients of public money. However, I do not want to deal with this particular case here, which we have to deal with at home. However, I would like to appeal to the Commission to be more transparent in its reports, to publish the conclusions of the investigation, as well as to publish the positions of individual Member States. We are in a situation where another multiannual financial framework is being negotiated, at the same time existing programmes are being drawn up, and many of the institutions that decide on the payment of subsidies do not know whether and to whom they can continue to grant subsidies. The Czech Government does not want to publish the audit conclusion because it is supposedly considered confidential by the European Commission and prohibits publication and does not provide it to the authorities that decide on subsidies. They continue to pay subsidies with taxpayers' money, in our case one influential oligarch. In the same case, I also lodged an appeal with the Commission.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, today's issue is conflicts of interest and corruption affecting the protection of the European Union's financial interests in the Member States. This is a very fundamental issue that needs to be addressed for the credibility of the European Union and the state of democracy in the Member States. We are talking about a phenomenon that is very old, but we have still not been able to solve it, even here, in the European Union. We can talk about a lot of ways out of this. However, I believe that, first of all, we must give citizens more space to participate in European Union policy. There have been enough secret negotiations, a democratic deficit, and enough of the so-called remounts that mean linking business and European institutions. The European Union must be open and transparent, and I would then expect the same level of transparency from the European Union in relation to potential misconduct on the part of the Member States and their representatives.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, today we are talking about corruption and conflicts of interest. I must say that the fight against corruption in Croatia is in principle, it is not real. As far as conflicts of interest are concerned, we have a so-called property card with a body called the Conflict of Interest Adjudication Commission and in that asset card, when you become an official, you enter your obligations and your assets. And now, that asset card is almost useless in practice. It sounds this nice, it spins a lot in the media, but it's actually almost useless. Why? Here's an example. Let's say you have ten apartments and now you haven't entered three apartments in that card. It's a huge problem. But even if you enrolled in ten apartments, no one asks you where you got those ten apartments from. Could you have gained those ten apartments from your salary, from your income? Therefore, as far as the origin of the property is concerned, there is no P. In addition, the origin of the property is dealt with by the tax authorities, but not a single promil from what it really should, in quantity and quantity. As for common policies, we have a common agricultural policy, environmental policies, monetary in the form of the eurozone, etc. Now we're going for foreign policy, a common defense policy... As a rule, all these policies are not good for Croatia. They're questionable, bad. However, why is there no talk of a common anti-corruption policy? Who has anything in this home, from any country, against us taking the best standards in the protection of whistleblowers, in the origin of property, in conflicts of interest – Finland, Sweden, the best – to accept them all together. Who doesn't want thieves in his country? We haven't picked up our thieves in Croatia in 30 years. Who has anything against high anti-corruption standards for all? Only criminals. (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, then colleague Sinčić, I don't know if you see what the topic is, the topic is the use of European funds. In this regard, Croatia is indeed one of the countries with the most strict controls in the entire European Union. In fact, maybe these controls are even sometimes too strict and in some things put too much pressure on users. As for these other things and control, therefore Croatia has one of the strictest laws related to preventing conflicts of interest in Europe. Recently, a law was passed to protect whistleblowers, i.e. report irregularities. So why are you talking about things you have no idea about and deceiving this high home.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Chairman, Mr. Falcon, your whistleblower protection law is not useless, it is turbo useless. Take all those whistleblowers who have suffered health and property since the founding of the state to this day. Ask all of them in order what they think of this law. I asked and I know what they think of it law. As for today's topic and european funds...  (Chairpers interrupt the Member and inform him that there is no interpretation, the Representative asks that he be given back lost time after the translation problem has been resolved) The whistleblower protection law passed by your government is useless. Ask the whistleblowers. From the founding of the state to the present day, from Vesna Balenovic on the far, who suffered greatly, lost property and health, what do they think of this law. As for european funds, I have extended the topic to other money, not just the one from European funds. Ask yourself about the LNG terminal. Why does the European Union, which boasts so much about the rule of law, finance a project that violates the spatial plans of both the city and the county, the Aarhur Convention, the will of the local population of the city and the municipality. Where's the justice in that? Where are the European standards?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think we all agree that European funds must be distributed in accordance with the rules. Specifically, it is immoral for heads of government to profit from European subsidies for their companies. No one can agree to that. That is why we have an amendment to the Financial Regulation, according to which a conflict of interest must be ruled out, and the Commissioner mentioned it. I am very sorry that the reputation of the Czech Republic is also at stake, because European funds have helped the Czech Republic, helped municipalities, citizens, helped to build infrastructure, and now the reputation of the Czech Republic in connection with the conflict of interest of the Prime Minister is also at stake. We expect the Czech Government to respond impartially to the audit, which shows a conflict of interest, but Czech citizens are concerned about the influence of the media, the influence of the administration and the courts by the Prime Minister, because he has power. That is why people are repeatedly taking to the streets and demanding the resignation of the Prime Minister as part of the 'Million Moments for Democracy' initiative. These citizens know that the European Commission is doing its job. I call on the Commission to be consistent on this matter, and I also call on you to publish the audit, which you yourself have declared final. This will benefit greater transparency.

name: Sándor Rónai (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support An oligarchic world has been built in Central and Eastern Europe, and these oligarchs live happily ever after in the happiest part of Europe. The politicians who govern these countries are now synonymous with the most influential players in economic life. It is naïve to believe that there are only legal deficiencies in corrupt countries, and that these are unintentional measures that undermine the rule of law. We're talking about the planned, criminal operation of corrupt governments. There is no need to expect these governments to cooperate with the European authorities. Where corruption is legalised, we simply cannot expect them to help. In the meantime, European citizens will have to pay twice for the damage. Once, when they pay the taxes that are stolen by corrupt governments, and the second time when they have to pay the penalty for the stolen money. As a proud European and a proud Hungarian from Europe, I would make two proposals: for the stolen money, corrupt politicians should be responsible for their own wealth, and European subsidies should be given directly to farmers, municipalities, NGOs, that is, to those for whom we originally intended these funds.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the definition of conflict of interest in the Union Financial Regulation comes almost 20 years after the council of Europe's recommendations and is not brave enough. The regulation must be put into practice, and when we have such situations, we have to say things by name, regardless of group or country. We urgently need a European definition of the legitimate public interest so that information on cases is available without any exception. Romania has such a definition in law and it can be an example. It is inadmissible to wait, on average, five years for the resolution of a conflict of interest case that directly affects the pockets of the people and the financial interests of the Union. We have competence, we can do much more and faster.  The control mechanisms for the distribution of European funds must be strengthened, without fear that we will affect the affairs of some or others, and it is time to have an independent European integrity agency to manage conflict of interest situations in the Union institutions, including Parliament or the Council, in order to set an example in this regard and the Member States.

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, dear visitors, for being here. I am addressing you in particular, because it is about your money. And you can see the importance with which this Parliament treats your cause, your money: it is, as always, empty. Christmas is just around the corner, and every year we have the same debates. It is a recurring theme, the almost endemic corruption within the EU. All my colleagues here have said the right things before, but you can see the total powerlessness of this Parliament on this issue. When Mrs von der Leyen presents her green programme, the benches are full, and the Commission benches are also full. When it comes to an important issue such as the truly multi-billion-dollar corruption in Europe, there are some Commissioners and some Members, but otherwise the Chamber is rather empty. Everything that has been said here is correct. Yes, the two major wasteful or the two major hot-button corruption scounds are the Cohesion Fund and, of course, agriculture. We have known this for 15, 20, 25 years. And nothing is being done here for just as long, because in the end there is no interest whatsonight in curbing this corruption. After all, in many areas, the EU itself is a system that promotes precisely this corruption, because it is too far away from the people, because it is too far away from using funds, and because it refuses to return these funds to where they are right, namely in the national parliaments. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Mr Fest, do you know that in many budget areas 98% of the money is spent properly and used properly by the appropriate users? Do you know that 95% of the money is also being spent properly in the area of cohesion and agriculture? What we are turning against here today is that there are a few who are trying to exploit ON a large scale with EU funds. We are opposed to this in a very concrete way and we will take further and additional measures for this and have always improved a little bit so far – year after year.  So for blanket vilification, I ask you: would you just answer the question, would you even know?

name: Nicolaus Fest (ID)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Hohlmeier, I would like to thank Mrs Hohlmeier for her work Of course, you say it is only 2%, others say it is 7% or 5%. These percentages are also questionable. And we also know that even at 5 or 7%, it is about large, large sums of billions. They have been running behind for years. It is always said: yes, we are now making a Commission and another agency to monitor it. And you don't want to see the systemic problems, let me excuse them. That's your problem. These problems have been mentioned here, and you continue to close your eyes firmly, as you have been doing for years.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The EU has many ineffective support programmes that are effectively exploited by rogue entrepreneurs, criminals, oligarchs, even politicians. Now many people are pinning their hopes in this House into a supranational EU public prosecutor's office, but that is not the solution. This type of suggestion only suppresses the symptoms, instead of curing the disease. The basic problem is simply the oversized EU budget that fattens corruption and waste.  The proposal for the next long-term budget would increase the Swedish EU contribution by SEK 15 billion, while two thirds of the budget will continue to be spent on various support programmes. The redistribution accounts for almost 40% of all reported fraud cases and almost three-quarters of the total monetary amount. And instead of moving even more power to the EU, we can effectively combat corruption and the irregular use of EU aid by reducing both the budget and the swedish taxpayers' financial burden.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, throughout Europe we see that young farmers and family and family farms are taking the water to their lips. It is therefore very distressing to read in the New York Times that a large part of the European agricultural budget does not end up with them, but disappears into the pockets of large landowners, oligarchs and political leaders or a combination thereof. EU support is widely used in some Member States for land picking and facilitating a kind of modern feudalism. It is not only the rural community and the taxpayer who are affected; moreover, this practice is detrimental to the credibility and support of the eu as a whole. It is therefore a pity that the Commission is responding rather laxly to it and is only pointing to the Member States. That's not enough. Opinions from the EU Anti-Corruption Agency are ignored twice as often as they are followed. Monitoring member states' expenditure should be much more compelling and effective. For example, a European Public Prosecutor's Office can play an important role in this. First of all, however, what we need is a greater sense of urgency. That is my call to the European Commission: get to work!

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in recent weeks there has been a lot of talk about disconcerting situations with regard to land concentration in some Member States, but malpractice has nothing to do with the common agricultural policy. In recent years, we have made important efforts to reduce the distortions that can be created at national level in a complex policy that covers 28 countries and involves millions of beneficiaries. But much remains to be done, and that is why Parliament has already taken a clear position in our report on the concentration of the Union's agricultural land. This position is unfortunately not reflected in the current proposal to reform the CAP. On the contrary, excessive flexibility granted to Member States would increase the risk that certain behaviours could be further facilitated by national choices.  Today more than ever, Commissioner, we need a strong anchorage to common objectives and instruments, capable of preventing any openness to political individualism that would make the CAP a mere container of resources without safeguarding social, economic and environmental strategicity.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Madam President, the scandal that has shaken the Czech Republic has rekindled concern about the proper use of European funds. No less than 705 fraudulent irregularities were reported in the last annual report, amounting to EUR 390 million, and this is only the part of the cases that the States concerned have been willing to look into. According to the European Court of Auditors, the Commission does not make any estimates of undetected fraud. Less than half of the cases result in prosecutions and most of the money is not recovered, a polite way of pointing to the impotence of OLAF and the Commission. There are illegal frauds, which must be combated. But there is another type of diversion, which is not included in these statistics, but which could merit it. I am thinking, for example, of the recent use of the Feader fund for the settlement of migrants in the countryside, or of Turkey's delusional pre-accession aid. Such scandals also contribute to the diminishing confidence of suspicious peoples, and we understand them, in European policies and the use that is made of their money.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I wonder how the EU will ensure that EUROPEAN funds do not go to corruption. The Sweden Democrats and the ECR Group can never accept that EU funds are used in this way. When The Economist ranked eu countries by a democracy index, Romania was the very last. Since 2016, the Social Democratic government has been pushing through bills that effectively legalize corruption and give the government an increased opportunity to appoint and dismiss judges. The Party Chairman of the Social Democratic Party and the President of Romania, Liviu Dragnea, are personally suspected of embezzling hundreds of millions of kronor from the EU budget. He has also been identified as the leader of a crime syndicate by the country's special corruption prosecutor. In 2015, Dragnea was sentenced to one year in prison for electoral fraud and later, in 2018, he was sentenced in another corruption case to three and a half years in prison. It is uncertain whether he will serve any of those sentences. This is totally unacceptable and the EUROPEAN Union must make efforts here to control where the money goes.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that we must distinguish between two things here, at least as far as agriculture is concerned. As a few previous speakers have said, if we look at the real error rates and reports from our Court of Auditors, we have an error rate of one per thousand in the area of direct payments, that is to say a payment of thousands, and 1.4% in rural development. These are the bare numbers. But then there are a whole series of payments, which are also there and which we are discussing today. They are legal or, as Mrs Hohlmeier said, on the margins of legality and have to do with either paying to subjects who have nothing to do with agriculture, or paying things where it comes to pure returns on investment and increasingly also from investments from outside the European Union. This is where we, as legislators, are called upon, because in the end we have to decide to whom we want to pay money under agricultural policy. I believe that we should promote farming, we should pay for those who really populate rural areas, which make a positive contribution to the cultural landscape and to the protection of resources. I think that is what we must do now in the context of the debate on the reform of agricultural policy.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the citizens of our Union ask for transparency on the use of European funds, including cohesion policy, which plays a crucial role in creating sustainable growth and jobs, with the clear mission of not leaving any region of our Union behind. The Commission should take very seriously any kind of error detected in the use of the cohesion funds. For the financial year 2018, the European Court of Auditors showed that the level of error on cohesion increased. As the budgetary authority responsible for the discharge, it is our duty to understand the reasons behind this inversion. Even if an error does not automatically mean fraud, the credibility of cohesion policy should not be undermined by specific cases on which the Commission should promptly take action. Cohesion policy is one of the most successful tools of the European Union. It is for this reason that we should put all our efforts, and urge others to do the same, into significantly reducing the error rate so that we can deliver better results for our citizens. It is clear that the crucial challenges we will face in the future will require at least the same financial means the cohesion policy has had until today. If we want our regions to continue to grow, cohesion policy must be prioritised.

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we have a record here. Nine Czechs are speaking to one particular point today. Half the national members. Why? It's about the money, no less, no more. The Czechs are afraid of wearing a coat out of shame. On the one hand, the Czech government is headed by a prime minister and a businessman who draws and consumes. On the other hand, there is the European Commission, which logically accuses Prime Minister Babiš of a conflict of interest. The first argues czech laws, the second by European legislation. We need to clear this up very quickly. It'll be too late soon. A new budget is being negotiated next year. I normally say subsidies are like plague, the disease spreads fast. But we can't do the Green Revolution without money. I therefore ask the European Commission to resolve this particular conflict of interest problem quickly and transparently. I've already appealed to you, but we're still waiting for an answer.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, at European level, we have adopted a number of rules to manage taxpayers' money, including conflicts of interest. Persons in any public office must therefore choose what interests they wish to hold, whether their private property interests or those of their citizens. Compliance with these rules must be supervised by both the European Commission and we, the European Parliament, we are the co-creation of the European budget. Persons with conflicts of interest must be weaned from any influence, albeit indirect, on the administration and decision-making of European funds. That is why, by the way, the European Parliament has rejected several Commissioners-designate this year, precisely because of a conflict of interest. These rules must be respected at European and national level. I know that this debate affects several Member States, but I will focus on the Czech Republic. No one expected such a conflict of interest to affect directly the Prime Minister of a Member State or, therefore, a minister. I would like to call on Prime Minister Andrej Babiš to put an end to this European disgrace to our country. It is completely damaging to our country's reputation in Europe. I would also like to call on the European Commission to focus on the Czech system of allocation of European funds. In the Czech Republic, it seems that we have a systemic problem with compliance and officials measure by double standards.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is not the first time today that Members of this House have blamed each other for corruption or the tolerance of corruption or the obstruction of the fight against corruption. I do not believe that such behaviour particularly impresses our viewers in the gallery or on the Internet. I am in favour of us talking about systemic problems, and I believe that all those who have already spoken in this debate about the problems of the common agricultural policy are right. I believe that the area premium – and this is the essential instrument by which farms are supported today – is precisely a false means and invites abuse. From my time in budgetary control, I often think back to the funny discussions about how many trees on a mountain meadow one can probably no longer speak of a pasture, but rather of a forest. But that's just by the way. I believe that if farming is invited to promote public goods – such as contributing to clean water, such as protecting biodiversity or animal welfare – we would then make the misuse of CAP funds much more difficult and oligarchs spoiling business.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - A respected chair, conflict of interest and corruption in several Member States are a common practice when it comes to the use of European funds. In doing so, it must be clear to us that European financial instruments are not the only ones manipulated in order to unlawfully benefit, they are only an addition to national funds that, by the same principle, end up in the pockets of the eligible. Such discussions are usually reduced to the protection of the Union's financial interests. It is important to prevent European money from being stolen nationally. I think we are misguided in approaching this problem because it is not important to exterminate corruption only when it comes to European funds, but in general. We must be accountable to citizens and protect them from nepotism and corruption, whether national or European means. The EU needs to show that it cares about people, not just some of the money.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, I am pleased that we have this debate today because corruption and conflicts of interest are a major problem in the European Union today. The cost of corruption in the European economy is estimated to be around €120 billion a year. However, and I would agree with the previous speaker, the main problem is not European funds. When we look at the analyses, only 2% of the funds from the European budget, i.e. from cohesion policy, are problematic in this sense, and a large percentage of this is error. When we talk about some kind of corruption cases, and it's about European funds, we're really just talking about millions. A much bigger problem is at the national level. I see that some colleagues want the European Union to have even greater competences, as my predecessor used to say, and to enter even more into the space of national autonomy to control member states even more. But I don't think that's the way. I think that Member States themselves need to take care of solving their problems, not that the European Union imposes certain solutions, but it is also the fact that when we talk about the situation at European level, the problems are iapk less than at national level and therefore I think that this debate should not go in the direction of being used as an argument for reducing european funds. Stronger control yes, preventing corruption yes, but cohesion policy and funds are still essential for the development of Member States and we do not need to reduce them.

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, of course, if there is one thing to justify our work as members of this Parliament, it is that we must put an end to all kinds of corruption — without a doubt — and we must protect the interests of the citizens, of course. Who's going to question this issue? Now, don't expect me to be on the side of the one who intends to make a general judgment against the common agricultural policy. I disagree. There are elements of corruption that need to be tackled, in this or other policies, in this fund or in the other, but I refuse to ask a general questioning of the CAP; of course, don't count on me. The common agricultural policy has served to improve the income of our farmers; has supported our public goods; our food sovereignty and food security; and has led to the territorial cohesion of rural areas and also to avoid depopulation. I therefore refuse that general judgment; rather let's all go solve that corruption. And let's not put financial times in this sack, which is coincidentally from a country that is imposing tariffs on our agricultural products. Watch out for journalistic information.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the European Court of Auditors estimates that last year there was an irregular level of payments of 2.6%, increasing by 0.2% compared to last year, which means, taking into account the total level of expenditure, which is almost already EUR 5 billion in irregular payments, some one hundred euros per European citizen. You guys go tell your voters, I'll do it with mine.  The Court of Auditors finds, in fact, that, of those funds, the level of irregular payments essentially reaches 5% in the area of cohesion funds and rural development funds, but fundamentally imputs it to the complexity of the rules and eligibility criteria, so that the solution does not apply coercion mechanisms to States , but to deregulate, make the rules simpler, clearer the eligibility criteria and in the specific case of some countries, such as Spain, prevent that money from being distributed throughout the autonomous regions, as has happened in Andalusia under the socialist government.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Buxadé, what is the doubt or question you have regarding one of the regions, Andalusia, which has better and more managed public resources from cohesion funds and the common agricultural policy? What doubt do you have about it? Your political party interests? Or what is it?

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR)
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, very simply. We are not talking here about the common agricultural policy. We are talking about the fate and the correct fate of funds emerging from the European Union. And I do not want to extend myself, especially in the largest case of corruption that has been discovered in Spain, particularly in Andalusia, in the area of so-called employment regulation files, in which your Government and your party are involved. These are national issues, but we are obviously talking about European funds, also in this case, the European Social Fund for Employment.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think it is very good that we are talking here in plenary about the financial interests of the European Union, namely the money of all Europeans. This topic, as has already been said here, is currently linked to perhaps the biggest conflict of interest we have ever dealt with in the European Union, and unfortunately this is a conflict of interest of The Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babiš.  I am very glad, Commissioner, that in the end, after some hesitation, the Experts of the European Commission carried out an audit procedure and that you therefore ultimately made a decision. In my opinion, it is important that this decision is transparent, that it is credible and that people believe in the arguments that you make in it. Because Andrej Babiš controls the media, he has a huge media impact and, of course, presents the whole thing as evil Brussels officials attack the shrewd Andrej Babiš. It is therefore wrong that the final report is not public, even if it is final. Please publish this report, take steps towards greater transparency so that the citizens of the European Union know the official arguments and believe that Andrej Babiš is illegally drawing on European subsidies and thus drawing their money. Hundreds of thousands of people are manifesting in the Czech Republic and want to know clear answers from Europe.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Tudor Ciuhodaru is my name, Ciuhodaru. I am an emergency physician in Iasi, Romania, and an old medical dictum Ambroise Paré told him more than a hundred years ago that it is easier to prevent than to treat. I believe that this also applies to corruption.  Is that why, Honoured Commission, honoured Council, honoured colleagues, when will we have a national integrity agency? In Romania I have been working on that law in the Romanian Parliament and I tell you that it can be taken as an example of good practice in order to detect these potential cases, usefully, and prevent them. And I want zero tolerance for corruption, and I am telling you today that we are not talking about corruption of the left or the right, small or large, we are simply talking about corruption that takes our European money from infrastructure, from health and from education. Secondly, when will we ensure that access to European funds is simplified - if we are talking about European funds - so that the same rules are equal for all, the same for all? And speaking of common agricultural policies, when will farmers in Romania have that subsidy like those in France? Because you know that there are many questions and many grievances and many disappointments about the fact that the same European rules do not apply in all states. I also want you as a zero tolerance for corruption, and that is why I call on the Commission to establish this European integrity agency which may be the solution to the conflict of interest.

name: Radan Kanev (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the biggest problem with corruption and conflicts of interest is that they are compromising any and all other European policies and that they are endangering their tangible results. The problem is that corruption and conflicts of interest with European funds are deeply compromising the trust of people in the European institutions. Let’s take the biggest, most important example in today’s European politics: the Green Deal and Just Transition. We’ve lived through transitions in Eastern Europe, and we know that no transition is fair if there is no strong rule of law, no strong justice and no strong prosecution. So the answer for the whole of Europe should be strong European prosecutors, strong European rules and strong European institutions – or we will have no Green Deal and no Just Transition.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I am glad that, behold, the President of the CONT Committee has come here with a clarification question, and I am glad that, and in her reply to one of her colleagues, she has pointed out that, in fact, 95% to 96% of the funds are correct, because this is where all European citizens listen to us, and I would not want to believe that all European funds are being wasted and there is corruption with all European funds. But, Commissioner, I appreciate your honesty. You said that you need to research to answer some of the questions, from what our colleague reported today. I think there are solutions. Conflict of interest now, when we speak, is not defined equally in all Member States and imbalances arise.  Then we must prevent, as has been said before, and I think the things that have been pointed out here, namely: money, for example, for farmers. For years, and in my country, I have seen that uncultivated land is also given. They should be given to those who work the land and not to those who have accumulated and maintained the land and exploit others, after all.  Then you need to make an anti-fraud strategy. Of course we have an anti-fraud strategy, but you need to improve the mechanisms so that, from year to year, we can lesse fraud and corruption on European funds and responsibility is shared at Member State level as well.

name: Ondřej Knotek (Renew).
text: –  Madam President, I regret seeing that some colleagues are using this debate to generate national—oriented political attacks instead of having a serious and constructive discussion. For this I would advise them to go to their national parliament. However, let me contribute to the discussion in a factual manner, as the shadow rapporteur for the common provision regulation, also called CPR, and outline some planned future improvements in the use of the new fund.  CPR aims to establish a single rule book for the period 21-27, including enabling conditions, a key element for the control of Member States’ fund spending. Programmes funded by EU resources will have to respect enabling conditions and preconditions in order to achieve effective implementation. If conditions are not fulfilled, Member States will not be able to claim for the payment of their expenditures. On top of that, besides enabling conditions, CPR new rules require to measure the performance of the funds. For example, the Member States will have to conduct a mid—term review. So there are tools.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the story here isn’t actually about a few bad apples robbing EU funds and the need for the Commission to do more. The problem is actually the system itself. Now, of course I have no difficulty in acknowledging the corruption exposed in the recent CAP subsidies scandal in the likes of Hungary and Bulgaria. I’ve actually spoken about the corruption in Bulgaria on numerous occasions in committee here.  We have to get real. We can’t, on the one hand, come in here and talk about corruption and then agree to, for example, the lifting of the CBN. We can’t go on about tackling crime and corruption and invite individuals like Bulgaria’s disputed Mr Geshev, the state prosecutor, in here. But I think the biggest scandal about the CAP subsidies is that, when journalists started asking questions, they were blocked by the Commission itself: stonewalled and not allowed to get information. This is a EUR 58 billion programme. It should be open to scrutiny. And when the Commission doesn’t allow itself to be open to scrutiny and transparency, it too is complicit.

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is a percentage of people who cheat, but they don't deceive everyone, and here I agree with Monica Hohlmeier. There is a problem – sometimes fraudsters acquire land through fraud, and later also through fraud receive subsidies. And that's what we have to take into account, it just is. Not everyone does it, it's a part, a small percentage, but it's that percentage that we have to fight. My question – and the request – is this: would there be a will, here in Parliament, for all the institutions of the European Union to tackle corruption in the area of land trading in each of the Countries of the European Union? Let there be a report on the land turnover in all the countries of the European Union. Poland has a good law on this and we have managed to protect the country from fraudulent land turnover. With us, the fraudster will not buy land.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the recent New York Times report on the abuse of CAP subsidies is damning and undermines the trust and governance of CAP subsidies and how the funds are spent. The report reveals that CAP subsidies underwrite European oligarchs, mobsters and far-right populists. The report also showed that some national leaders used the money to enrich friends, political allies and family members, and yet the current CAP reform proposals want to give national governments more power and flexibility over how CAP money is spent. Only yesterday, the Irish agriculture minister, Michael Creed, put internal convergence on hold for the transition period of CAP. It means that he’s going to direct payments away from farmers with the lowest per-hectare values in favour of rewarding those with the highest values per hectare. It’s state-organised malpractice and EU citizens have a legitimate expectation to be treated equally.  What is the Commission going to do? Are they going to allow Member States to behave abysmally like this?

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are taking a very serious subject, because corruption is a cancer of democracy. And if this corruption stalks the area of european absorption, it is all the more problematic, because in this case, people are rightly concerned, sad, angry.  But if what's going on has been clarified today. A small proportion of those subsidy deposits where this corruption is dealt with. Now those found must be punished and simply put off the agenda. We can't work the way the Slovenian saying is that if you want to have one steak, you don't go to the barn to kill a cow, you buy this steak. So too, we must find such, whether it be the Granny, the Orbans or whatever they are, and we must make agricultural policy custom of the European people.  Commissioner Howard has proposed capping, upper limits, support for small farms, including targets that need to be set, so that we need to find solutions in this direction.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the need for the proper implementation of the Structural Funds, Cohesion Funds and the common agricultural policy is not at issue. There is no question of the need to combat corruption and conflicts of interest in the implementation of these funds. But you will understand that we wonder about the opportunity of this debate and the motivations behind it.  It is at the moment when some want to cut the budget, precisely in these two areas, in cohesion and agriculture, for the next seven years, that this debate takes place here. Those who are already the biggest beneficiaries of integration, the single market, common policies and the euro, want to be also the biggest beneficiaries of the budget. A logic that is also present in the proposal for the so-called euro area budgetary capacity that was discussed in the Eurogroup. A logic of fair return, which is anything but fair, which accentuates inequalities and divergences between States, which accentuates the benefits of some at the expense of the harm of others, which makes, for some to win across the line, others have to lose across the line. And that was it, it was above all this, what we should be discussing here.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for First of all, I would like to thank all those who have taken part in this debate from the outset. I say this deliberately because the only Member in the House who had complained about the empty ranks left himself immediately after he spoke. This is for the sake of completeness. Secondly, thank you also for correcting the chairman of the error rate. We would like to remind you of this once again: we have a very low error rate, and within this error rate, if you take the error rate as 100%, 98% errors, and a very small percentage is really fraud. I would like to emphasise this in particular and emphasise it. However, I would also like to thank you today for the very wide-ranging and general debate, which I hope will also feed into the regulatory discussions on the next financial framework, how to further develop the conflict of interest area, how to achieve greater accuracy in agriculture. I believe that Mr Dorfmann's comments, for example, are quite groundbreaking. I would like to add something to the point, for example, that today we see a trend that large retail chains are buying agricultural land themselves, producing agricultural products there and thus actually creating a value chain from start to finish and, frankly, competing with actual farmers. With regard to the immediate event, I would like to point out once again that we, as the Commission, have reacted quickly here, have been on the ground with audits and now have the task of acting within the framework of our legal provisions and conditions, and they are set out. And if we, as the European Union – Parliament, the Commission – find shortcomings in the rule of law, then we are also the first to be called upon to respect the principles of the rule of law on points and commas. I therefore ask for your understanding, if the current rules provide for confidentiality, if the current rules provide for a certain process sequence, that the other person can also react et cetera, then that takes time. If you do not agree with these rules, you can change them. But at the moment I am forced to abide by these rules, and I will. One final note: the European Public Prosecutor's Office will take up its duties in November 2020 and therefore cannot yet be called upon to take action.
