name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – András Lánczi, president of the End of the Century Foundation, the hinterland of the Orban government and fidesz, which is supported and maintained by heavy public funds, allowed himself a rather frank speech in an earlier interview, which he gave to a pro-government newspaper, also stuffed with public money. As the senior adviser put it, "what is called corruption is practically the main policy of fidesz". It is not possible to sum up what is going on in Hungary in a simpler, more honest and authentic way.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the EU disability strategy for the post-2020 period (2019/2975(RSP)). I would like to remind you that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous speeches and the use of the blue card, both in the usual way and through the electronic system. Instructions for use are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, addressing the rights of persons with disabilities is essential for this Commission. The ratification by the EU of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities: we have all taken the legal and political commitment to implement it, and you can be assured that the Commission remains fully committed to its implementation. I have the mandate to work closely with all Commissioners to mainstream disability in all EU policy areas during this College’s mandate. According to the latest figures available to the Commission, approximately 100 million persons in Europe have a disability. They represent a very important share of the EU population, and they must by no means be left behind. The current European Disability Strategy 2010—2020 is the European Union’s main instrument for implementing the UN Convention. Our future policy will pursue the same objective. In my view, the fact that we have a long—term strategy has proven to be essential. Proposing a new strategy for the next decade is certainly an option when evaluating the current one and considering the next steps. Such a follow—up initiative should build on the values enshrined in our Treaties and contribute to the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights, as well as of the Sustainable Development Goals. The Commission is currently carrying out an external evaluation of the implementation of the current strategy. This is in line with the ‘evaluate first’ principle of our Better Regulation Agenda. In consequence, the precise follow-up will be defined and agreed only once this evaluation is finalised by mid—2020. To improve coordination within the Commission and to mainstream the equality dimension – including disability – into all relevant EU policies, we have set up an Equality Task Force. We are committed to consult with the European Parliament and to take into account the two reports it adopted these last years. We will, of course, consult with all relevant stakeholders, in particular with persons with disabilities and the organisations that represent them. For instance, the European Economic and Social Committee unanimously adopted a valuable contribution to the debate just last week, and we are carefully studying those recommendations. On the basis of a thorough review of our European Disability Strategy, we will propose how best to move forward on implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) and disability mainstreaming. Our future disability policies will also have to take into account the changes affecting our societies. There are new challenges and also new opportunities. In this respect, I recall that the United Nations Convention recognises that women and girls with disabilities are subjected to multiple discrimination and calls on state parties to ensure the full and equal enjoyment by them of all human rights and fundamental freedoms. To this end, the future gender equality strategy announced by President von der Leyen in her political guidelines will pay particular attention to groups facing multiple disadvantage, including women with disabilities. Digitalisation and accessibility legislation have allowed us to lift some important barriers, but many hurdles still remain for people with disabilities, and in some cases, new barriers have appeared which need to be addressed. The fact that we are evaluating our current strategy does not prevent us from making further progress now. We already use – and will keep using – all tools available to achieve progress across Europe. Areas such as personal assistance or accessible and inclusive education are a primary responsibility of the Member States. However, the Commission is committed to keeping on working together with the Member States and supporting them in their endeavours. The European Semester and EU funds can be used for this purpose. European structural and investment funds already support the deinstitutionalisation and development of community-based services for persons with disabilities in the Member States. For the future programming period, having a national framework for implementing the United Nations Convention is proposed by the Commission as a pre-condition for receiving funding from any of the funds covered by the Common Provisions Regulation. This condition needs to be met throughout the entire 2021-2027 period when implementing the funds. It also cemented the importance of promoting independent living and moving from institutional care to family- and community-based care. The Commission is also working with the Member States to ensure the correct transposition of the European Accessibility Act. A first informal meeting with the Member States took place on 22 November 2019. More meetings are planned in the months to come. I now look forward to hearing your views on our future policies on disability.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I thank the Commissioner for the reply and I thank the European People's Party for supporting the effort to put this very serious issue on the agenda. No institution, no tradition, no power in the world can stop our thirst for human dignity, for real freedom. And in institutions, we're not just talking about wasted money, we're talking about discarded human lives. People are singed and tied up, without care, because that's how we got used to it. Dignity is to rebel against indifference that is becoming a habit. Don't let human life be thrown away, no way you're going to rise up against corruption and exploitation. Dignity is to honor all our fellow citizens. The big issue is not most money. According to a New York Times report, companies that hire disabled workers have on average 23% higher profitability, as our need to always try to address social barriers makes us innovative.  I call on you all to agree on the basics: institutionalisation is a violation of human rights 'made in EU', a prison funded by the European Commission. Let's stop funding the institutions now. All institutions present a more or less bad picture. The reality in Bulgaria, Romania, Greece, even in Brussels is disheartening. The Charter of Human Rights that preceded the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities stipulates that all citizens, disabled and not, should be able to choose their lives as free people, as equal citizens. Independent living is possible in a society with access to education, health, work, freedom of choice. It is important not only to stick to declarations but to ensure that there is a disability clause in all policies. Can the Commission make investments for inclusion and accessibility a priority in all EU policies? Do you consider accessibility initiatives to be part of our new vision for the New Green Agreement? Can the new Commission confirm that it will actively promote the transition to 'personal assistant', through the promotion of best practices and through the overall transfer of funds to institutions? In addition, can we secure a single labour market for disabled people? Thank you and I look forward to your answers.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, some people have to overcome many more hurdles in life than others. When you have a disability, the course you have to go through is much heavier. I therefore believe that our task is to create real equal opportunities for all in the new European strategy on disability. After all, everyone deserves a fair shot at a job. If you are in a wheelchair or have a visual impairment or a certain disorder, you are often underestimated. I would like to know from the Commission how it intends to change that. It is well known that the Dutch government lags behind the business community in terms of the recruitment of people with disabilities. What about Europe? If the European Union, as an employer, sets a good example, then this is possible everywhere in the labour market. Everyone must be able to participate in society without hindrance. As far as I am concerned, we must focus on this in the new action plan.

name: Abir Al-Sahlani
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you for the floor and thank you to all the Members who have raised this issue so that it is not forgotten. And thank you to the Commissioner for being here and trying to answer our questions and concerns. This strategy is at its core about human rights – human rights for everyone in the EU, human rights that are available. One of the important points in the creation of accessible societies is to review the implementation of the Functional Law Convention. It is high time to review it, albeit perhaps a little late.  Let me remind you that 100 million Europeans, European citizens, are waiting for their human rights to be met. Today, many Europeans live without the possibility of real participation in society, including in terms of the labour market, culture, studies and, not least, general elections, and not least the elections to this Parliament. It is unworthy of the world's only union of democracies that the elections to its elected assembly are not available to all its citizens. Our citizens who have a standard-breaking functionality do not have the same opportunity to participate in the European elections. That is why My intention is to push for a resolution that makes the 2024 European elections accessible to all, and here I hope for the support of my colleagues in the European Parliament.  A future strategy must focus precisely on the accessibility of the labour market, anti-discrimination legislation, training for young people, personal assistance and participation in democracy. I wonder how the Commissioner intends to ensure that this happens. Finally, it must, of course, be emphasised by the organisations representing this group in society must be involved in both the development and implementation of such an agenda. Because again, it is far better to include those it touches and to talk to, and not just about, these people, these 100 million Europeans.

name: Katrin Langensiepen
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which After almost ten years, the EU has still not managed to implement the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  Every day in the EU, the human rights of people with disabilities are violated. In order to guarantee them equal participation in social life, we must become bolder and more consistent. A continuation of the current strategy is therefore not enough. We call on the Commission to present a more ambitious strategy for the post-2020 period for all areas of action and to set clear, binding targets with fixed timeframes. We need strong monitoring with appropriate indicators and sufficient financial resources. People with disabilities must be involved in legislation and monitoring. This is the only way we can be honest about the implementation of the UN-BRK. In addition, we must consistently address the rights of people with disabilities in all policy areas and intersex discrimination at last. This is also the case in the new strategy for equality between men and women. Women and girls with disabilities are particularly often victims of abuse. We must defend their rights to sexual self-determination and the right to family, but we must also protect them from violence. Yesterday, Parliament agreed to my question to add a motion for a resolution to be voted on in February. Thank you very much for that.  I call on the Commission to take our proposals seriously and to be involved in the development of the new strategy.

name: Gianantonio Da Re
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Article 26 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union states that the Union recognises and respects the right of persons with disabilities to benefit from measures to ensure social and professional autonomy and integration and the participation of life in a community.  Well, in describing the Priorities of the European Commission, President von der Leyen has not once spoken the word disability, sad consideration and observation that tells us well what place disabled people occupy on the Commission's priority scale. Disability statistics and figures are disheartening. Disability in Europe affects around 80 million people, who often do not have the opportunity to participate fully in social and economic life due to behavioural and environmental barriers. By 2020, one fifth of europe's population is expected to have some form of disability, also due to an ageing population. These figures tell us that the European Union must do more for people with disabilities and attention to them must become a priority. If we want to create a truly inclusive society, we need determined political will. Let go of useless slogans and focus on the goal with concrete actions. Financial instruments should therefore be increased for people with disabilities, their families and voluntary associations, in particular the structures where they operate. Finally, the accessibility of disabled people to information must be improved so that they can fully exercise their rights as European citizens. It is the european Commission's moral duty to pay more attention to the weakest sections of our society, especially respect for their people and for the families who unfortunately have this problem.

name: Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová
text: for the ECR Group. – Mr President, forecasts say that after 2020 people with disabilities will account for up to one fifth of the population. We have the UN Convention, we have strategies, and yet we find even abysmal differences in the Member States. The current strategy clearly lacks monitoring of its implementation, we lack data. I will now tell you what such a person looks like, such a life of a person with a disability in Slovakia. Even after birth, it gambles with its potential, because we are completely failing early intervention. After a flawed or late diagnosis, he begins to lag behind his peers from more developed countries. Up to half of children with special needs are educated separately from their peers, even if their disability allows them to attend a normal primary school. People with disabilities can hardly be seen on Slovak streets due to barriers. If a wheelchair user wants to travel by train, it must humiliatingly report it to the railways the day before. Up to 7 people out of 10 with disabilities are completely excluded from the labour market in Slovakia. And we are still talking only about those who have not ended up in disastrous large-capacity facilities that we should have turned into community services a long time ago. The planned strategy after 2020 must bear in mind that we have an acute lack of comparable data and a lack of implementation. Very many countries show superficial improvements on paper that contribute to false statistics, which we then satisfy ourselves with. We must move on from the general recommendations and prevent the misuse of European funds for projects that go against the objectives of the strategy. It is very important for disabled people from countries such as Slovakia to promote a common European card for people with disabilities and to unify disability diagnoses.

name: José Gusmão
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the paradigm shift in addressing the problems of citizens with disabilities requires moving from an institutionalisation model to an independent model of life, from a model of segregation to a model of rights, but it also requires oversight in all policies that are implemented from the European Union.  We must know, to be sure, that funding for independent living policies will not serve in the Member States to perpetuate models of institutionalisation and segregation, as is still the case in many Member States. And we must also ensure that all European funding for all infrastructure and services complies with accessibility rules, i.e. that does not add to all the barriers that citizens with disabilities already have to face in their lives.  And we still need to deal with two other issues: the first, the definition of poverty and the increased risks of poverty faced by citizens with disabilities, which have to be addressed in a comprehensive strategy to combat poverty and, finally, overcome the discrimination that continues to exist in policies and ... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Chiara Gemma (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Commissioner Dalli said, the disability strategy is coming to an end in a context in which there are still over 100 million disabled citizens experiencing barriers to their independent lives on a daily basis. For the next strategy, we must demand much more ambitious targets. So what concrete action is being taken on principle 17 of the European Pillar of Social Rights dedicated to the inclusion of persons with disabilities who intend to undertake? A strict regulation for the management of the European Social Fund Plus must be adopted without delay, radically improving the conditions of disabled citizens in the world of work as well.  I would remind you that Eurostat photographs a reality in which only 50 % of men and 45 % of women have jobs. Within the framework designed by the European Children's Guarantee, we must relaunch the priorities of disabled children, ensuring equal access to traditional education with adequate support for their needs. This speech must go far beyond Europe's borders, as I mentioned in Panama during the work of the EuroLat delegation, where I requested a debate on the subject of inclusive education.  Finally, I would like to stress the importance of fully implementing the project of the European Disability Charter, on which I am personally fighting, an instrument that must be adopted by all The Member States and which can guarantee social services even when moving to another country. ... (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, many steps have been taken for people with disabilities over the last ten years. At the level of policy, there has been a shift from policy that is limited to the care aspect to policies that aim at full participation in society. These include, for example, the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the European Accessibility Act, which was worked on under the leadership of former European Commissioner Marianne Thyssen. Nevertheless, there is still a great deal of work to be done and the priorities for the next strategy need to be clearly set out. For example, efforts should be made to ensure the full implementation of the UN Convention and the European Accessibility Act. It is also necessary to ensure that both the regular labour market and the social economy are inclusive for people with disabilities. The use of the European Social Fund has already been mentioned in this context. Finally, full participation means being able to make their own choices regarding individual care needs. It is therefore important to include european coordination of the assistance budget in the new strategy. We are only a fully-fledged society if there is complete inclusion in all facets of life.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Commissioner, for your speech. Next year, 2020, more than 100 million Europeans are expected to have a disability, partly due to the ageing of the EU population. The current strategy has had a significant and positive impact. And together with all the work that is being done nationally in our Member States, we must continue the fight for an equal society.  People's different backgrounds or circumstances should not be allowed to determine the possibility of participation, and there are still a lot of challenges. Because although people with disabilities have the right to work on the same terms as everyone else, access to the labour market is still restricted. The employment rate is significantly lower for people with disabilities. We see the same thing in education. It is important for our children to receive an inclusive, high-quality education.  We also see that there is a greater risk of poverty and social exclusion. Not least, this affects women. So we need to work more actively on these issues. We must replace the current strategy with a new and powerful strategy. For me as a Social Democrat, it is about shaping a society in which everyone has the opportunity to be involved.

name: Radka Maxová (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the 2020 Disability Strategy is coming to an end, so let us now try to create a new, more ambitious one that can implement all the objectives of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This Convention has been signed and ratified by all Member States, which is a great commitment. Persons with disabilities should be seen as completely equivalent, in particular we should take into account the rights of women and children with disabilities, as the Commissioner has said. The great problem is still the accessibility of buildings, including authorities, cultural institutions and other institutions. Speaking of accessibility of buildings, it is also worth mentioning the facilitation of movement for persons with disabilities. It would also be appropriate to seek a uniform arrangement for the discount on motorway charges for persons with disabilities within the Schengen area, the barrier-free nature of means of transport in public transport or a single disability card. By educating and integrating people with disabilities, we will make a significant contribution to reducing their... (The President took the speaker's word.)

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Of course, the current strategy for people with disabilities must be evaluated. But it is already clear that we need a new one, we need a stronger strategy for the post-2020 period – a strategy that is effective in all areas: school, work, leisure, health, sexuality, family, and which also applies to all EU citizens concerned. We are not talking about luxury problems or charity, where there is no rush for time or coercion. Equality and self-determined living are not a luxury, limited freedom of movement and an increased risk of poverty, loneliness are no small problems! This is about the essential human rights of more than 100 million people, and it is already clear that we still have a lot of work to do in the European Union. Nor does the Commission have to wait for experts to be assessed in order to listen now and not to talk about, but with people with disabilities.

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have been working very closely with people with disabilities for years. I know that taking up paid work by a person with a disability is the best culmination of treatment and painciful, many years of rehabilitation, and maintaining such work is another challenge for these people. Employers with at least a 50% employment rate for persons with disabilities and creating a friendly working environment could: be entitled to the same state aid as small and medium-sized enterprises guaranteed by Article 17-30 of the Commission Regulation of 17 June 2014, including, inter alia, investment aid, consultancy services, fair participation, access to risk finance, start-up aid , for recognition costs, R&D and innovation. I hope that we all understand the situation of people with disabilities here and we will try to make this strategy realistic and as good as possible for them.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what does it mean to be a person with disabilities in the European Union today? What opportunities and prospects do you have? The present is not exactly rosy: of the 100 million disabled people in Europe, one in two people is unemployed, two out of three have not completed tertiary education or equivalent and two out of three are at risk of poverty. We spend a great deal of words on words, but then in deeds what are we prepared to do to change the situation? I ask you this because even in the recent past, when we discussed the Marrakesh Treaty here in this House, we had to overcome enormous difficulties in getting the Treaty ratified, because the debate always fell solely on the economic interests of a few. The basis from which to change things for me is precisely this: stop thinking only about the economy, but think about people's rights.  Having said that, we are preparing to lay the foundations of the European Union's post-2020 disability strategy and therefore, in my opinion, a full review of all EU regulations and policies is needed to ensure full harmonisation with the provisions of the UN Convention.  It is necessary to ensure that every project funded by the European Union includes accessibility among its points. This is also a way of informing and educating on these issues and it is necessary to involve the most representative organisations in this process. The task of this House is to guarantee every citizen a full life free of any kind of discrimination.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one hundred million Europeans are waiting for the Commissioner to step up and set out the new European Disability Strategy. We have had a Strategy, 2010-2020, which has had lights and shadows. There has been a European Accessibility Act. This Act did not cover the issue of transport as a whole, the issue of tourism, the issue of the accessible environment, the subject of micro-enterprises. We have a chance to correct it.  The Commissioner told us that she has set up a working group. What I'm asking is day and time. Because the new European Disability Strategy, on the subject that we need to take stock of the old one, cannot be delayed any longer.  We need the new Strategy, because it is the only way, the only tool we have to truly implement the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. So that we know what is accessible and what is not. And when something is not accessible, face it and eliminate it. We need the new European Disability Strategy in order to have a real inclusive education, with a real budget, with reasonable adjustments at work. We need data. We're short of data. You've talked about women. We do not have disaggregated data on how many people with disabilities there are in Europe, how many women, how we can evaluate it and that is why I ask you to...  (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Thank you, President. Commissioner Dalli, I congratulate and hope that the disability aspect will certainly be important in all the Commission's work. I believe that one of the eu's greatest achievements in the disability strategy for 2020 is the European Accessibility Act adopted last year. Therefore, when we talk about the EU strategy for 2030, we must ensure that the provisions of this Accessibility Act are properly transposed and implemented in the Member States. We also need to ensure that accessibility in other areas of public services is fully guaranteed over the next decade. For example, access to education, employment and healthcare is essential. At the same time, the future strategy must fully implement the social pillar so that our people with disabilities have adequate social guarantees to ensure a dignified life and services that enable them to participate in society and the labour market.

name: Dragoş Pîslaru (Renew).
text: – Mr President, there are a hundred million people with disabilities on European territory, and 840 000 of them are in Romania. Let us not forget that for them we are debating here today and that we must demonstrate by deeds that we are their voice. A new strategy is needed to take into account past lessons and commit to supporting in practice all rights as set out in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in order to guarantee their access and integration into society over the next ten years. A Commission strategy must have at least three points. The first point: ensuring access to society for people with disabilities through integrated measures on education, health, housing, mobility and accessibility of public services. Then invest in opportunities for people with disabilities to live as independently and actively as possible, especially with regard to access and integration into the labour market. And finally, equality, enhanced anti-discrimination legislation that ensures a sense of integration into European society and that their rights as European citizens are respected.

name: Kim Van Sparrentak (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the disability strategy of the past 10 years has led to several initiatives to establish better rights for people with disabilities, but to ensure full inclusion of people with disabilities in our societies we need to continue these efforts and work harder to create an inclusive European Union. We need to make it easier for people with disabilities to access the labour market, not only by creating work spaces that are accessible, but also by making the process to find a job inclusive for everyone. Maybe even more important, we need to make sure that having a disability doesn’t affect your income.  That is why I call upon the Commission that when this initiative for a fair minimum wage comes to the table, it will cover all workers and make sure that discriminatory minimum wages for people with disabilities are prohibited in all Member States. For people who are not able to enter the labour market because of their disability, we need to ensure a proper minimum income in order to turn around the high poverty rates amongst people with disabilities.

name: Patryk Jaki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to ask, when will the European Union start spending on people with disabilities, even if it is promil, such as new policies, such as, for example, the recent 'green policy', for which we hear that we are to spend hundreds of billions of euros? When, at least promil of these funds will be spent on people with disabilities? For their professional activation, for their education, also for how the disabled have to cope in old age, when they become seniors and when they have big problems with care? These are fundamental questions. Furthermore, I wanted to ask how the European Union intends to protect people with disabilities who are in advanced pregnancy and who in many countries have the right to be removed simply because they are disabled, at a time when they are often already able to live independently? Do we have a policy in this regard that also takes into account the concept of tolerance? Do we really want to tolerate people with disabilities?

name: Dennis Radtke (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Around one in five people in the EU is struggling with a disability. That is why a new strategy for people with disabilities is absolutely essential. Above all, if we are serious about implementing the Pillar of Social Rights, where the rights of disabled people are also an essential component. That is why I think that this oral question to the Commission can be a prelude – an important contribution – to this debate, which must be held with a view to the question: what more can we do to integrate disabled people into the first labour market in order to strengthen the social labour market? But also: How can we support the relatives of these people? Because it is not only a challenge for the people themselves, but also for the relatives. I am quite sure that we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), have a very important role to play in this process, because for us, as Christian Democrats, everyone has the same value, whether they are disabled or not disabled. This must not only apply in Sunday speeches, but must also be reflected in practical policy.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the new strategy is an excellent opportunity to remove barriers for people with disabilities and to ensure their better social inclusion. Under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, persons with disabilities, regardless of the degree of disability, belong to all human rights as much as possible. It is therefore necessary to focus on ensuring the quality of life, improving their care and maximise autonomy, that is to say, from institutional care, it is therefore necessary to move to care or to live within smaller residential communities.  Within this, the greatest obstacle is poverty, because it is precisely that they do not have access to employment that also poses a higher risk of social exclusion and mobility problems for people with disabilities, as the European Network for Independent Living also points out. Access to institutions is unfit and mobility between countries is not adapted. Therefore, as I say, greater social inclusion of people with disabilities is key.

name: Jane Brophy (Renew).
text: – Mr President, under the European Disability Strategy, many actions have been taken to promote equality for people with disabilities, but not enough was achieved. What stands out with the 5 million EU citizens with autism is their lack of opportunity for education and employment. People with autism face many challenges, starting with a lack of family and community support. Many end up in institutions. They face high levels of school exclusion and university dropout. Less than 10% of people with autism are in employment, mostly in low-paid jobs – far lower than for other disabilities. We must combat this inequality stigma and prejudice. Any future strategy must ensure support in our communities and help for families to raise children with autism at home. Sadly, my country will not be part of the next EU disability strategy. I hope that any strategy that my country adopts will at least match that of the EU.

name: Λουκάς Φούρλας (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing the European Union's disability strategy after 2020, thinking that one in six citizens in the European Union is facing some form of disability. Disability is, above all, a matter of human rights. There are no people with disabilities, but people with souls and needs. We wanted to be clear to the Commission about what we are asking for. We call for full implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities, full participation in all areas of life, with dignity. What we demand is that there is not a single man in any corner of Europe who, because of his disability, cannot do everything his fellow citizens do.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fully implementing the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, this is the objective that the European Commission must set itself in order to draw up the European strategy for post-2020 disability, which is also in line with the social pillar and the Sustainable Development Goals.  The work done so far is worthy, from the European Accessibility Act to the revision of public procurement legislation, but it is still insufficient. We need to do more for freedom of movement with inclusive transport policies, greater service portability, promotion of independent living, deinstitutionalisation. We need to improve labour market access policies and the fight against multiple discrimination. The next European budget must reflect these priorities, and the internal organisation of the European Commission must also reflect the transversality of policies for the inclusion of people with disabilities. The Commission is in the hands of the results of its public consultation and the path is outlined. Let us remember that when we talk about the rights of people with disabilities we are talking about universal human rights.

name: Chrysoula Zacharopoulou (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, there are 46 million Europeans, and they are invisible or almost invisible, because they are disabled and because they are women: this is double punishment. The inequalities and discriminations they experience on a daily basis are manifold: prejudices that can be an obstacle to normal schooling, difficulties in finding employment and careers, barriers to accessing health care, inadequate sexual and reproductive health monitoring, and women are more vulnerable to physical and sexual violence. Commissioner, in order to build an inclusive European society, it is essential that this new strategy incorporates an intersectional gender dimension. We will need data to provide concrete answers and improve their quality of life. Our citizens are not asking for more rights, they are simply asking for the same rights.

name: Frances Fitzgerald (PPE).
text: – Mr President, by next year, 2020, it is estimated that one in five Europeans will have a disability, totalling 120 million people. It is therefore imperative that we continue to take action to ensure that those one—in—five people have the opportunity to contribute to our society in the most meaningful way.  This will not be action, let’s remember, for a small proportion of the population, but rather for every fifth person that you see on the street or sit next to on the bus, for all Europeans therefore – people with disabilities, their families, their friends, our communities – I would urge the Commission to ensure that a new EU disability strategy is in place at the end of 2020 and to ensure a smooth transition between the two strategies. We know that the current strategy is wide ranging, covering many areas including training, healthcare and so on, but really this is no good if there are not the resources in place. We need to provide the resources as negotiations on the post-2020 MF continue, so we have a unique opportunity to earmark the kind of funding that is necessary. We must ensure that every personal and societal opportunity is given.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Manuel Pizarro (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 has proved to be an instrument to contribute to improving the lives of millions of European citizens with the most varied limitations. We have to acknowledge these advances, but we also have to recognise that there are still many problems to overcome, old problems such as access to the labour market, and new problems such as the transition to adulthood, the aspiration of an independent life and aging.  These are problems that need an effective, humanized and innovative response. That is why I think the Commission's commitment to the definition of a new European strategy is so important and I would like to hear a greater commitment from the Commissioner on this matter. We must take a step forward towards a society that fully integrates these citizens in a context of full equality and freedom. And we need to do this with the involvement of the people and organizations that represent them. People with disabilities have to have a central voice in this process.

name: Róża Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Janina Ochojska (here is her place, but she is not with us today because she is fighting cancer) asked me to draw your attention to an important aspect of the discussion that we are currently discussing. Many people with intellectual disabilities live in our society. For them, support schemes are needed to take up employment in the open labour market, so-called assisted employment, and supported housing, with the constant or periodic support of a qualified trainer. The European Union should include this in its new strategy and also allocate resources to it. It is important that every citizen can choose the best way for himself to develop and function in society according to his or her abilities. Disability adjudication systems in EU countries are patchy and each country has its own criteria. Urgent action must be taken to harmonise the disability system.

name: Marianne Vind (S&D).
text: Mr President! The EU disability strategy is now expiring, but we still have employment challenges for Europe's 80 million disabled people. Only 47% of Europe's disabled people are in jobs. Having a job affects your quality of life and has an impact on your finances. Studies show that employers' willingness to hire an employee falls enormously if something needs to change in the workplace, even if it is small changes such as flexible working hours or support tools.  When jobs are not inclusive, millions are deprived of the opportunity of a working life and the risk of poverty increases. There will be no more inclusive jobs from disabled people getting the minimum wage, which I would otherwise like to see many suggest as a solution. Of course, everyone with specialist skills must be paid for it, including disabled people. Everything else is humiliating. The new strategy for the area of disability must be a comprehensive one for the working lives we want for everyone in Europe.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, the support and protection of people with disabilities must be a matter for all of us, and above all for the European Union, which must take decisive action. But here in the European Parliament too, we must be the shield of people with disabilities and also the voice of the 100 million people in the European Union who are facing such an issue. The culture of the European Union and our European culture do not allow and tolerate discrimination against people with disabilities. Zero tolerance for discrimination against persons with disabilities. At the same time, I would like to stress that there should not be a single fellow human being who belongs to this category and who does not receive at least the minimum guaranteed income. The European Union will not be able and the European Union should not contribute a single euro for projects in member states that do not provide for projects that are incompatible with the accessibility of the disabled. Finally, the 'European Accessibility Act' must finally become a reality, and it must be made compulsory and compulsory for all Member States. Because only with mandatory regulations will we really be able to be proud of our work for people with disabilities.

name: Alex Agius Saliba (S&D).
text: – Kummissarju Dalli, ninsab ferm kuntent illi dan huwa l-ewwel dibattitu tiegťek fil-Parlament Ewropew bťala Kummissarju responsabbli mill-ugwaljanza. Il-Konvenzjoni [Ewropea dwar id-Drittijiet tal-Bniedem] hija dokument bi kliem u b'ťafna drittijiet, dokument sabiť ťafna. But jekk ma jiżix implimentat f'kull Stat Membru u anke abbażi Ewropea, dan id-dokument ma jkunx jiswa' lanqas il-karta li jkun miktub fuqha. Gťalhekk, dan huwa dibattitu important ťafna li juri wkoll l-impenn li dan il-Parlament gťandu sabiex ikun vuèi soda gťall-persuni b'diżability fl-Unjoni Ewropea. Fl-Ewropa fejn gťandna aktar minn 100 miljun persuna b'diżability illi jeťtieżu minna illi nkunu vuťi waťda u unita fuq livell Ewropew. Is-sena 2020 daqt magťna u gťaldaqstant l-istrateżija kurrenti waslet fi tmiemha wkoll. Jekk irridu li mmexxu 'l quddiem politika li twassal biex nies b'diżabilità jipparteżipaw b'mod sťiť u ekwu fis-sożjetà tagťna, gťandna bżonn strateżija żdida mżedda u b'ażenda aktar ambizzjuża f'dan ir-ward

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The strategy we are discussing today aims to promote a barrier-free Europe, to empower people with disabilities so that they can fully exercise their rights and participate in social and economic life without hindrance. The evaluation of the strategy over the last ten years has undoubtedly been positive, and I therefore believe that it should continue, after the necessary changes, of course, also after 2020.  However, I would like to draw attention to an aspect. To date, the Union has not decided to harmonise the status of persons with disabilities and those related to disability. Consequently, the granting of a degree of disability in one EU country does not imply automatic recognition as a disabled person in another Member State. I believe that this situation may lead to violations of the fundamental principles of the EU legal order, equal treatment and non-discrimination and the free movement of persons. The Commission should therefore consider taking appropriate legislative action in this regard, and I would like to ask the Commissioner to do so.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, concrete measures are needed to defend people with disabilities and give them the right to an independent life. For this, mobility, accessibility, information and inclusion must cease to be a mere list of good intentions to be a reality.  We argue that access to work with rights is fundamental in overcoming inequalities and integrating people with disabilities. States should promote measures to encourage their integration into the labour market, in particular through public training and employment policies, by adjusting labour legislation and regulating working hours to their needs and specificities, paying particular attention to the protection of pregnancy and maternity in the case of women with disabilities.  Even in a situation of dependence, people have to have rights and these rights also pass through the rights of caregivers, when they exist, and the existence of a humanized and accessible public network that supports informal caregivers and caretaked people. This is what we stand for.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to the spontaneous speeches.  I am sorry to have to tell you that I have more than three times as many requests to speak as we have allocated time in this debate. I would therefore ask you to understand that I will only consider six colleagues. Spontaneous speeches

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am concerned about the many people with disabilities whose voice I represent here in the European Parliament. The strategy is running out by 2020, and we do not yet have a new one. It is true that evaluation is underway, but we are late, so we should hurry with this, and I have the feeling that we care better for many groups in our society than we care for people with disabilities. I am also concerned about the situation in my country, where we still do not have regulated long-term care, which of course has a significant impact on the quality of life of all people with disabilities, and, of course, on the quality of life of their families. People with disabilities are often excluded and at risk from poverty, but not only they suffer, they suffer, as their families say. In Europe, we are giving money for many projects, and there is no reason not to find it for people with disabilities. More than that, it is important that we include them and recognise them as equal members of our society. Let the European strategy set an example for strategies in the other Member States.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the 2020 Europe strategy set out five ambitious targets, including unemployment, education, and fighting poverty and social exclusion. Yes, we have progressed overall, but not nearly enough for the disability community who, quite frankly, are fed up of waiting to be treated equally in all areas of life. We must be more ambitious and more inclusive. The 2020 strategy target was 75% employment rate in the EU. However, across the EU about 47% of persons with disabilities are now employed, compared with 72% of persons without disabilities. Meanwhile, 68.1% of the EU population with a disability would have been at risk of poverty without social benefits, allowances or pensions.  The new agenda must mainstream disability in all EU policies and laws and push for social acceptance of people with disabilities as part of human diversity by fighting all forms of discrimination and stigmatisation. I finally want to pay tribute to the work of the European Network on Independent Living, whose members demand quite rightly... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Union needs a new disability strategy and also to promote more intensive fulfilment in the Member States of objectives and accountability. In this new strategy I bet on placing personal autonomy as the first objective, which implies a better access of this group to the labour market. I insist on demanding more participation of cities and regions because this strategy is implemented from below. I call for more support for the social economy, from which most initiatives to create protected employment are undertaken. I hope that they will redoble the controls so that they comply and cover all the places that are reserved in the public administration and the private company for people with disabilities. The combined action of these factors has led to unemployment among people with disabilities in the Basque Country having dropped to 16%. Only one in three disabled people work in special centers. The rest are in the ordinary market.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the 2010-2020 strategy had great potential for integrating the disabled into European Union policies, but let us face it, it has failed. Today, disabled people are not satisfactorily involved in strategies such as Europe 2020, the European Semester or the ESF, ERDF or Erasmus. It just can't happen again. The new strategy must take into account two trends in the development of the European Union. This is population ageing and digitalisation. In the case of disability in old age, the common problems of these persons are multiplied.  People with mental illness or other psychosocial disabilities have also been forgotten in the past. Unfortunately, these people have found themselves on the fringes of the Interest of the European institutions. All sorts of austerity measures applied by Member States over the past decade are also to blame. To sum up, the Commission has a lot of work to do, in which it should, above all, follow the recommendations of the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Let's not make it up, let's do what we can.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, since 2005 we have battled in this Parliament to stop EU funding going to build institutions and I know there is a concern that some people regard smaller institutions as the answer. They are not. I would like you to pay very close attention to that.  Secondly, when we are banning things in Europe and we are banning plastic straws, I know that my citizens with a disability need plastic straws. So we should be very careful in our move for a more sustainable Europe not to disadvantage the already disadvantaged. Straws should be available as normal for those who need them. They are not – and should not – be regarded as a medical device.  My last comment: I want to give a shout-out to two organisations in Ireland. One called Walk, because they walk with, and in the shoes of those with a disability; they give them dignity and they find them work with businesses and they do a great job. Secondly, locally to my own area, I want to mention Prosper Meath. They have created videos and, if you watch those, you will understand how it is for people with disabilities. I’ll send you links.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I admit that I did not think you would give my word, but thank you, because I am a doctor, an emergency doctor, and not once have I treated such patients, and I want things to be very clear. We have an extremely ambitious policy, we have a fair assessment of the number of citizens at European level, but to really ensure that European quality standard for every person with disabilities needs funds.  I believe that on this European standard of quality in health that I keep talking about, we should develop special programmes from the Cohesion Funds, whereby we give the chance for every European citizen who has a problem, a disability, to have equal access to education, to health, to all that is his life every day, because otherwise we can speak nicely , there are extraordinary statements, we can make strategies, but I remind you that many countries will not be able to afford to ensure these things. And if we leave them on subsidiarity, I ask myself the big question that this strategy will have a lot more to lose. I ask every European citizen with disabilities to think about such a situation, and that social pillar to become the future of every citizen with disabilities.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Once again, I regret that I was unable to accept so many colleagues. I would point out that colleagues who have not been taken into account in the spontaneous speeches are able to put this on the record once per plenary session, and the speech will then be recorded in the Minutes as normal.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their contributions to this debate. I have taken note of all your very valid comments, and I can say that we are very much on the same page and I appreciate each and every remark. I also look forward to links which you may have; we are not reinventing the wheel. I think we shall emulate all projects which have been a success. So thank you for your contributions. I will reiterate what I told the European Disability Forum (EDF) and what I also told the Disability Intergroup of this Parliament: that I will do nothing about you without you. I think it is of the essence that, when we are working in the area of disability, whatever we do, we do it with people who have the knowledge and also with people who have disabilities. So rest assured that the process will be all-inclusive. This debate also shows once more the relevance and the necessity to promote equality and better inclusion of persons with disabilities in our societies. EU legislation, funds and social policy have increasingly provided important rules, tools and means for supporting persons with disabilities, and the Commission is committed to fulfil its role as a focal point of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I assure you that this commitment is a top priority for the Commission and for me personally. We will use all input received today, and also input received from stakeholders, to further improve our approach to disability and propose an appropriate follow-up to our current strategy. We will also take into account the reports adopted by this Parliament. They represent a great contribution to this process. These reflections will also feed into the Commission’s reflections on the future action plan for implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. I am sure that I can count on your support to further strengthen European disability policy. We need to bring it to the degree of ambition and protection that EU citizens expect from the EU in this area of policy. So thank you all for your contributions.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at a later part-session. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits all forms of discrimination based on disability, and affirms the right of people with disabilities to autonomy, social and professional integration and participation in community life. The European Strategy 2010-2020 has been an important tool in this direction, but inequalities with people with disabilities still persist: the difference in employment is too great; the drop-out rate is twice the general average, the higher the risk of poverty. There are still too many barriers to the needs of everyday life, even the most basic, of people with disabilities. And inequalities also affect children, the most vulnerable, whose protection commits us all. They must be guaranteed specific assistance so that they do not suffer any form of discrimination. For the first time there is a Commissioner for Equality, whose task is to strengthen the EU's commitment to inclusion and equality, and to ensure that the EU implements the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is therefore necessary for the EU to draw up a more ambitious strategy for post-2020, acting as a driving force for Member States' action to ensure dignity, equality and full implementation of the rights of persons with disabilities.

name: Josianne Cutajar (S&D)

name: Jarosław Duda (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome and hope that the Commission will engage in a matter-of-fact dialogue with Parliament on the new European Disability Strategy. Two years ago, the 4th European Parliament for People with Disabilities adopted a manifesto for a new strategy. The disabled community is eagerly awaiting a new, ambitious Disability Rights Agenda for the next 10 years!  More than 100 million people with disabilities live in Europe today and this number is increasing. Millions of disabled Europeans want to learn, work, participate in public life, travel, lead independent lives without hindrance. Meeting these expectations is not only a commitment for Europe, but a necessity. Europe needs the social, economic and intellectual potential of this group of citizens.  The availability of universal education for children and young people with disabilities and adequate support for teachers are crucial in order not to limit opportunities for further development. The obligation to adapt the workplace rationally, as well as to support european measures for the education and further training of persons with disabilities, the transition from dependence on benefits to employment in the open labour market are the best way to combat social exclusion and poverty. It is necessary to introduce European accessibility standards, especially in transport, and to regulate the rights of passengers with disabilities satisfactorily and to introduce a European Disability Card in general. I very much hope that the new European Commission will make building an inclusive, accessible Europe a priority.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Commissioner, given that the disability strategy has not carried out the expected effects and given that 1/5 of EU citizens have a disability, I propose that the post-2020 strategy be much more effective.  You need to do a thorough analysis to know how many children, adolescents, older people are disabled. Then we need to have a sufficient budget for this category of people, to increase inclusion, access to the labour market, mobility, but also budget for specialist interventions to correct disabilities, where possible, especially in children.  Commissioner, the problem of people with disabilities must be dealt with systematically and, if we think that more than EUR 135 billion is VAT evasion, annually, we could, through anti-fraud measures, have this money for programmes dedicated to those people who have the right to life like all European citizens. Talk to disability associations in all Member States and you will have the mirror of reality!

name: Elisabetta Gualmini (S&D)
text: in writing. This year marks the tenth anniversary of the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the last treaty that the countries of the European Union have approved in order to bring Europe closer to its citizens and their needs. The Treaty of Lisbon stated that the values of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity are central to the European project, for which we should all be grateful. Furthermore, as a result of the Treaty, Parliament has become a fundamental institution in the legislative process of the European Union. Finally, for ten years now, the directly elected representatives of the citizens have been a voice that cannot be ignored in Brussels. But, as we have seen in recent years, more needs to be done to reach the citizens of Europe and give them the answers they need in the face of enormous economic, social and cultural changes. The conference on the future of Europe will be a step forward in understanding how the Union can do more to serve people in Europe. I believe that the citizens, by voting en masse in the last European elections, have given a clear signal of participation that must be welcomed by our institutions.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – People with disabilities used to look at passive recipients of assistance policies. Most of them, however, are people of working age who want to actively participate in the labour market and social life, but do not have the opportunities created – they still face physical and administrative barriers, as well as the discriminatory attitude of some employers.  However, the exclusion of persons with disabilities comes at a huge price – the ILO estimates that this is up to 1 to 7 percent of a country's GDP. I am therefore of the opinion that the new European Union strategy on disability after 2020 should focus on removing these barriers. The development of new technologies and changing conditions and forms of employment offer great potential for the inclusion of persons with disabilities, but these elements must be used well. Changes should start at the earliest possible stage of education.  I also very much hope that the new strategy, as one of the priorities, will also include the full implementation of the European Accessibility Act, in partnership with the Commission, the Member States, the private sector and NGOs.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The aim of the new strategy for people with disabilities should be to increase their ability to fully exercise their rights and participate in society and in the European economy, in particular through the single market. It should be recalled that one of the priorities of the new European Commission is the European Pillar of Social Rights, which speaks directly of equal opportunities and, in paragraph 17, of the integration of persons with disabilities. Persons with disabilities have the right to receive income support that provides a decent life, to services that enable them to participate in the labour market and social life, and to a work environment adapted to their needs. There is still much to be done, if only in terms of improving accessibility, which is why I am pleased that the Government of Law and Justice in Poland has created a special social programme in this area. I hope that the new strategy will be a good continuation of the concluding European Disability Strategy 2010-2020.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – During my first term in Parliament, I worked as rapporteur on the report on the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020, which focused on the mobility and reception of persons with disabilities. Over the last ten years, the strategy has lived up to its expectations and made everyday life more livable for millions of Europeans with disabilities. In recent times, we have made great progress, such as the adoption of European accessibility legislation or the accessibility of websites, but we cannot stop on the road because there is still a lot of work to be done. The decade, meanwhile, has brought rapid changes in other areas: digitalisation is both a challenge and a great tool that can further help integrate people with disabilities. It is imperative that, for the period after 2020, we have a strong, complex, enforceable disability strategy that responds to new challenges in full line with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the Sustainable Development Goals and implements social inclusion of persons with disabilities with an even more complex approach. It is also important that the funding of the monitoring body is solved. A new approach to the horizontal directive must also be taken: it is impermissible that the prohibition of discrimination against persons with disabilities cannot be legislated because of dilemmas relating to other groups.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – For persons with disabilities, it is essential to adapt the infrastructure in order to create a convenient conditions for them to function independently. This also applies to people with intellectual disabilities who are able to function like all other citizens and perform many social roles.  In many EU Member States, closed-protected centres are the predominant form of social and professional rehabilitation for people with intellectual disabilities. This applies both to places where people with disabilities live and work. This is a discriminatory and limiting situation for them to function in society. An alternative to this situation is the organisation of systems to support persons with intellectual disabilities in taking up employment in the open labour market, so-called 'assisted employment' and 'assisted housing' with the permanent or periodic support of a qualified trainer. The European Union should allocate adequate resources to the promotion and establishment of the abovementioned support schemes. The aim is to increase the availability of care and support systems so that every citizen can choose the best path for himself or herself to develop and function in society according to his or her abilities.  Furthermore, there is no legal regulation in Community law on the mutual treatment of decisions on disability handed down in another Community country– each country applies its own criteria. Urgent action should therefore be taken to harmonise the system of adjudication of disability.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – The EU disability strategy is very important for many Europeans. I would like to draw the attention of Parliament and the Commission to a number of issues. In the European Union, one in six people has a disability from an easy to severe level, which means that around 80 million Europeans cannot participate fully in social and economic life due to environmental barriers and attitudes. Meanwhile, the poverty rate for people with disabilities is 70% higher than the European average, as well as due to limited access to employment. The aim of the strategy must therefore be to improve the quality of life of people with disabilities and to eradicate discrimination and social exclusion. The creation of a society ensuring the full social inclusion of these people will also bring new opportunities for the development of the European market and the economy. This document recalls that the European Union and the Member States are responsible for improving the socio-economic situation of persons with disabilities. This is a very important commitment. According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, persons with disabilities are those with long-term physical, mental, intellectual or sensory impairment that may prevent them from fully and effectively participating in society. The European strategy should therefore define the actions and mechanisms needed to implement the UN Convention in the European Union to prevent people with disabilities from experiencing social exclusion.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the results of COP 25 (2019/2998(RSP)). I would also like to remind you in this debate that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous speeches and the use of the blue card, both in the usual way and through the electronic system. Instructions for use are still available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the outcome of the COP25, which has just finished in Madrid.  You are certainly aware that the conference ended 42 hours after schedule – a delay which is testimony to the difficulties encountered during the negotiations.  With your permission, I will come back to these difficulties in a moment. I would like to point out some important progress that was made in the EU’s climate policy last week. Firstly, last Wednesday the Commission presented the European Green Deal, which is a road map to embed climate action into all policies.  Secondly, one of the main priorities of the Finnish Presidency was reached in the European Council which, after a long debate, endorsed the objective of achieving a climate neutral EU by 2050, in line with the objectives of the Paris Agreement. However, one Member State at this stage was not able to commit to implementing this objective as far as it was concerned, and the European Council will come back to this Member State’s position in June 2020.  The decision by the European Council is a step forward. The EU has now agreed on the common objective of climate neutrality and all the Member States but one have committed to implementing it. It is important that the work continues and that next year all Member States will commit to its implementation.  Now, honourable Members, coming back to the Madrid Conference. I would like to recall what was at stake at the conference, both for the planet and for the EU.  COP25 had three major objectives.  First and foremost, to finalise the rule book on the issue of the carbon market, as laid down in Article 6 of the Paris Agreement. Second, to complete the review of the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage, and finally to agree on the extension and revision of the Gender Action Plan.  On these objectives the EU negotiation position was clear. The rules on Article 6 should ensure robust accounting for the use of international carbon markets, should avoid double counting and should also guarantee environmental integrity.  Concerning the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage, the EU should resist calls to create additional institutional mechanisms, but should support instead solutions that would provide for countries to effectively address loss and damage associated with climate change. As to the gender action plan, the EU was supportive of an extension and revision which strengthens gender considerations and women’s participation in climate action.  On 2 December, addressing the conference on behalf of the EU, the Presidency made it clear that, in front of this climate emergency – the one this Parliament declared last month – we had to change our approach dramatically and embrace the green revolution. Our objective being to make Europe the first climate—neutral continent on the planet by 2050. Indeed, during these two weeks of negotiations, it became increasingly clear that there was an elephant in the room – ambition, which was not on the agenda of this COP – turned out to be a major issue.  A number of parties, together with NGOs, the youth with Greta Thunberg, and the public at large, in their thousands in the streets of Madrid, called on the COP to do more to address the climate emergency.  Here I salute our team of negotiators who spared no effort and worked literally 24/7 to achieve the best possible results. Their task was made extremely difficult because a small number of parties either refused to engage or insisted on mechanisms under Article 6 that could potentially be the death knell of the Paris Agreement. Until the very last hours of the COP, the EU showed the maximum possible flexibility in view of striking a deal which would preserve environmental integrity. Unfortunately it proved impossible.  Ladies and gentlemen, there are several lessons to be drawn from this experience.  First, standing by its principles for the common good, the EU is increasingly recognised as the champion and the main actor of the Paris Agreement. By launching the EU Green Deal we translate our words into action.  Second, great progress has been made. Although no agreement was reached on Article 6, the quality of the texts on the table has significantly improved. An agreement on these texts at the COP26 in Glasgow next year seems within reach.  Third, we read in the news that the results of the COP are disappointing, but we should look at what has been achieved. The review of the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage and of the framework for capacity building have been successfully completed, and the Gender Action Plan has been extended. And it was agreed that the work on the global climate action agenda would continue beyond 2020.  So, ladies and gentlemen, to conclude, the EU will continue to negotiate the implementation of the Paris Agreement in the same spirit. In 2020 the parties will have to update their nationally—determined contributions and submit their long—term strategy.  I would take this opportunity to call on all parties to update their nationally—determined contributions in a manner that reflects their highest possible ambition.  I look forward to this debate and I thank you very much for your attention.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union and its Member States, as was shown by the Member States present, the delegation of the European Parliament and the Commission, stand firm behind the Paris Agreement. We stand firm behind the global transition to a climate-neutral future and the Commission believes in a Green Deal for Europe to lead the way.  The COP in Madrid is now behind us. It did not deliver what we had travelled there for on international carbon markets and on other issues. For Europe, there were some bridges that we just could not cross if we want to lead on climate; if we wanted to stay credible towards our international partners; if we wanted to respond to the young people in the streets and to citizens here at home in Europe who are asking for action and a plan for the climate.  To put it plainly, we could not support global rules that would undermine the very integrity of global climate action. We could not endorse an outcome that would take us back on climate instead of taking us, and the rest of the world, forward. But now, we, in Europe, will be looking forward. We will build on the global consensus to work next year to increase climate ambitions worldwide.  I noticed, and I think many of us who were there noticed, that the world is watching us, and they know that our task is more urgent than ever. Last week we presented in your Parliament the European Green Deal, which is our proposed roadmap to take climate action across all our policies. We have committed to climate neutrality by 2050, and we set out a timeline to increase our ambition for our emissions reductions in 2030. That’s Europe’s momentum to increase ambitions worldwide and we will work relentlessly next year to do this.  And I have to say that there were quite a number of countries in Madrid who were interested by this and who want to talk to us to see whether we can create alliances and help them do the same.  By COP26 in Glasgow, we intend to propose to update our nationally determined contributions to tackle climate change. We also need to submit our long-term strategies in line with the Paris objectives and in the European Union we are ready for this. We cannot afford to leave anyone behind.  At the COP in Madrid, Europe showed solidarity with the countries that are most vulnerable to climate change. We must make sure that we help the most vulnerable in their climate efforts so that they are taken along in this effort, that they have the capacity to deal with the changes so that they find courage and hope in a better, sustainable future. You know, nothing makes such an impression as talking to representatives from countries that can quite literally disappear if we don’t do anything about climate change.  So I think that we can build the capacity to deal with the changes so that we, together with them, can find the solutions. This is what our citizens want, in Europe. They want it also for people outside of Europe. The EU and its Member States already provide more than 40% of the global climate finance. Europe will continue to scale it up in line with the Paris Agreement, so we remain firmly committed to boosting global climate finance and to supporting developing countries.  We remain committed to achieving the USD 100 billion financial goal and financing the key funds under the Convention and Paris Agreement. We look forward to the commencement of deliberations on the post-2025 goal at COP26, to submitting information on our finance beyond 2020 next year, and to taking further action to align global finance with the Paris goals. This Commission and this Parliament know that people are calling for action, and that in fact they are taking action on the streets themselves to push us for more ambition and a concrete climate plan. Most of us who have children know they talk to us at home – what are you doing? Are you doing enough? You should be doing more! It’s a good thing. It’s a good thing to see this young generation lead us. It’s a good thing to see that the 16-year-old climate activist was named Person of the Year by Time magazine. It’s good that this generation is taking this huge responsibility.  I think our Green Deal responds to the calls. The Green Deal is a start for Europe to reinvent itself, to base our wealth and our well—being not just on carbon, to get rid of that as an essential element. I believe it’s a once in a lifetime opportunity to deliver a greener and cleaner future for our citizens, without leaving anyone behind.  Next year, on the global stage, we will work with our partners to raise global ambitions. We will fight to make sure that we all face head-on the urgent challenges of climate change. I know we can count on this Parliament to do that, and I know that this Parliament understands that the fact that Europe has only 9% of emissions does not give us an excuse to not do anything, because I’ve also seen in Madrid that if we lead, others will follow.
