If we lead, others will be convinced to go the same way. If we lead, those who are hesitating today will no longer be hesitating tomorrow.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Given the urgency of action and the legitimate expectations of people, especially young people, this was, of course, a disappointment of what happened in Madrid. In the case of Article 6 in particular, it would have been good if we had achieved a good result. However, we, as the European Parliament delegation, have always said to the Commission and the Council: we would rather not have a deal on Article 6 at all than a bad deal. For there was a danger that we would fall behind the Paris Agreement, that the old world, where not all states have obligations, should be rescued into the new period, when states such as Brazil also have obligations to do something themselves and not just to allow trade in questionable allowances to take place in their country. That is why it was right that the Commission and the Council remained strict here. Outside the official negotiating rooms, there has been a positive development: for several years, I have systematically asked our partners from Japan, South Africa, Mexico and many other major countries: What are you doing to raise your climate target? And until a few months ago there was always a great silence. Some of them did not know what we were talking about at all, when we in Europe were talking about higher ambitions and, in some cases, passed laws that went beyond Paris, they did not know what we were talking about. That has changed. We will find partners, for example with Canada, but also with the listed countries. And we need to keep putting pressure on. That is why the international dimension of climate policy is now more important than ever. That is why the GROUP of European Democrats also wants a high-level climate ambassador. Mr Vice-President, the day has only 24 hours, you cannot do everything on your own. But I know that this is also a priority for you. And we must act together. Because only if the European Union leads but takes others with it can we really avoid dangerous climate change.

name: Jytte Guteland
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Vice-President and Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his I would like to start with the clear message to the citizens of Europe that those of us who belonged to this delegation absolutely went to Madrid with the highest expectations and with a strong political message from the European Parliament. In retrospect, however, Like all previous speakers, Madrid, despite the good hospitality of Spain and Madrid, did not deliver politically what we are entitled to expect as citizens.  The rule book that would be a strong proof that you are living up to the Paris Agreement was not at all successful. Despite long negotiations and very good intentions, not least on the part of the EU, an agreement on the rulebook was not reached. This is very negative and I would say directly irresponsibly by the countries that should be held accountable for this, such as Brazil, the USA and Russia, which took a very destructive line. The only thing that comforts is that a bad deal would have been worse than no deal. The fact is that a weak regulatory framework could have undermined our ability to make a stronger climate year in 2020. I would also like to pay tribute to the Commission for its work and Mr Timmermans for his hard work in Madrid, also for the Green Deal, which will really be a 'game changer' for Europe, but thus also send a clear message from europe to the rest of the world that we are even more clearly ready to take leadership together with the constructive forces that listen to science and young people.  This is the only way forward. It must be clear. We are going to do more to reduce our emissions in Europe and in europe, but we also need to continue to keep the pressure on the international community for Glasgow, and it is good that we are united in that message. It is also important that everyone takes responsibility, all industries, all countries, all political levels. And we Social Democrats from the Socialist Group will be a very important part of that work and push for higher ambition.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I would actually like to start by thanking the Commissioner, with the too long title, for the way in which he kept us informed during the days in Madrid. We had a strong feeling that we were in the loop. The same gratefulness goes also to the Finnish Presidency, especially one old policy advisor from the Parliament who was a very eager person, who informed us at almost every step. So we knew what was going on, and what was going on was really disturbing. After coming back from Madrid, I tried to quantify what was actually at stake. A report from the US Department of Energy says that the amount of Russian allowances is about 884 million tonnes, probably the same amount as in China. So had we given in during the negotiations, there wouldn’t have been any policy left. So we did the thing we had to do.  For my part, the most touching discussion we had was actually with the delegation from the United States. There’s an old saying in American politics: the shining city on the hill. That was used in 1630 when the first pilgrims left for the eastern coast. That was a mark of being a leading state in the world. Today, the US is not the shining city on the hill anymore. So congratulations, Commissioner, I think we are the shining example when we speak about environmental policy in the world in the future.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the Finnish Presidency and the Commissioner for their contributions in Madrid in trying to make something out of this. But let’s be honest: Madrid was a disappointment. It was clearly a disappointment. It has been stated before. We came to Madrid with little on the agenda, and even that we didn’t manage to conclude. And that does not bode well for next year in Glasgow, because then it needs to happen. In Glasgow, that’s the moment where we can really raise our ambition. And it’s needed. We are still on a track of warming more than three degrees, with all the devastating consequences, and the world is bickering about details, about allowances, taking them from old to new periods, or here in the Parliament, the EPP is saying that we need a climate envoy. This kind of institutional battling doesn’t help the climate. What helps is really more ambition from Europe, and what is important there is that we need it on time. This is really a question to the Commissioner: how do you see 2020 evolving? Because this is going to be a crucial year. How are we going to make it happen that Europe is on time with increasing its ambition so that in September, when there is the EU-China summit in Leipzig, we can really try to get China on board with more ambition? Because that is absolutely needed in order to create dynamics when we go to Glasgow and also to get other partners in the world at a higher ambition level. This kind of choreography is a bit unclear so far, and I would like to hear from the Commissioner what his view is on how he sees 2020. A final comment: the role of some of the countries was clearly just blocking, and one of them was Brazil. And I would also like to hear, both from the Council and the Commission: will this have repercussions for the trade deal that is on the table – Mercosur? We all know it will not pass anyhow; there are already countries saying that they will vote against. So this is also the moment to really become serious about sustainability demands within our trade deals, and Mercosur should be the first.

name: Silvia Sardone
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN Conference on Climate Change was a total failure on behalf of the ID Group. The slogan was "Time to act" – which is also the slogan that also uses the Greta note – the result a total flop. However, we will only remember this important international meeting because of the money wasted. About 200 delegates, who were there for two weeks, before for another few weeks went the officials, the staff, all of course with flights to Madrid, to the peace of the pollution that you fill your mouth so much, probably it wasn't important there, the ecologists there didn't care. But a nice video conference, right? Because just to end up with nothing, it's not like we needed to move all these people. The European Union has made a miserable impression, and in any case let me say that it should also stop shouldering responsibilities that are not its own because taking on the whole burden of climate change seems to me to be a bit of madness.  The 2015 Paris Accords set climate targets for developed countries by saying they must move first. But I wonder, China and India, which are the world's economic giants, which are at the top of the rankings for CO2 emissions and pollution, but in the European Union they continue to be considered developing countries, with the result that they are free to pollute until 2030 and are even free to divide a hundred billion dollars from Europe, America and even the other developed countries for the new climate policies.  I would like a somewhat more realistic approach on the part of the European Union and also to have climate policies that are not so invasive. In general, you also thought a little more about the problems of European citizens.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The 2015 Paris Agreement reaffirmed the parties' determination to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Some even claimed that once adopted, there would no longer be a need to protect EU industry from global competition. What is different, however, is the general treaty written on paper, and what is different is the specific provisions intended to implement it. The latter proved too difficult. Great progress has been made in Katowice in this area by drawing up the Katowice Book of Rules, but the rules on market mechanisms provided for in Article 6 have been lacking. The reason is obvious – it is these market mechanisms that are a source of income for many parties to the Paris Agreement, which they do not want to give up. For this we still have transparency problems. China continues to prove that it does not want too much transparency in reporting, which calls into question the sincerity of their intentions. That is why today we cannot talk at all about the fact that the principles of protecting our industry from global competition from countries with weaker climate solutions are already a thing of the question. We still need this protection, perhaps more than ever before, especially in the face of the Green Deal that we are about to implement. What about the European economy?

name: Mick Wallace
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, COP25 was a let- down and a lack of international leadership and a global swing to the right hasn’t helped. The recent right-wing coups in Venezuela and Bolivia have undermined the positive role of the Latin American ALBA group in these international climate talks. These countries were once prominent advisors on indigenous rights, climate justice, and non-market approaches. Instead, we are making very little progress, thanks to right-wing and liberal major economies. Canada, USA, Australia, Brazil, Saudi Arabia have left a lot to be desired. They are preventing us from even reiterating the requirements of the Paris Agreement in the COP conclusions: that we need to boost our efforts before next year. It’s a sad affair. In the run-up to COP25 we were negotiating and celebrating the idea of a trade deal with the Mercosur countries, which is toxic, and the idea that climate diplomacy is going to be an effective tool is a myth, from what we are seeing. I would like to say to Mr Timmermans that he has a big job at hand and, Mr Timmermans, you will need to get your pal, Phil Hogan, on board as well. Good luck with that one!

name: President. –
text: I will keep strictly to the time limit because we have so many catch-the-eyes that, if you overrun the time, I cannot take other colleagues, so please, stick to your time limit.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, for years we have been witnessing what can now be called a theatre: the great international climate conference. I am 25 years old and at the 25th edition the result is always the same: nothing in fact, nothing done. Twenty-five years since politicians, heads of state, heads of government, scientists and professors meet, and the result is once again the same: nothing in fact. China is the first polluting country in the world, followed by the United States, then India, then there is Russia, then there is Japan and then there is Germany. Do you really believe that these great industrial powers will block their industrial production because the planet must be saved? They never will, just 60-70 years ago, wage war on each other. We waged war between us and we were ready to destroy ourselves all. Millions of people have died and now they should change their destructive disposition because the planet must be saved and only four poor scientists say so. They never will.  Then we must intervene with the European Union. Yes, that's true, but the Green New Deal isn't enough. We must prevent oil extractions from ing once again now. Imports from China must be stopped if China does not adapt. Imports from the United States must be stopped if the United States does not adapt. If we don't do these brave things, nothing will ever change and we will roast everyone, including our children.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Madam President! I attended cop25 in Madrid last week and I believe that my colleagues from all the political groups in this House, who also participated, agree with me that the message from the vast, vast majority of countries and delegations we spoke to was that the European Union should step even more clearly into the global stage as the role model we are the only ones that can fill in.  As a bourgeois liberal, as a Christian Democrat and as a conservative in the Danish way, I believe that we do the best in the way we work with our industries and companies so that they can convert production methods and energy consumption in a carbon neutral direction.  We in the European Parliament can only do this if we cooperate constructively, technology-neutrally and, above all, evidence-based, and we can only do so if we create a green industrial policy that improves Europe's competitiveness even further, creates more jobs and strengthens us, so that we are eternally adaptable, so that the next generation does not have to deal with the great crisis and emergency that we are struggling with right now.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to highlight organizational success. The cancellation of the COP would have been a sledgehammer. It is a pride that the socialist government has drawn its gaze to the solvency of Spain. A success that we want to share with the whole European Union.  Yet, as Spanish Minister Teresa Ribera has said, the COP of Madrid leaves us with a bittersweet taste. In a context marked by citizen social vindication, more ambition against climate change and, at the same time, with a set of countries with denier positions, the European Union has shown leadership and firmness. The Council's agreement to commit to climate neutrality in 2050, the climate emergency declaration adopted in this Parliament, the simultaneous presentation of the European Green Pact with the COP, with the outstanding work of Commissioner Timmermans, managed to engage other governments and ensure that it did not derail the Paris Agreement. This shows us the power of the EU when we work together.  However, it is true that no significant progress has been made in global carbon markets. Some intended to undermine the Paris Agreement and the European position has not allowed it. As has been said, better a non-agreement than a bad deal. It's not all bad news. Progress has been made in the need to bridge the gap between Paris' current efforts and objectives, progress has been made in a gender perspective, in making a fair transition.  We have a tight schedule left for Glasgow. We have to achieve 55% emissions reduction. It is the generation that requires us to live up to it that will have to finish this transition. Let's make it easy. Let's do more and faster.

name: Catherine Chabaud (Renew).
text: Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I am also returning from Madrid and I would like to express my mixed feeling because we could indeed have expected more ambition. But still good news: even if, until the end, we feared that the ocean would be completely excluded from the final declaration, the Chilean Presidency managed to maintain its objective of making this COP a blue COP. It has been reinforced by the holding of more than 90 events on the theme of the importance of the ocean in the balance of climate, but also increasingly to illustrate concretely how States can include, in their national contributions, solutions based on the ocean. This is the example of blue carbon, it is all these ocean forests like mangroves, it is marine energy, it is the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from ships. The final text also calls for a dialogue in June 2020 and calls on stakeholders to submit their contributions by 31 March. The European Union must mobilise, join the community of friends of the ocean and include in the Green Pact for Europe, which I fully support, a genuine global strategy on the ocean.

name: Pär Holmgren (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Unfortunately, as several of the speakers before me have noted, the world failed with much of the really important details in Madrid. Not least in terms of how responsibility for the transition in the future should be distributed. That is why it is even more important now that the EU, in particular, takes clear leadership and shows ambition and precisely clear leadership. This political leadership, it must be based on a holistic approach and, in terms of climate change, a policy based on science. This will not mean a 50-55% reduction by 2030. Nor is climate neutrality enough as late as 2050.  But at least an important decision was made in Madrid, about which the media have not reported much. The world agreed on a new five-year equality plan to make climate action and the Paris Agreement fairer and more equal. This is something that we Greens have been fighting for for a long time in the European Parliament, because without equality, we cannot cope with the challenges we face.  In all likelihood, the 2020s, as we are in full speed heading into now, are the last decade we have if we are to manage to keep global warming below 2 degrees. And next November, as we all know, it is time for the next big meeting in Glasgow. In the meantime, we must raise our ambitions and take global leadership, at a time when, unfortunately, no one else seems to want to do so.

name: Laura Huhtasaari (ID).
text: – Mr President, Europe is doing its bit, but we cannot save the whole planet, because the EU's emissions account for 10% of global emissions. Climate tariffs must primarily be introduced so that China in particular cannot act as a free rider of climate and trade policy.  The EU should better understand the wood needs of the Finnish forest industry and not make it more difficult to finance nuclear power plant projects because of ideological motives. Nature is important to every human being, but we cannot protect nature if we ruin the operating conditions of the welfare state and the national economy.  Species have become extinct for almost as long as there has been life. An estimated 95% of species that have ever lived have become extinct. The climate has always changed, and species have also died regardless of human activity. The current wave of extinction is caused by human activity. Large forests are being cut down to make way for crops and settlements, for example.  In the 19th century, there were less than two billion people. Now there are just under eight billion of us and the annual population growth is estimated at around 82 million. No reduction in emissions will suffice if we do not curb population growth. Population explosion is the biggest challenge facing the climate – solutions must be found.  The end result of the EU's climate policy must not be that countries become indebted, the people become poorer and purchasing power weakens. The EU's climate policy must not improve the competitiveness of asian and US economies at the expense of European countries, because global emissions are therefore only increasing. To this end, I would like to wish the whole House a very good 'Merry Brexmas'.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I will be as raw as the raw consequences we face with the current measures. The result of COP25 is the signing of an announced genocide. Two visions facing the world: those who defend capital and those who defend life. There's no time for Glasgow, the time was now. Reducing CO2 emissions to limit global warming, regulating carbon markets, financing the Green Fund for the most vulnerable countries remain to-do. We have seen the largest companies most polluting subsidizing the COP, governments that allow it, sitting on their board of directors, and the reactionary international pressing to hinder the objectives through accounting tricks. You can't fight climate change without ambition. Nor can we, from Europe, without questioning the current system, demand individual responsibilities and not fight against large polluters, while carrying out continuing policies that legitimize the looting of multinationals or bet on free trade agreements that destroy our local fabric. Our full support for an ambitious, courageous, binding commitment, with resources for a fair transition. We're leaving the planet on it. We're going to have our lives on it.

name: Dolors Montserrat (PPE).
text: – Madam President, you will all agree that the best thing about COP 25 has been the organisation by Spain, our Mayor Almeida and our President Ayuso, because the results have not been as expected.  Europe has done its homework with the presentation of the Green Deal, but the problem is that only Europe does its homework. Not only do we have to lead within the Union, but we have to convince and demand outside the European Union. And let me tell some people that the fight against climate change is not a photo or a tweet, nor to expect Greta to solve all the challenges. Because the fight against climate change is not a banal thing, but it is vital and the responsibility of all. Within the EU we must overcome the barriers imposed by both far-right denialism and far-left hysteria.  And for EU leadership to be true we need to unlock the multiannual budget: to finance the right transition, to leave no one behind, to protect employment and the economy. Only in this way will we really lead the fight against climate change.

name: Mohammed Chahim (S&D).
text: Mr President, I am very disappointed that no agreement has been reached in Madrid. An international climate agreement such as the Paris agreement is, of course, great, but without clear agreements on its implementation, it is merely empty words. Nevertheless, I am pleased that the EU has not set aside its ambitions during the negotiations and has not catered to the will of less ambitious, polluting countries such as China, Brazil, the United States and Australia. Better no deal than a bad deal. The most important question is: what about the next? We need to take steps before the next Conference of the Parties in Glasgow. That requires two things. Firstly, the European Green Deal offers an excellent opportunity to show the world not only how it is done, but above all how it can be done. Good leadership does follow. If the Member States show the same ambition as Parliament and the Commission, we can actually achieve our objectives under the Paris Agreement and also encourage the rest of the world to participate. The European Green Deal must be a success! Secondly, as Europe, we must not only lead by example, but we must also tackle and force the sleepers in this world to take action. We are the largest consumer power in the world and we need to make better use of our position. We must make the production of goods more sustainable for Europe and impose strict requirements on it. If you do not want to contribute to a cleaner climate and do not want to make your industry more sustainable, you have to feel it at the border.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, it is a little ironic that we are talking about the outcome of COP 25 when there really wasn’t one. Simply agreeing to meet next year and hoping that world leaders can be more ambitious isn’t an outcome, but a failure. Failure to deliver and take meaningful action, failure to listen to science and evidence, and failure to live up to the expectations of citizens, who demand a safe and sustainable future. In Madrid, we witnessed once again how political greed overpowers common sense. With the majority of big emitters unwilling to take climate change seriously, the EU must become an even more prominent world leader regarding climate protection, and I am aware of the criticism we receive. Commuting between two parliaments is terrible for the environment and, yes, we use way too much paper in this House but, on the global level, the European Parliament is probably the most ambitious and committed institution to fight climate change. The Members of this House must be the engines of change and the ambassadors of global climate action, and we need tools to do that. We need the right of initiative so we can issue our own proposals, and this step would be more impactful than the outcomes of COP 25.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Vice-President Timmermans, and also to the Commission as a whole, for staying tough. For if the Paris Agreement had been undermined here in Madrid, that would have been truly fatal. I am particularly glad that there are now no lazy rules for this so-called emissions trading scheme. After all, what is described in Article 6 is not really emissions trading. After all, there is no upper limit – as in the case of real emissions trading – but the basis is the national climate plans. Each country can write in what it wants to achieve now.  If I can sell any additional reduction that is achieved beyond my plan expensively, then of course that is an incentive to set the bar as low as possible. That is why it is perhaps not a bad thing if nothing has been achieved in this area. This does not mean, of course, that this COP of gridlock is a good thing. On the contrary! The millions of people who have taken to the streets to demand climate protection are disappointed, and they have seen that governments have no reliance. This makes it all the more important that the High Ambition Coalition – the Coalition of Ambitious People – now travels to Glasgow in a coordinated and well-prepared manner. I believe that with an ambitious green deal, we can also be a role model, and we are very happy to support that.

name: Herve Juvin (ID).
text: Madam President, no one can rejoice in the failure of the Madrid COP, which also means the failure of the Paris COP, since the desired trajectory will not be kept and we are moving away from the desired objectives. I call on Parliament and the Commission to reflect on the reasons for these failures. The great globalist machinery no longer works, the unbearable pretension to hold a monopoly on the good and to impose universal solutions to do the good of peoples without them, or even against them, no longer works. That is why we must face our contradictions. We cannot continue to sign free trade treaties while deploring the consequences. We cannot continue to adhere to a financial economy, while regretting the damage created around the world by the extinction of biodiversity and human diversity. I therefore believe that more modesty, more solutions close to the ground, more efforts controlled as close as possible to SMEs, which make the economy of our territories, this is probably what the European Union can do best to combat ecological disruptions.

name: Πέτρος Κόκκαλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as a member of our delegation in Madrid, I witnessed the failure of the international community's attempt to reach an agreement. I witnessed the anguish of 500,000 young people on the streets of Madrid, who demanded immediate and effective measures. I have witnessed the anguish of the small Pacific island states that are literally sinking. I also witnessed the failure of Chile's neoliberal "runaway government" to lead the process. Witness the deadly inaction of dark far-right governments forming a new black International in the face of our effort to prevent climate disaster. I also witnessed the European Commission's agonizing attempt to defend the environmental and political integrity of the Paris Agreement.  Ladies and gentlemen, if there is one thing I learned in Madrid, it is that we have a duty to lead the fight for a human world with climate justice and climate security. We must lead by our own example, by implementing the Green Agreement on climate neutrality in our own home. It is our duty to young people and to the whole world. Rendezvous in Glasgow!

name: Maria da Graça Carvalho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, COP25 did not go as it would have been desired. Concrete commitments were expected in Madrid, but issues such as Article 6 of the Paris Agreement on carbon markets were still open. In any case, I do not believe that this summit was in vain. The situation of the oceans has been addressed for the first time, a greater impact of climate change on women has been recognised, the important role of science in the challenges that await us has been discussed. And this was a COP very much participated by civil society, as I could see in Madrid: by the young people, who were present in numbers never before seen at these summits, but also by the older ones. This is a sign of hope to be withdrawn from Madrid. Climate action is not only done through measures approved by governments. It requires the mobilisation of the whole society and society is clearly committed to these battles. It is up to us politicians to recognize and value this motivation.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We are facing humanitarian disasters and we will certainly not be able to achieve the UN's sustainability goals unless we act more, and now. Climate change requires action at all levels, both in the public and private sectors. Today, for example, 100 of the world's large companies account for 71% of total greenhouse gas emissions. The climate is not a matter of perhaps, as some would argue. Climate change is already affecting us today, but requires urgent action to be kept below the 1.5 degree increase. Especially in the talks with the smaller nations, such as the Maldives, at COP25 in Madrid last week, it became even clearer to me how urgent the situation is. Maldives is protected and exists right now because of its coral reefs. However, the coral reefs are disappearing due to the increase in heat in the water.  Climate change also hits developing countries hardest, while at the same time having the least resources to cope with a changing climate, and despite the fact that many of these countries emit much smaller amounts of CO2 than other countries. It is clear that efforts to eradicate poverty, preserve the planet, create sustainable economic growth for all and promote social inclusion are strongly linked.  COP25 may have failed, but I am proud of us here in Parliament, of the Commission, led by Mr Timmermans, and of the Finnish Presidency for pushing the EU Member States to take the lead in a climate-neutral Europe by 2050. But now it is up to both the EU and the Member States to move from words to deeds.

name: Caroline Voaden (Renew).
text: – Madam President, 2019 is coming to an end, another year of record wildfires, floods, droughts and livelihoods destroyed under our watch. Another year of discussions on measures to stop climate change. Yet the COP25 failed to deliver on international trading rules. But we also failed to deliver on adaptation, on loss and damage, on reaching agreements to reduce vulnerability and increase resilience against the future natural disasters that the world will face. Discussing the outcomes of the COP25, let’s not lose focus on what’s at stake here. Let’s not forget who will suffer at the hands of climate change. According to the 2019 Climate Change Performance Index, there is today no country on earth that is heading towards the 1.5° target.  We as Brits are devastated that we will not be able to play our full part in driving forward stricter green targets within the European Union, as we will no longer sit at the table. During the COP25, the gap between the reality of our climate emergency and the pace of negotiations has been clear. The time for talking is over. I urge you now, as Members of the European Parliament and Union, to be a strong and ambitious voice in all future negotiations.

name: Ville Niinistö (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think that the failures of Madrid give more light to the obvious prospect ahead of us that 2020 will be the crucial year for climate. That is the last year and the last COP when we actually still have a chance of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees, or even close to that.  However, I also think that there are some positives to take from the failures. There is more legitimacy in either making a good deal or no deal at all. There was a bad deal on the table and I applaud the Commission and the Presidency that you didn’t take that, because it would make it totally, utterly useless to have these COPs if we just give more room to those who just want to use climate for their business opportunities, get credits for free and not support climate legitimacy. So it’s good that we have brought the system to the brink of failure where all countries have to realise that we have to do more, that we have to deliver a good deal and that no facade is going to be enough. And this is the project for the European Union for next year. We need to deliver on the Green Deal at home and build on the alliances that we have with those countries that want to do more before the Glasgow meeting. Then we can succeed.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what was supposed to be the most ambitious UN climate change conference ever ended in a resounding failure.  No compromise was found on Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, which provides for global regulation of the carbon market, and large polluting countries such as India, China and the United States have reiterated their no to reducing greenhouse gases.  A well-deserved slap in the face for Europe and its slogans on climate change which not only do nothing but harm European companies, which are forced to face competition from the large polluting countries, which do not want to undertake the energy transition desired by Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, the failure of the UN Climate Change Conference will not be the only one, but many others will follow. Our companies and businesses do not compare with Greta, but face unfair competition from China, the United States and India. So, ladies and gentlemen, it must not be just us, we must involve everyone, otherwise it will be a continuous failure.

name: Silvia Modig (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Madrid was disappointing and expectations for Glasgow are even higher. In order to reach the necessary decisions there, the EU must lead by example and take genuine leadership. Article 6 is extremely important and it is good that the EU did not accept the watered-down conditions. Agreement must be reached on the calculation and reporting rules so that double counting is not possible and that both environmental objectives and social justice are safeguarded.  Now we must clearly communicate to all our partners the need for a change of direction. We must use all means, including trade policy. In order to agree at the next meeting to adequately tighten up the states' commitments for 2030, we must begin by raising our hard target. We must make it clear to our trading partners that we will not give an unfair competitive advantage to those who do not take responsibility, but will, if necessary, create a carbon tariff at the EU border, and that we will come from the trade agreement to demand stricter environmental regulations and start with Mercosur.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, those of us who participated in the Madrid Conference not only experienced a missed opportunity but also faced with a powerful picture of the difficulties facing the implementation of the Paris Agreement. As the European Union, we have and are trying to maintain the lead in tackling climate change by changing our economy through the Green Agreement and aiming to create new and good jobs. Only the Green Agreement must give particular support to the countries and regions leading the way in coal detoxification, such as Greece, which wants to have the old plants withdrawn by 2023 and excluded coal from its energy mix by 2028.  The speed of the discharge of European economies from coal must be a key criterion for providing support for the transition. The world sees us, as you say Vice-President Timmermans, and we must mobilise all countries to assume their responsibilities - rewarding the pioneers.

name: Sándor Rónai (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We are the last generation who can still do something about climate change and climate catastrophe. We only have time for that, and all we have left is to find solutions to the consequences of the climate catastrophe. The leaders of the Union, the politicians of the Union, know that delay is not possible, we must act immediately. A lot of people say that, but America, India and China – well, I'm a prouder European than that. Europe will set an example, and Europe will lead the fight against climate change to success.  Let us not forget that we all have a shared responsibility to succeed in this challenge. The European Green Agreement can be successful if it acts as a new social contract, which is accepted by everyone and everyone feels theirs. We must draw strength to fight from the people, from the young people who are fighting climate change across Europe for their future. Policymakers, civilians, economic and industrial actors and all European citizens must fight together, and then we can succeed.

name: Fredrick Federley (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for There is no doubt that COP25 was a failure. But then you can handle it in different ways. One can deplore that failure and recharge for next year, when we still have the chance to do something. But then I hear some colleagues, especially on the right wing, pretending to be dissatisfied. But they are really incredibly happy, because this is what they have wanted all along. They want to stop the clocks. They do not want to be part of the transition to green society. And there is no doubt about my disdain for their kind of politics.  But if any of those right-wingers were in here listening to my speech, I would give them a chance to change their minds. That's because we're going to launch the Green Deal this year. You have the chance to support the political project towards a new economy, new jobs, new prospects. But now that we are debating the important climate issues and when we are going to debate the Green Deal, you will not be constructive, you will not be here to contribute. So be honest and tell me that you are happy about this livelihood and meet the voters who take up the streets across the world, look them in the eye and say, "We don't care."

name: Michael Bloss (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The year 2019 is the year of the climate movement. All over the world, people have risen up against the destruction of our planet, and we here in the house, we have declared the climate emergency. This year, of all places, the climate conference is failing. What a disgrace!  But many people, who are already one step further: they are developing the technology of the decarbonized world of tomorrow, they are taking to the streets on Fridays for the climate, and they are waiting for the cumbersome politics.  Next year, politics will have to follow suit, which means, Mr Timmermans, to say at the beginning of the year how much climate ambition you really want. This means presenting a real climate change law so that the next climate conference in Glasgow in a year's time will be a success. In 2020, the climate is all about it. Mr Timmermans, do not disappoint the people in this climate year 2020!

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen (ID).
text: – Mr President, Minister Tuppurainen, the climate conference in Madrid, which was expected with great hopes, ended in a complete stomach drop. Of course, hotels in Madrid got a boost when 27,000 people travelled to the meeting. In the run-up to the meeting, attention was drawn to an attention-seeking Swedish school student who should be in school and had to travel in the first class of a German train. Actually, there was nothing else to report on the meeting. In Fact, the government, which has been pushed into the climate in Finland, is using every opportunity to punish citizens with additional taxes, using the climate as a pretext. It also emerged that the EU intends to spend EUR 100 billion on climate funding for developing countries. They're going in the pots of poppers. I think the meeting bed up to the consultants' accounting day, not the citizens.

name: Manuel Bompard (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, let us not be afraid of words: despite the pressure of young people around the world, COP25 is a fiasco. I hear here that we would have done the right thing, but the others are irresponsible. It's too easy. First, because our own objectives are insufficient. To meet the 1.5oC target included in the Paris Agreements, we must reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by at least 65% by 2030. And we must set this goal as soon as possible, without waiting for COP26, to lead by example and to have a ripple effect. Secondly, because we continue to forge trade agreements with those whose inaction we denounce here. Because who refuses to raise their goals? The United States, Canada, Japan, Brazil, among others. But who signed a free trade agreement with Japan, with Canada? Who prepares one with Mercosur or the United States? It's you; it is the European Commission. In short, let us not be hypocritical, let us finally put our words and actions in line: it is the future of our ecosystem that we have in our hands.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I join my colleagues in pointing out that the outcome of the Madrid conference was not a success. Unfortunately, contrary to expectations, countries have failed to find agreement on the rules for creating a global carbon trading system and for directing new funds to countries facing the effects of climate change. I would like to thank the Commissioner for their being able to defend the Paris Agreement, when the states agreed in Paris in 2015 to revise their climate commitments by 2020. However, countries such as China, India, Brazil opposed more ambitious commitments, pointing out that this should now be each country's decision, and that if stronger wordings are to be adopted to increase ambition, it will only be if rich countries provide them with adequate financial support.  The European Union has rejected different approaches to rich and developing countries, saying that future ambitions under the Paris Agreement, which applies to all countries, should be addressed. I consider this decision to be the right one.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, since the signing of the Paris Agreement in 2015, successive climate summits, including COP25, have frustrated expectations and been unable to respond to an increasingly active and intervening civil society, asking policymakers for more action and ambition. The European Union responded to the call of civil society by presenting the European Ecological Pact last week. It was with this commitment that Ursula von der Leyen and Frans Timmermans made the will in Madrid the desire to transform the European Ecological Pact into a global ecological pact. We didn't talk to each other, but we had fewer followers than we needed.  Only 84 countries have pledged to submit more ambitious plans in 2020, following the call by UN Secretary-General António Guterres. Particularly unsatisfactory was the lack of agreement on Article 6 on carbon markets, whose trading stalled a year ago in Katowice, and which was once again not possible to unlock in Madrid. This is not a time to give up, but to fight for example, especially for the example of concrete actions. Therefore, actions should be financed in a cross-cutting and fair manner. After this summit, the application of the carbon tax is more urgent than ever.

name: Marie Toussaint (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, history will remember that we were schizophrenic. In the morning we were talking about climate and tonight we are about to adopt a list of so-called community interest projects, which will confirm for several decades the Union's dependence on fossil fuels. This is in total contradiction with the ecological emergency. At COP25, representatives of the Tuvalu Islands alerted us, saying that denying the millions of victims of global warming was a crime. It's time to be consistent. The failure of COP25 further reinforces the European Union's historical responsibility. We must affirm that the laws of the economy are not superior to the laws of nature. We must stop seeing our Earth as something to dominate, rape and exploit with impunity. We must recognize, condemn the crimes of ecocides, we must guarantee environmental justice. Our weight in the world is such that the climate will not be saved without us. After the terrible failure of COP25, Europe must lead the way.

name: Michal Wiezik (PPE).
text: – Madam President, yes, we can conclude that COP25 ended in failure, people's expectations were not met and disappointment occurred. Still, I'd like to grasp it from that positive ending. COP25 failed, not the European Union. We have come up with an ambitious Green Deal plan and it is already visible how it inspires many countries in the world. Our job is to prove that a planet-compatible economy is possible and essentially necessary. I am proud to be part of the European Union, which is openly committed to climate neutrality, biodiversity protection, green policy and which is looking for active solutions. We are the first in the world to follow this path, and I know that our success will be a success for all. If we are successful, everyone will join us in the end. There will surely be more of them on the next COP.

name: Liudas Mažylis (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Mr. Prime Minister. In Madrid, it was found that there is an urgent need for new commitments on climate change. But that's probably all positive. The overall results at the conference are rather disappointing. In any case, science has undeniably proven what the factors are of climate change. However, the political will in different regions of the world, as we can see, is different. There is no agreement on a system for channelling new funds for countries affected by climate change. There is also disagreement about the deadline itself: ambition. For us in Europe, today this already means the specific legal, financial and implementation aspects of the Green Course. That is also the ambition to reduce carbon emissions by at least half as compared to 1990 levels by 2030. This is how we consistently strive for climate neutrality in 2050. Europe has therefore taken strong leadership and we must maintain it. Use future for a to discuss with other global players and continue to move towards the objectives of the Paris Agreement, and most importantly to respond to the expectations of European and global citizens.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, and in the documents issued by the Commission, and in Parliament's position, it is required that all measures be taken on the basis of impact studies. I would like the introduction into the ETS of maritime transport, as well as the 75% transfer rate from road, river and rail, as you have proposed, and the transition from 40% to 50% in 2030 to be taken on the basis of sound impact studies. There should also be coordination between you and all Directorates-General for taking these measures, do something to have global agreements, in particular to urgent CORSIA for aviation and try something for maritime transport. I would like to ask you, is the investment plan you propose in your document based on new money or the transfer of other budget lines?

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: This brings us to the spontaneous speeches.  I'm not going to be able to take everyone on top of it. But I try to distribute it among the groups in such a way that we are reasonably balanced. Spontaneous speeches

name: Ljudmila Novak (PPE).
text: – Madam President, was the Madrid conference really in vain? We have heard a great disappointment here that the desired success has not been achieved. And yet I do not think the conference is in vain. Sometimes to those of us who have children, it seems like they don't hear us say what they're saying, and yet once, somewhere, that talk is familiar to their behavior. I am thus convinced that the European Union must not give up, but must continue its path, implement the Green Agreement and demonstrate that these measures are feasible in order to achieve climate action. The countries that pollute the air are also the biggest problems, and the situation will force them to take urgent action, perhaps very late. Europe must set an example.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it’s a tragedy that 30 governments failed to reach an agreement on carbon markets at COP 25. It’s a tragedy for small island developing states, for indigenous people, for young people. It’s a tragedy for the natural world. Yet there is consensus that we need an energy transition, as well as nature-based solutions with a focus on oceans and forests, to balance our global climate. COP25 was a historic opportunity for collective action on the key issue of our time. The Climate Emergency will not go away: it will become more lethal. And whilst I welcome the Green Deal proposed by the Commission, I know that if we really want to address the twin crises of climate change and poverty, we must be honest about the failure of neoliberal austerity policies.  The Green New Deal proposed by DiEM25 is a far more holistic and realistic plan, which recognises the links between the climate emergency, poverty and migration. Millions of young people all over the world are fighting for our planet. They’re declaring we have one home, we share it and we must protect it.

name: Billy Kelleher (Renew).
text: – Madam President, firstly I want to welcome the Commission’s Green Deal and the announcement last week. I think it’s important that we, as a European Union, show leadership in a global context. There is no doubt that there are a lot of climate deniers out there. We look at President Trump, we look at Brazil, we look at many other countries which simply do not accept that there is a global crisis in our midst at the moment. So from that context, while COP was a failure in terms of actually bringing forward a meaningful policy, it does highlight the fact that there are many countries out there which simply will continue to jeopardise the climate for economic gain alone, without taking a holistic approach.  I would urge that we would look at it from an economic point of view and an environmental point of view. We also need to enhance our diplomatic efforts, as a European Union, across the globe to encourage countries in the context of the next COP to be serious about bringing forward tangible proposals that will actually have a meaningful impact on how we transition to a carbon neutral world and save the planet.

name: Ellie Chowns (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, as a British Green I have experienced two significant disappointments in the last few days: first of all, the result of the British general election and, secondly, the failure of COP25 to make sufficient progress. That is an especially bitter disappointment because of the unprecedented green wave of protests that we’ve seen over the last year calling for unity around the science, and those citizens are disappointed. As Mr Timmermans said, our task is now more urgent than ever and we in Europe have a particular historic responsibility. I am actually tired of hearing excuses from other Members of this House about the responsibilities of China and so forth. We owe a carbon debt to low-income countries, in particular, for the loss and damage caused by climate change. We need to put our own house in order; we cannot keep kicking that can down the road.  Now my country, the UK, is hosting COP26 next year and I have a message to Boris Johnson, our new Prime Minister: ‘The world is watching. Will you sell out climate change with a race to the bottom trade deal with Trump or will you step up?’ The world is watching, not waiting. We will continue to mobilise until action matches the urgency of the climate crisis.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it has been four years since the Paris Agreement. Several climate emergency proclamations have been made since then. From the point of view of a concrete reduction of greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere, the practical effect of the agreement was nil. Concrete reduction targets consistent with the objectives set in Paris have not yet been set. It is certain that, often, the proclaimed objectives give shelter to other objectives, perhaps less noble, less mobilizing. Just watch the parade of the multinationals that sponsored the Madrid conference. As or more important than the objectives are the means, the instruments defined to achieve them. They tell us a lot about the interests that lead certain processes. Perhaps not by chance, one of these instruments, the carbon market, was at the heart of the discussion in Madrid, and triggered contradictions that made the agreement unfeasible. Now, the monetization of carbon, the purchase and sale of the right to pollute the atmosphere serves undisguised interests, does not serve the interests of the peoples, nor genuine environmental objectives.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, one thing I’m pleased about is that we are calling COP25 what it was: a failure. There were times in the past where there were fudges, where there were statements saying that there was progress made, blah, blah, blah. Nothing really happened. At least now we are saying what it is and I congratulate Commissioner Timmermans and the others for so doing.  It also, of course, gives us an opportunity – and particularly the new Commission which cannot be blamed obviously for the failure last week – now to use the next 12 months to put pressure on the big emitters, those who are fudging and not living up to their commitments, to so do in 12 months’ time, and also to use our trading strength, especially in relation to future trade agreements; that countries will not be entertained if their products are not sustainable according to the promises and commitments they gave in Paris a few years ago. I think if we can do that we will send a message to the rest of the world, and hopefully this time next year, we’ll be talking about COP26, as the COP on COP.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me point out, first of all, the good organisation that Spain has carried out, and, ladies and gentlemen, let us see the good side of history. It is true that no agreement has been reached on the level of ambition we had of reduction commitments, in Article 6 on carbon markets, but there has been an impeccable role in leading the European Union, and that is why more than eighty countries have decided to increase their reduction commitments. We must also conclude the general framework that has been adopted: the European Green Pact; here's Vice President Timmermans who leads it. TheRefore, the European Union cannot, ladies and gentlemen, show weakness. We are the reference model for the rest of the world. We're not alone on this journey. More and more countries are following our model. And we need to fight and work to make Glasgow's next COP the success of the carbon markets, environmental taxation and the definitive and effective implementation of the Paris agreements.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it is very difficult to overstate the importance of COP26 in Glasgow next year. So what we should be doing, starting from today, is to prepare well, as the European Union, for that COP. This is a combination of doing the right things in Europe and, at the same time, being extremely active on the international scene in climate diplomacy. And these are not two different things. You cannot separate these two roles. You need to do the same thing, both at the same time. What are the concrete things we should do internally to prepare? First of all, we need to prepare our climate law so that we can show the rest of the world that we put into law our commitment to be climate neutral by 2050. To do that, we should also indicate clearly what we would be doing intermittently because 2050 is a long way from now, but 2030 isn’t. It’s almost tomorrow, it’s only 10 years, but we should be able to determine what we do in 2030.  To determine that precisely, we will do an impact assessment, but we need to do it in time so that we are timely in preparing our climate law and preparing the clear targets for 2030 so we can take that to the international conference. At the same time, we need to be rather quick in preparing a strategy that offers a future to our farming community with a From Farm to Fork strategy, which says clearly that we need our farmers more than before but in a different way. We should also look at ETS. Where can we improve the ETS system? What is it going to do on shipping? How are we going to apply it in the airline area? What are we doing with different sectors in our economy on ETS, etc., etc.? These things are urgent and we need to work on all these things at the same time. What are we going to do in our building environment? What are we going to do on biodiversity, which is intimately linked to this?  I am mentioning all these subjects because, when you look at a conference like COP, on the surface it looks to be about emissions, but emissions are part of a much broader spectrum. What we’re proposing in the Green Deal is to actually reset our economy. Our economy, our system, our welfare, our well—being depends almost fully today on carbon and we are dependent on that. We’re addicted to that. So we need to get rid of that addiction and we need to make sure that we can create the same level – or better levels – of well—being, welfare and prosperity without having to depend on carbon.  That is a paradigm shift of unprecedented proportion – and it can only happen if we convince other parts of the world to follow suit because I do agree with those who say that if we only do this in Europe, it’s only 9% of emissions and it will not have the effect we want on a global scale. But what is also true is that if we don’t do it in Europe, we will have no arguments to convince others. I experienced – and I hope colleagues had the same experience in Madrid – a lot of interest in many parts of the world for the European Green Deal and also a lot of interest in the idea of setting a target of being climate neutral in 2050.  The rest of the international community is waking up to the fact that this is a completely new way of looking at things. It is no longer believing, like we did many years ago, that by taking incremental steps, eventually we’ll get there. We’re turning things round. We’re saying this is where we need to be in 2050 and then we take steps back until today and then we can chart exactly what needs to be done until then.  Our proposal is not a blueprint, it’s a roadmap. It would give us the opportunity, also through a climate pact, to make sure that the people who are on the streets, the people who have a stake in this – whether it’s in industry or in agriculture or in academia or in trade unions – are part of the conversation and the decision—making. That’s what the climate pact will be.  So this is, I believe, what the European Union has to offer to the rest of the world and we do it for the next generations. We do it because it’s inevitable. We do it because not doing it would be relinquishing our duty in light of the facts that can no longer be disputed, and in light of what science is telling us. We do not have the luxury to sit on our hands. We do not have the luxury to ignore this. We have the duty to act.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I wish to thank you for this very useful and timely debate. It is indeed disappointing that after years of hard work, and especially during the last two weeks, we could not agree on Article 6, providing incentives to reduce emissions now, and especially in the future.  As I said, the EU showed both determination and flexibility in order to reach the best possible results, notably as regards ambition and Article 6.  However, it is very difficult to negotiate with parties which refuse to engage. Eventually, under these circumstances, our negotiators considered it safer to refrain from accepting a very bad deal on Article 6.  But at the same time we are happy that we managed to complete the second review of the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage. This enables us to enhance our capacity to mobilise and catalyse effective action for averting, minimising and addressing loss and damage associated with climate change targets. I also welcome the new Gender Action Plan. It strengthens gender considerations and women’s participation in climate action and highlights the important role of women as agents of change.  Dear friends, I’m sure this debate will contribute to informing a period of reflection in view of the forthcoming negotiations. I would especially like to thank Commissioner Timmermans for his passion and commitment to hard work. Next year, dear friends, must be the year of increasing ambition. It must be the year of hope and the year of a high—quality agreement.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – To say that the UN climate summit – COP25 was unlucky, that is not enough. It can be summarised briefly: disagreement. There was no agreement on areas such as emissions trading, a common timeframe, common air quality metrics, reporting, ambitions and climate targets. We have only been able to establish that we have a climate crisis and we need to act. It's really revealing. Commissioner Timmermans aims to increase the EU's reduction target for 2030 from 40% to 50%, while aiming to increase it to 55% responsibly. What is Poland doing at the time? The government is announcing the success of the summit because no one has told us to move away from coal. Published in November, the energy policy Polish until 2040 – assumes that coal will still have between 56% and 60% of electricity generation in 2030. As Orlando A. Battista once said, "a mistake doesn't become a mistake until you refuse to correct it," so let's stop using nature as a credit card without a limit. It is time for decisive action, and the recent Madrid Summit shows that not everyone is aware of the seriousness of the situation.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent I am a Member from Silesia, from Rybnik. In my city, air pollution levels can exceed standards by 1,000 percent for several months of the year. In Poland, 44,000 people die prematurely due to air pollution. It's as if every year the city bigger than Mikołów disappears from its map. Scientific studies conducted by the Department of Pediatrics and the Department of Pediatric Neurosurgery in Katowice show a close correlation between breathing smog and higher than average incidence of central nervous system tumors in children. These are undeniable and frightening facts.  I would therefore like to express my deep disappointment at the results of the Madrid Climate Summit, or rather the lack of these results. The lack of agreement means that all countries will have to re-develop their climate concepts. So we go back to the starting point, we delay decisions in time, and let's be clear, we don't have that time anymore!  I hope that the European Commission, when preparing the Union's position for the next climate conference in Glasgow, will continue to act ambitiously and uncompromisingly, because I have no doubts about Parliament. We feel responsibility on our shoulders for the future of the planet and future generations. I therefore strongly urge all the institutions of the Union and governments to understand the seriousness of the situation, to agree on divisions and to cooperate intensively on a New Green Deal for Europe.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, I am shocked by the growing gap between reality and the necessary measures and political commitments. Madrid did not achieve what would be needed to combat climate change or even adequate mitigation. COP25 demonstrates the current incompetence of politics. We are in a hurry because the drastic de environmental de faction does not wait. On the positive side, we know the challenge, we have the technology, resources and money for a sustainable lifestyle. Now even greater responsibility falls on companies, circular economy means and sustainable financing. The Green Deal is an important initiative that is expected for the EU to take responsibility for combating climate change, both internally and globally. The most significant proposals are the Climate Act, the updating of existing climate legislation, carbon emissions, the next stage of the circular economy, and sustainable food and buildings. The degradation of biodiversity, which was too much overshadowed, was also highlighted as part of the Green Deal. Political leadership is the RESPONSIBILITY of the EU. This will mean much higher ambition in the EU's climate policy. We must multiply our efforts if we are to meet the challenge of climate change. The further we postpone the solution, the faster and more drastic measures are needed and the greater the cost of harm.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU's pollinator initiative (2019/2803(RSP)).  First of all, I would like to remind you that you have the opportunity, both in the usual and electronic way, to register your spontaneous speech or even the blue card.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, pollinators are fundamental for the conservation of biodiversity and for life on Earth. They are essential for food production and human livelihoods. They are key to supporting our ecosystems. Pollinators are also important for the economy. Their impact is particularly visible in food production. Almost EUR 15 billion of the EU’s annual agricultural output is directly attributed to insect pollinators. For many crops, the contribution of pollinators can amount to half of the market value of the produce. Over the past decades, the number and diversity of pollinators have seriously declined in Europe as well as globally. Many of them are threatened with extinction. This situation is unsustainable. The functioning of our ecosystem and human well-being are at risk. Many different drivers contribute to the decline of pollinators and they are all linked to human activity. Much pollinator habitat has been lost to agriculture, resource extraction and new urban and suburban development. Non-native species take away the natural habitat of the pollinators and unfamiliar parasites and diseases can severely compromise whole colonies of bees.  Intensive farming and the use of harmful pesticides are another big threat for pollinators, destroying their habitat and taking away the diversity of the plants they usually forage on. Climate change and temperature changes also have disruptive effects on pollination. I agree with you that we need effective measures in the EU to address the root causes of pollinators’ decline. The Commission took an important first step in this direction by adopting in June last year an EU initiative especially focusing on pollinators. The Council welcomes this initiative, which seeks to address the problem in an integrated way and to use existing tools and policies more effectively. Like this Parliament, the Council is of the view that in order to tackle the loss of pollinators, more research is needed to address knowledge gaps and to clearly understand the causes and the consequences of the decline. Pollinator species and populations in the EU also need to be better monitored to better understand their status and trends. Only with scientific knowledge and a full understanding of the problem can we address it effectively. It is also important to raise public awareness about pollinators and their importance for healthy ecosystems and for our well-being. Parliament is right in stressing the need to engage citizens, beekeepers and farmers to contribute to pollinator conservation and industry, citizens and governments at all levels have to join efforts.  International cooperation is another important aspect. The Conference of the Parties to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity agreed on a plan of action for 2018 to 2030 for the conservation and sustainable use of pollinators. In the action plan stakeholders, including farmers, are encouraged to adapt pollinator-friendly practices and address direct and indirect drivers of pollinator decline.  Our Member States are active in raising the problem of pollinators’ decline in the international community. Eleven Member States have joined the Coalition of the Willing on Pollinators established in 2016 at the 13th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity in Cancún. The members of the Coalition committed to take action and to work together on pollinators and to share their knowledge and the best practices to encourage other countries to take measures in this respect. Last month the Coalition proposed to have a specific target, an indicator for pollinators and pollination, in the Post-2020 Global Biodiversity Framework.  Perhaps the most important and urgent of the priority actions identified by the Commission in the EU pollinators initiative is to tackle the causes of pollinator decline. The EU has already put in place a range of measures, such as the protection of natural habitats through the EU’s nature legislation, support for beekeeping and restrictions on the use of pesticides harmful to bees.  The EU Natura 2000 network of protected areas provides many habitats of vital importance for pollinators, yet these measures have not been sufficient. Measures have also been taken to promote pollinator-friendly solutions in agriculture and to support biodiversity in the reformed common agricultural policy for the years 2014 to 2020.  All these developments are positive. But, despite the action taken so far, the decline of pollinators has not stopped. The Intergovernmental Science—Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services ‘Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services’ released in May this year provides a grim picture. The global decline of biodiversity at unprecedented rates in human history is, to a large extent, caused by the loss of pollinators which are the very basis of habitats and ecosystems. To conclude, it is clear that we have not done enough and more efforts are needed to halt the decline of pollinators and maintain and restore their habitats. The Council therefore calls for rapid and effective implementation of the existing measures by the EU and the Member States to address the loss of biodiversity. The Council also welcomes the European Green Deal adopted by the Commission last week. We also look forward to the publication of the Commission’s biodiversity strategy for 2030 with ambitious targets for biodiversity, which we will examine with great interest as soon as it’s available.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’m addressing this point on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Sinkevičius. The decline of wild pollinators in the European Union is, as you have said, dramatic. The functioning of ecosystems, our food security and well-being are at risk. As we all know, this problem has vividly captured public attention. In 2016 the European Parliament called on the Commission and Member States to act urgently on this problem. In 2018 the Commission adopted the first ever European Union initiative on pollinators, building on European research projects and following a broad public consultation. This initiative sets long-term objectives and short-term actions, providing the necessary framework to consolidate efforts across sectors and to provide a more effective response of the European Union and its Member States. The scope is comprehensive: more than 30 actions aimed to strengthen our understanding of the problem, tackle the main drivers and engage actors across the board. Main threats to pollinators are well known. The initiative addresses directly the loss of pollinator habitats and the use of pesticides, particularly in the context of agriculture. It also addresses directly the threat from invasive alien species. The already existing and future European Union actions on research, climate change and pollution will also be critical for the protection of pollinators.  Agriculture is the key sector. It does depend on pollinators but also exerts a strong pressure on them, whether through intensification of agricultural practices or abandonment of high nature value farmland. Our common agricultural policy is essential to turn these challenges into opportunities. The role of Member States is critical. The future common agricultural policy, in particular, offers them a significant opportunity to improve and scale-up their actions on pollinators.  As announced in the European Green Deal, and while we are still waiting for the adoption of the new CAP, the Commission will work with Member States to ensure that strategic plans are assessed according to robust and environmental criteria and lead to more sustainable practices.  These include precision agriculture, organic farming, agroecology, and ensuring that these plans work towards the goal of stopping the loss of pollinators.  The Commission is currently developing a common European Union monitoring scheme for pollinator species in close cooperation with Member States. The scheme will mobilise scientists, citizens and practitioners to generate data necessary to build robust policy indicators on the status and the trends of the pollinator species. This will ensure that we have the necessary knowledge to assess the effects of our policies, including the common agricultural policy, on the diversity and the abundance of pollinators. The responsibility to duly deploy the monitoring scheme on the ground lies with Member States. The Commission will coordinate and provide the necessary support, including through the future Life programme and, of course, Horizon Europe. The European Union pollinators initiative is also developing monitoring processes for pressures on pollinators, including pesticides. This will support research on the causes of pollinator declines and better understanding on how to effectively tackle them.  The initiative aims to reduce the impact of pesticides on pollinators by: strengthening the risk assessment; banning all outdoor uses of the three neonicotinoids restricted in 2013; and supporting Member States to ensure the sustainable use of pesticides, in particular through integrated pest management. In the European Green Deal, the Commission announced an increased level of ambition to tackle the causes of biodiversity loss, including by reducing significantly the use and the risk of chemical pesticides, as well as the use of fertilisers, and restoring damaged ecosystems.  The Commission will identify the measures, including legislative measures, needed to bring about these reductions.  And finally, the biodiversity strategy for 2030 and the Farm to Fork strategy to be delivered in the spring of 2020 will provide strong frameworks for the European Union pollinators’ initiative and help us to reach our goal of stopping the loss of pollinators.

name: Mairead McGuinness
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, thank you both to the Minister and to the Commission for their opening statements. I think there is no disagreement on what both of you have said to the House here. We have a very serious problem. I’m sadly old enough to remember a time when I would go out as a child into the fields and be able to collect bees, all sorts of varieties of bees, look at them in a jar and release them. And I think there are many children today who just wouldn’t know that that ever happened and would not be aware of the biodiversity that existed. So we do have a serious problem and I’m happy that this resolution takes hold of this issue and points a way forward.  So rather than repeat all the reasons why we have a problem, let me just talk about two issues which have been raised here. One is the new Farm to Fork Strategy.
