This is a new element and a very important one, and maybe you will be surprised when I throw in competition law with biodiversity, but there is a link here and we need to understand how competition law is impacting in a negative way on biodiversity, and I ask you to do that.  The second issue I raise is about trade deals. We have to ensure that what we practice internally, where we restrict the use of risky pesticides and those that are damaging, is practiced outside of the European Union on food that we import. We haven’t done that in the past and we need to do it now. I want to thank the groups. We’ve worked well and we’ve worked hard on this resolution, because we all have a common aim to not just preserve what we have but to restore nature and to make sure that there is space for nature in all of our places, urban and rural, and gardeners and farmers all have an important role to play.

name: István Ujhelyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support For me, as S&D's theme manager, it was a great experience to learn and understand why pollinators matter. Did you, you know, that a single bee colony dusts 300 million flowers in a single day? Do you know, did you know that bees and pollinators give us one in three bites of food we eat, because 90 percent of food crops and wild plants breed by pollinating insects? And do you know that, as far as agricultural activities in the European Union are concerned, 84% of crop species and 76% of European food production depend on pollination by insects, which is around EUR 15 billion, which we owe them? And did you know, you know, that since 1970, half of all insects have died out because of the destruction of nature and the use of pesticides, and 40 percent of the one million identified insect species are threatened with extinction? Now, dear colleagues, when you are asked at home by the children or journalists at home why you are dealing with such issues in the European Union, you say these things, tell them. This is why it is important, for example, to identify the causes of pollinators' demise because of climate change, diseases, the spread of parasites, chemicals used by large-scale agriculture, or even the expansion and lifestyle of large cities, and find solutions together. Hungary is particularly exciting from the point of view of the european union, because we Hungarians, for example, imported the most honey from the EU Member States last year. Here, too, the issue is relevant. This is what the European Green Agreement is all about for me, for example, and that is what this resolution is all about for me, and please support it. It's a useful job, and it's been a useful experience for me as a private citizen and as a father.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I have made a habit of echoing in plenary the questions, the questions of Europeans and Europeans: "We are running a disaster. It's time to react. The question is whether our policy makers have children and grandchildren." End of quote. Yes, we have children; yes, we have grandchildren. These few words are those of Agnes Beulens, who is a beekeeper in the Walloon Brabant and of whom 60% of the hives did not survive the winter. Calls like this, Commissioner, we receive dozens of them. We receive dozens of emails, petitions are raining down, and even a European Citizens' Initiative, which has just been registered by your Commission. It's a disaster, a real catastrophe looming. The extinction rate of pollinators today is between 100 and 1,000 times higher than normal; these are the UN figures. Four out of five plant species depend on this pollination, with fruits and vegetables in mind - we haven't talked about it yet. So it is our diet that we watch disappear with our bees, our butterflies, our beetles. The European initiative for pollinators, which you are presenting to us and which was initiated by your predecessor, Commissioner Vella, is a positive signal. I've been one of those who's been asking for it since 2016, but more needs to be done. The causes of this decline, they are known. So we have to act on each of them and right away. The disappearance of habitats, first, the habitats of pollinators: create obligations of nectar corridors between crops, for example. Pesticides: ban neonicotinoids, set obligations to reduce other most harmful substances and develop safer, non-chemical, of course, chemical alternatives for farmers. The same now applies to invasive species: environmental pollution, global warming, clear goals and obligations. In short, Commissioner, Mr President, more ambition and concrete measures now. And Parliament, our Parliament, will support you.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that we agree on the analysis: we are dealing with a silent disaster outside – 75% of the insects have disappeared in the last 20 years. But the question is: what follows from this? I am always surprised by the Green Deal, which says that we want to achieve the objectives, but we do not want to change anything in agricultural policy. That will not work. We need to change this common agricultural policy. We need more diversity in the field, we need to do more for organic farming, we need to use fewer pesticides, but also less nitrogen. All this is necessary, and that is why it annoys me that the Green Deal has disappeared a clear target for the reduction or restriction of pesticides.  And that is why I find it incomprehensible why several neonicotinoids are still allowed, why we are now getting a new discussion on glyphosate. None of this is part of agricultural practice any more. These are things from yesterday that we cannot work with in the future if we really want to achieve something.  I am also annoyed that, on the one hand, we are banning neonicotinoids and making Member States exceptional, as Belgium announced yesterday to allow neonicotinoids in sugar beet. We will not be able to afford that in the future either. We must also reflect on the fact that we have a stricter authorisation regime for pesticides. Here, too, a number of things need to change so that we do not make mistakes, as with many other things, that we take pesticides off the market after years that should never have been put on the market.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, bees, butterflies and other pollinators are essential vectors of biodiversity. It is therefore worrying that their survival is threatened. On 11 October 2019, the International Union for Conservation of Nature issued an urgent call for action and I believe it must be listened to. The European Union must step up its participation in this pollinator rescue mission. Of course, the EU has already decided in April 2018 to ban the field use of neonicotinoids, which are the most harmful pesticides. But too many exemptions have been allowed, as the European Food Safety Authority has revealed. It needs to be addressed. More generally, the development of the new Common Agricultural Policy should be used to encourage states to safeguard pollinators as part of their strategic plans. This is also in the economic interest of farmers, as 76% of European food production depends on insect pollination, which represents an estimated value of EUR 15 billion. Finally, we must fight more firmly against the importation of adulterated honey, especially from China, in order to protect European beekeepers and thus create economic conditions conducive to the growth of our bee population.

name: Pietro Fiocchi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe very much in defending pollinators because, in my opinion, they are the most powerful instrument we have for safeguarding the biodiversity of our country and our Europe. It is essential, however – and I ask our fellow Members, since we will be voting on several amendments tomorrow – that this resolution should not be used for ideological purposes of the generic fight against pesticides, but should become an operational detailed instrument for the protection of pollinators. We know from EFSA's data that there are, we have already identified some pesticides that need to be removed from the middle because they cause chronic conditions in our pollinators, so we need to act in detail and scientifically in this direction.  I would like to add another thing: that there are not only pesticides – as so many of my colleagues have already mentioned – but there is a very precise threat that is advancing from the south of Italy, because we already have it in Sicily, in Calabria and it is coming north in a really worrying way, and it is the Aethina tumida, which is an invasive species that is destroying all our hives. I therefore specifically ask on this issue that there should be an operational plan by the Commission to stop it before it is too late.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, I am very happy that we are completing one of the great rests of the last parliamentary term with this point and this debate. However, the Commission's initiative presented does not sufficiently address the main causes of the decline of pollinators and, as such, should have been rejected and criticised long ago, I apologise, Commissioner. Instead of reducing the use of pesticides in their fields, Member States are now in a daily state of disassive new and new permits and applications for authorisation of more and more substances that are destroying our bees and pollinators. Given that the current activity is going nowhere, and this seems to be directly due to the inappropriate regulation and setting of the current agricultural policy, the new one needs to be in line with the need to protect these vital organisms more. How far are we, colleagues, able to make up for it? On the one hand, we hear constant excuses for limiting chemistry in the fields, on the other hand, the declines in biodiversity are terrible. It is necessary to remember that there is no substitute for pollinators, and grab a little by the nose. Perhaps this resolution will also help to improve the situation, but we are finally expecting concrete action from you, dear Commission.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all saying this: bees and pollinators play a fundamental role in the reproduction of plants, in maintaining biodiversity, in our agriculture in general. Yet, despite the fact that European crops depend on pollination, we are not doing enough to protect them and allowing the indiscriminate use of pesticides, which are one of the main threats to bees and other pollinators.  The CAP, it has been mentioned, the common agricultural policy has an enormous responsibility for the protection of pollinators and should absolutely commit itself to drastically reducing the use of pesticides, promoting crop rotation and abandoning intensive farming practices. With this resolution, we are calling on the Member States finally to introduce binding targets for reducing pesticides. I would add that It seems to me important today, absolutely necessary, to invest more in research funds, to invest in research for pollinators and to ensure that farmers are properly trained on how to promote and protect biodiversity and pollinators themselves.  I hope that the European Commission will follow up the European Green Deal with a concrete commitment to sustainable agriculture without pesticides, without being misrewarded by those who still want to defend intensive agriculture that is no longer sustainable today.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Madam Minister, Commissioner, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Bees are our favorite insects. Not only are they children's favourites in TV shows, but they above all ensure a functioning ecosystem. Three quarters of food production in Europe depends on pollination. Both honeybees and the approximately 600 wild bee species and other pollinating insects are therefore indispensable for our food security. That is why we are once again calling on the European Commission to present an effective, comprehensive and long-term strategy to improve bee health. This should include, in particular, incentives for more sustainable agriculture. This is particularly true in the use of plant protection products – by the way, Mr Häusling, also in the use of plant protection products in organic farming. Goals – or prohibitions – for the sake of the goal are not helpful at this point. I therefore welcome the impact assessment envisaged by the Commission before proposing a specific figure for reduction. This should also be, in my opinion, Parliament's position. Policy without impact assessment is contrary to the principle of better regulation. So I am counting on your support tomorrow.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his A sustainable society is measured very well by how well it protects its children and protects its bees. We therefore welcome the fact that the Commission has responded to the calls of the European Parliament and the Council to take an initiative for pollinators. Viable bees and pollinators are vital for us humans, for our food production and for our ecosystems. We know that these little animals play by far the most crucial role on our planet. It's really quite simple: without pollinators, no food. Three quarters of what is produced and ends up on our plates depends on viable pollinators. Taste it, for real, and feel! Three-quarters! These are enormous efforts that bees are making, and we must ensure that the bees are protected.  We will do everything we can: it is time we started the transition towards a non-toxic society, and it is important to be clear about that. Much of the reason why our ecosystems are damaged is because of the pesticides we use. The widespread use of pesticides is not sustainable. We need to change, so that it is both sustainable and non-toxic. In fact, we have rules in Europe – you know that, Commissioner – that are to counteract this trend. But they are not followed. I am thinking, for example, of the directive on the sustainable use of pesticides. We must ensure that the Member States comply with this directive.  I also think that we should – as we want from our side in the S&D Group – get a mandatory target of bringing down, and getting a percentage for how much we want to bring down, the use of pesticides. Another major problem is the neonicotinoids, and here too many Member States are violating the policies that exist and the legislation that exists, and I would urge the Commission to get tough.

name: Jan Huitema (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am committed to minimising emissions of plant protection products. Much has been done in this area in recent decades, but the vast majority of farmers in the Netherlands want to go even further. For example, there is even a sector plan to completely eliminate emissions of plant protection products by 2030. However, this will only have a chance of success if farmers are offered a good alternative to the protection of their crops. Whether intensive or extensive, organic or regular agriculture; every farmer wants to protect his crops, and with it his income. Failed harvests are tantamount to food waste and we simply cannot tolerate that anymore. I therefore believe that it is the responsibility of politics to offer farmers an alternative. In the past, for example, the use of plant protection products has been encouraged in the context of public policy. We need to encourage entrepreneurship among farmers and invest in integrated crop protection, low-risk resources and new frailing techniques to promote crop defence mechanisms. As a society, we are also responsible for bringing about this transition. Many young farmers in the Netherlands want to be more sustainable, but cannot take the extra costs out of the market.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, thank you. It is true that the situation of pollinating insects is really dramatic. More than 75% of insects have disappeared in 30 years in Germany, and 40% of insects worldwide are in decline: there is a real urgency. So the Commission's initiative is a very good thing, but it does not go far enough. And the parliamentarians wanted to amend it so that there are at least two measures that I think are very important on reducing pesticides. Firstly, the evaluation: it is essential that the full 2013 EFSA guidelines on the assessment of pesticides, on pollinators, and in particular the acute and chronic effects, be adopted. This affects both adults and larvae. And then we really have to ban waivers. In France, in 2016, there were 58 exemptions, especially for neonicotinoids, although it is forbidden, which is still allowed to be produced, sold and used. Waivers must be prohibited. And there is an urgent need, we really need to get effective and tangible results because, if pollinators disappear, a large part of the food chain will collapse.

name: Annika Bruna (ID).
text: Mr President, tomorrow Parliament will probably vote by a large majority to toughen the European initiative on pollinators. When we know that four out of five flowering plants need the help of these insects to produce seeds and fruits, we understand the threat that their decline poses not only to biodiversity and agriculture, but also to humanity. However, this mass disappearance and its consequences are not new. For example, Parliament is calling for scientific recommendations dating back to 2013 to be taken into account. In 2015, the proposal to reject a pesticide dangerous to bees was rejected by Parliament on the sectarian grounds that it was the initiative of my political family. Meanwhile, in France, in one winter, 30% of bees died due to lack of measures to protect them. In May 2019, the Commission again backed down from the agrochemical lobby, which is driving today's debate. We will support this text of Parliament. But what time wasted, and how much longer before the measures requested here are implemented?

name: Андрей Слабаков  (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I will speak as a normal person and not as a politician, because I am chosen by the civil quota and I want to tell you that I have some kind of selfishness about liking bees and beekeeping simply because I eat nothing sweet but honey. Here, however, the problem is not whether there will be honey, but whether humanity will survive, and I think this is something extremely important and such weak and pathetic resolutions should not be adopted, but problems must be radically addressed. I can't constantly be concerned with pesticides, as there are enough pesticides that are not harmful to bees. We just need to take a reasonable position and I think the position of the EQF and my friend , colleague Pietro Fioki, is extremely normal and reasonable. We just have to be normal. And please stop being MPs and politicians, just be reasonable people! It is in the interest of your children and your grandchildren.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the dramatic decline of pollinators, such as bees, bumblebees and butterflies, is characteristic of the way we deal with and destroy our environment. We know there is a problem, but we are doing far too little to solve it. As in the field of climate, scientific facts are called into question. Thanks to the lobby of the poison industry, we are being told that solutions are not feasible or not affordable. How stupid is that when we know that we are putting not only nature but also our own future at risk? The introduction of the Bee Directive to eradicate dangerous agricultural poison has been postponed for a further two years. What does the new Commissioner intend to do to speed up the process and how does it intend to ensure that neonics are no longer allowed in Member States? Every little bit helps: they are indispensable links in our nature. We need a radical greening of the city and the countryside. Get rid of the monoculture, get rid of pesticides and clean up the bee. Finally, I believe that agricultural subsidies must be stopped.

name: Ljudmila Novak (PPE).
text: – Mr President, you may know the letter from the Indian chief of Seattle, which he wrote in 1854 to George Washington, president of the United States of America, who wanted to buy back the land of the Indians and, of course, put them on the reservation. He wrote this way: Earth is our mother. Everything that happens to Earth will happen to its children.  Unfortunately, these forecasts are very much realising today. The world is taking big steps forward with new technologies, with new inventions, and we will also have to take a few steps back: back to nature, to respect for nature.  Pollinators are our invisible and very good collaborators. That's why they need all our concern. I am pleased with the proposals that we will be making with the adoption of these documents, and I am pleased that my country was the initiator of Bee Day two years ago, so that there is also an opportunity to raise awareness among the population.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Kyriakides, ladies and gentlemen, the state of health of bees is one of the most urgent alarm bells, in the face of which the Union must be at the forefront of tackling the causes of reducing pollinators.  Without bees, more than three quarters of the food that arrives on our tables would not exist, just giving an idea of how ambitious and no longer deferred choices are needed on our part and on the part of all Member States, in line with the European Food Safety Authority guidelines on bees of 2013. Bees are farmers' first allies, and European farmers recognise this fundamental role. In fact, in recent decades we have seen a collapse in the use of pesticides at higher risk, and thanks to cap greening measures, which have been, among other things, recently strengthened in the Omnibus regulation, we have promoted the use of honey plants and today in the Union more than 10 % of the arable land is dedicated to the protection of biodiversity. But we cannot stop there: European farmers must be encouraged to make a further qualitative leap forward in the provision of environmental services that protect the health of pollinators, for the benefit of the whole community. We need a coordinated, properly funded initiative focusing on research and innovation, giving Europe back its right to compete in this challenge. Otherwise, the risk is that we will find ourselves faced with a messy puzzle of national intervention. This Parliament, Commissioner, did not want and does not want to take this risk, but to live up to the ambitions of the European Green Deal.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Mr President, our future is not only threatened by the climate crisis, it is also threatened by the biodiversity crisis. We have reached breaking point and we have two options: we can continue to sit with our hands wrapped and watch it go downhill, or we can finally start acting properly. The massive decline of insects is not just a coincidence. This is the result of several serious factors. It is climate change, there are invasive species, but first of all there is agricultural policy and the further use of dangerous pesticides, which contribute to the decline of pollinators. How is it possible that we are funding from our taxes the activities that cause this. We need change, a change that will bring about an agricultural policy that will help protect biodiversity, bees, but will also help farmers in this endeavour, support for science, so that we have enough knowledge of where we have a problem, and a transparent and responsible Commission policy that listens to scientists and not just selectively selects what is appropriate. Citizens need action. They want a solution that governments and the Commission must bring to them, because without bees, without pollinators, there is no food, there are no farmers and there is no future.

name: Sarah Wiener (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We must finally banish harmful chemicals from our fields. We know that it does not only harm biodiversity, not only pollinators, but also field birds and our own health. More pesticides will end up being even more resistant and then more pesticides. That cannot be the solution! The current version of our resolution rightly states that plans to reduce pesticides are needed in each EU Member State. However, these should include clear objectives and timetables. We cannot afford any more well-meaning but inconsequential announcements. EU-wide binding reduction targets must be enshrined in law. This could happen, for example, in a sustainable CAP, which has not been mentioned to date. In addition, I would like to urge everyone to vote in favour of an amendment by my group. It calls on the Commission to ban all neonicotinoid-based pesticides. We now know that they are dangerous, they are toxic, they no longer belong in nature or on our plates.

name: Nikolaj Villumsen (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President! What we are discussing right now is the foundation of life on earth. The extinction of the animals and insects that pollinate our plants is not only a loss to our nature and biodiversity, it is a threat to our overall ecosystem and food production. In Denmark alone, we have lost more than 50 bee species in a short time, and the same serious trend is seen in other pollinators: the butterflies, the beetles, the flies.  We must take much better care of the little creatures that have such an infinite impact on the world around us. We must stop waivers for dangerous bee toxins. We need a fundamental reorientation of EU agricultural aid to give space to nature and sustainability.  So, ladies and gentlemen, vote for the pollsters, vote for the resolution!

name: Michal Wiezik (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the pollinator conservation initiative is an important step in saving a key component of ecosystems. The reason for the decline in pollinators is several, but the most serious are the change in land use and chemical pollution of the environment. We are losing ecosystems and species that have accompanied us for centuries. The landscape we manage too intensively is disappearing in diversity. And here I want to say that the initiative will not be enough if we do not ensure coherence across other measures. If the common agrarian policy continues to promote the intensification of agriculture, we will not succeed. If the Green Deal promotes the planting of trees and plantations instead of protecting natural forests, we will not succeed. If we prioritise the intensive use of biomass instead of maintaining draws, limits, tree trees, solitaires or old forests, we will fail. If we promote intensive livestock farming instead of free grazing of animals in the country, we will not succeed and we will lose the buzz, and not only that. Pollinators just can't be fooled.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in recent years, the public's attention, but also here in the European Parliament, has drawn attention to the unfavourable situation of the bee population, which has suffered huge losses both in the European Union and in the world. Behind this phenomenon is a much broader problem and phenomenon, which has already been mentioned by my Slovak colleagues, and I am very glad that we in the Slovak Republic care about solving this topic, and it is also a dramatic decrease in the incidence of diversity of all kinds of European pollinators, including bees. Numerous pollinator species have been extinct or at risk of extinction. It is estimated that in the European Union, around 84% of crop species and 78% of wildflower species depend, at least in part, on opping. Up to EUR 15 billion of the European Union's annual agricultural production is attributed directly to insect pollinators. I would therefore also like to take the opportunity in this debate to call once again for the fight to protect bees and other pollinators in the European Union. This fight is an existential struggle and we cannot afford to lose it, but we cannot underestimate it, so we must continue to extend the ban on pesticides and insecticides that kill or significantly harm pollinators in the European Union.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos (Renew).
text: – Mr President, pollinators are fundamental to the health of the environment and are therefore fundamental to our health. They are at risk and in some countries of the European Union the bee population has been reduced in recent years by more than 70%. So, of course we have to act. We salo add to the Commission's initiative, but we call for more ambition. In particular, this Resolution calls on Member States to take concrete measures to protect the pollinator population in their own agriculture. This Resolution clearly calls for the integrity of the bee guidelines adopted by the European Food Safety Authority, which is the most scientific, most advanced knowledge we have so far. And this Resolution also calls for clear progress in the forthcoming revision of the Directive on the sustainable use of pesticides following a prior evaluation in the establishment of common indicators and binding targets for pesticide reduction.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the decline of pollinators is really dramatic, I think almost all of us agree on this. At the same time, healthy pollinators are essentially indispensable for agricultural activity in the European Union, as 84% of crop species, as well as 76% of European food production, depend in some way on insect pollination, as My colleague Beňová has already said. The decline of pollinators therefore has a major impact on the quality and, of course, on the quantity of agricultural yields and on the yields themselves. We must change our common agricultural policy, which must remember the protection of agricultural areas of high natural value, reduce pesticides, this is absolutely crucial, also neonicotheses, the use of mineral fertilisers and, above all, create incentives for polycultures and crop rotation. Unfortunately, it is these vast fields with monocultures under the management of large enterprises, as we know them from the Czech Republic, that make a significant contribution to the decline of pollinators. I would like to appeal to the Commission to take this resolution seriously, and I would like to congratulate my colleague McGuinness, her proposal is very good.

name: Иво Христов (S&D).
text: – Mr President, while it is a step in the right direction, the European Commission's initiative cannot be considered a serious commitment to tackling the dramatic decline of wild and domestic pollinators. The European Commission needs to think on a longer horizon than a business that expects rapid liquidity and will not give up pesticides on its own. That requires willpower. In the last two years in my country – Bulgaria there have been dozens of cases of bee poisoning. Many beekeepers lost their bees and livelihoods, most often because of spraying with harmful herbicides and pesticides. And this is just the bill for the domestic bees on which we have observations. What is the effect on all other pollinators, we can only guess. We don't yet know what the effect of 5G technology will be, and scientists warn it will have an effect on pollinators.  Without a real and real financial and political commitment from the European Commission to beekeepers and scientific professionals, I fear that the fate of this initiative will be quite similar to the 2013 Guidelines of the European Food Safety Authority for Bees. Six years later, we are still much closer to the launch than to any positive result.

name: Irena Joveva (Renew).
text: – Mr President, bees and other pollinators are key to life on earth and one of the main indicators of the health of our environment. They are not only necessary for the pollination of most of our food, but also for food quality, biodiversity, pest control, soil and water quality.  In the past, nature has taken care of pollinators on its own, and now we have to take care of them ourselves. I therefore welcome this resolution, which calls on the Member States to take measures to reduce the use of harmful pesticides and to monitor bee populations ally.  The Commission and the Member States should set out measures for biodiversity and the reduction of pesticide use in strategic plans and increase funding for support for the citizens' scientific project for the recording and monitoring of pollinators. Without pollinators, the world will be left without food, without nature and, my dears, without people.

name: Liudas Mažylis (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there are no doubts about pollinators’ decline, so a scientific approach to the problem is required. The consequences can only be dealt with once the causes have been eliminated. Everything we do to prevent biodiversity loss must be based on science and ambitious, but realisable, goals. To prevent pollinators’ decline, the 2013 EFSA bee guidance should be fully adopted as soon as it is possible. Regulation No 1107 of 2011 concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market should be amended with regard to chronic toxicity, and not only for honey bees, but expanding requirements towards other pollinators. A blank impact assessment and standardised monitoring by pollinators should be an important aim for the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I will paraphrase Neil Armstrong a little at the time of landing: it seems a small initiative for the polynisers, but it is an initiative with a major impact for humanity. Because let us not forget that the future of mankind, as we know it at least, depends on it. There is no substitute for these bees and the Commission must at the moment also ensure firm policies both administrative, legislative and economic, because if we are talking about interventions only at state level, they will be ineffective. I am a doctor, an emergency physician, and I know the effects of toxics on this bee population, and we can't just talk about neonicotinoids, but we can also talk about organophosphoros, which are doing just as much harm to the bee population. On the other hand, it is easier to prevent than to treat; at least so says an old medical dictum from the time of Ambroise Paré, hundreds of years old. So it would be time to focus on the conservation of natural habitats and, why not, an initiative to ban the cutting of European forests at least during this five-year term. I am convinced that we are on a good path, but do not forget that there is no substitute for these bees.

name: Martin Hlaváček (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, congratulations on your responsible function. Stock stocks and species diversity are prerequisites for agricultural production, for our food security and for improving biodiversity. Properly carried out agricultural activity can make a significant contribution to addressing these issues. As you know, we are currently reforming agricultural policy, and this is a great opportunity, not a risk, as we hear so often here. However, we therefore need to find sufficient funds within the CAP and include the investments of our farmers in these areas in the category of climate and biodiversity expenditure, which is essential. There is also a need to invest in the development, alternatives and putting new technologies into practice. I trust you will support my colleague Wojciechowski in these areas in the coming months.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, indeed, this is a very important, extremely important topic, talking about the sustainability of ecosystems and how important pollinators are to us. I will not be the first to mention here that as much as 76% of food production depends on pollinators, but this is a fact that really needs to be highlighted, which may not be so well known to the public.  There are many causes for reducing the number of pollinators, but what is important is that when analyzing these causes, and also how to combat it, we should be based on science, on scientific facts and research, not on ideology. The second thing I would point out, and I use this opportunity to do so, is in general the role of beekeeping in the European Union. I come from Croatia, where high-quality honey is produced, but unfortunately there are many problems. One of the main problems is the import of pasta, uncontrolled honey from other countries, third states other than the Member States of the European Union, as well as the lack of data on the exact origin of honey and the mass content of honey from a particular country in the case of mixed honey. So this uncontrolled imports from third countries is a problem for our beekeepers, it represents disloyal competition and I think we certainly need to fight it here and protect our consumers and producers.

name: Isabel Carvalhais (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we know that there is a proven decline, both in the size of pollinating insect populations in Europe and in their diversity, and we know the vital relationship pollinators have with our own survival. Agriculture is a relevant part of this reality, either because of the negative pressures on pollinators, or as one of its main activities affected by its decline and, as such, it cannot fail to be part of the solution. In this sense, agri-environmental measures in rural development are an important tool in promoting agricultural biodiversity and in the conservation and creation of habitats favourable to the development of pollinators, but we must do much more, and it is essential to ensure that, in the next CAP, rural development interventions are endorsed with the resources needed to achieve much more ambitious objectives.  Research and training in this area should also be strengthened, pollinator populations monitored, the most effective intervention practices identified, and the development of productive solutions that protect bees, protect plants and meet farmers' production needs at the same time.

name: Nathalie Colin-Oesterlé (PPE).
text: Mr President, while we are witnessing a dramatic decline in pollinators, due in particular to the use of certain pesticides, this motion for a resolution, which will undoubtedly be voted on tomorrow, is essential because it clearly sets out targets and obligations to stop this decline. This is a major challenge for the preservation of biodiversity and agricultural production because, without pollinators, the question of our food sovereignty will arise. With this resolution, it is a strong message that we wish to send today to the new Commissioner. A few weeks ago, the European Commission proposed a draft regulation on the assessment of the impact of phytopharmaceuticals on bees, which was not sufficiently protective and did not go far enough. During this debate, we had already affirmed the importance of having appropriate legislation for the protection of pollinators, with increased support for research and innovation, enabling the development of sustainable practices. It is necessary to make this issue a priority, to provide concrete solutions in order to stem this decline, which would have very serious consequences for our agriculture.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Kyriakidou, you, like me, come from a country where bees and butterflies are part of its wealth. Almost EUR 15 billion of the European Union's annual agricultural production is directly attributed to insect pollinators. For many crops, the contribution of pollinators can amount to half the market value of the product. Pollinators are declining. They are reduced by pesticides, they are reduced by urbanization, they are reduced by increased pollution, they are reduced by changes in temperature. And we absolutely need to reduce pesticides but, in order to proceed immediately, drastically and horizontally to this, we must take the impact study as a basis. Because, in addition to the quantity of pesticides, their composition also plays a role. Because we must pay particular attention to the import of pesticides from third countries that do not meet the criteria of the European Union and because, above all, we must direct our producers to the use of alternative preparations. Our producers, our farmers, are those who know from tradition to respect bees and exploit their wealth.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the great Einstein mentioned this topic many years ago when he said that, if bees died out, a human life wouldn’t last long subsequently. And how right he was. I remember discussing this in Parliament some years ago, when the great Astrid Lulling, whom the MEPs’ lounge is called after, was championing the cause of bees, and here we are again, asking the Commission – especially now – to deal with it and to reverse the trend that is there. And I think it can be done. Obviously, harmful pesticides have to be curtailed and replaced, but more importantly, I think, is the next CAP offers a tremendous opportunity to create biodiversity in every single farm across Europe by incentivising farmers to make their farms a haven for bees and pollinators, and I think they would welcome that with open arms. So the policy has to change; it has to encourage the farmers, and then I think we will not have to be discussing this topic in future, because the trend would be reversed, and we will save the bees and human life.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as has already been mentioned, the loss of pollinators is a problem in terms of biodiversity, but also in terms of endangering crops. And farmers who actually farm know what is harmful and what helps, but they are also under great economic pressure. We need to stand up for our farmers. If we are tightening conditions, we cannot reduce financial support at the same time. Do we want farmers to meet more environmental criteria? We should therefore invest more in the first and second pillars of the common agricultural policy. Reducing pesticides is an important step, but it must be based on impact studies that will also offer farmers other sustainable practices. We cannot just ban pesticides without addressing how farmers will replace them. Let us make environmental changes responsibly both to pollinators and to our farmers.

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the need for the protection of pollinators and their habitats is indisputable, ladies and gentlemen, as indisputable are the benefits of their activity for agricultural productivity and for the environment and, of course, obviously for people. We are recognising the added value in this debate, the added value of the European Union's pollinator initiative launched by the Commission in June 2018. However, much of the resolution which we will vote on tomorrow is very critical of the Commission, the States and the farmers. And I would like to remind all of you: European legislation on the authorisation and use of plant protection products is one of the most stringent and reliable in the world and the European Union has banned the outdoor use of the three most widely used neonicotinoids – so I agreed because it was inevitable for public health. And I would like to conclude: we are all asking member states to implement EFSA's 2013 bee guide, but no section of tomorrow's resolution is calling for correcting errors in the methodology, and it is impracticable.

name: Vlad-Marius Botoş (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The motion for a resolution on pollinators is an absolutely necessary step in the European Union's green strategy. The Green Deal means more than pollution prevention. It means concrete measures to improve the environment. And we cannot talk about improving the environment without talking about pollinators. I would like to stress the importance of measures and programmes for the effective protection of pollinators, in order to draw attention to the fact that these programmes have no chance of success without the right funding to enter the territory directly for projects that pursue objectives with quantifiable results, with a direct improvement in pollinator numbers and their lifetime. There is a lot of research in this area and it has an undeniable quality. It is up to us and the European Commission to find a way to put these results into practice on the ground so that the effects are directly visible in nature.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Signor Presidente, Lei è un gentiluomo ... Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that there are certainly positive elements in the Pollinators Initiative in terms of setting strategic objectives and a set of actions to be taken by the EU and Member States. However, the initiative fails to adequately address the main root causes of the decline of pollinators such as land-use changes, intensive agriculture, use of pesticides and climate change. The new CAP reform can be a tool to reverse bee population, provided it is done right. Time will tell. We also urgently need legislation to ban all harmful pesticides right across the EU. The Irish National Park and Wildlife Service report submitted to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity this year blamed the pollinator decline on the obsession with ever-increasing levels of agricultural productivity; the loss of hedgerows, farmland edges and scrub; and monocultures, including cash crop forests made up of fast-growing coniferous species of low biodiversity value. We have got to stop this. And, unfortunately, in Ireland only recently, hedgerow cutting was extended by the Heritage Act last year. The EU should put manners on the Member States.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I come from a country where we have a great deal to do with bees, because we grow a great many fruits, and fruit, on the one hand, logically needs pollinators, but we also need plant protection. We live in this divisiveness and have some experience with it. You have to take a closer look at the whole thing. It is not only a question of which plant protection products are used, but also of how they are used. It is simply the case: in the flowering period, pesticides simply have nothing to look for on fruit trees, they simply have to be banned. It is a question of working closely with beekeepers, and the main issue – and we have not discussed this much – is that the biggest problem for bees at the moment is not plant protection products and is not the loss of biodiversity, but parasites that infect the bees themselves, i.e. varroa, marsupial beetles and the like, and that unfortunately we are getting more and more from these parasites and that we also have to work here in research and development. so that we develop effective countermeasures.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yes, we can all agree that biodiversity, the ecosystem and, of course, our fundamentally food security are at risk in Europe in the long term. Let's imagine that there are already areas in China where people get pollen, take brushes and pollinating peaches to give birth to new fruits. I just believe that, with our far-sighted policy, including in the area of agricultural policy, we will come to prevent such phenomena, because pollinators, and bees in particular, are probably one of the most important for our well-being and, at all, for the health of our children. We really need to get rid of pesticides and, in particular, so-called neonicotin pesticides, which mainly threaten the central nervous system. And when they threaten the central nervous system of bees, so surely humans. Let us really take this into account and behave very responsibly towards the future of our generations.

name: Silvia Modig (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we need action now, not fine words. You now have the opportunity to do better than the previous Commission did. Biodiversity is an intent value, but it is also a key element in the fight against climate change. Strong biodiversity will strengthen the planet's adaptability in the face of the warming that inevitably lay ahead. We need to think about the root causes. They can be found in agriculture, forestry and land use changes, and we must address them if we are to put an end to biodiversity and the radical decline of pollinators. Agriculture cannot survive without pollinators, and at the same time agriculture is the greatest threat to pollinators. That is why our common agricultural policy must be able, in the form of agricultural subsidies, to support farmers in farming techniques that promote biodiversity and preserve pollinators that are vital to us all.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, now, it’s abundantly clear that we all agree that pollinators are essential and that we need to protect them, and this is clear from everybody’s comments. The Commission has recognised the urgency and promptly answered the calls of the European Parliament and of the public to tackle the decline of pollinators, and we adopted the European Pollinators initiative, which is an ambitious framework that can address this complex challenge. It does consolidate actions across European Union policies and strengthen links between them, and to do this, we consulted broadly experts and stakeholders and introduced new actions where gaps were identified. Now, in the light of the European Green Deal, actions addressing the main threats to pollinators do need to be scaled up and made more effective. To measure the effects of policies and measures, however, we also need a robust monitoring system for pollinators and the threats they face. I listened carefully to a lot of the questions. I agree it’s crucial to look at imports, and the upcoming evaluation of the pesticides legislation will look at the issue of import tolerances and open this discussion. The Green Deal (I heard this being mentioned) does in fact speak about reducing pesticides. It says we will reduce the risk and use of pesticides significantly, and the farm-to-fork strategy, which, as you all know, will be presented, hopefully, in the spring, will be more specific about specific targets. Additionally, the Commission has taken decisive action to ban and restrict the use of neonicotinoids. Two are no longer approved, one cannot be used outdoors, and the Commission will be proposing not to renew the approval of a fourth one. And it is supporting the use of low-risk and non-chemical pesticides. Now, concerning – I think there was a question on emergency authorisations – we have increased scrutiny of these, including proposing decisions preventing two countries from granting contested authorisations. Furthermore, the Commission will continue supporting Member States to ensure the sustainable use of pesticides, and the Commission will be presenting the findings of the refit evaluation of the Pesticides Regulation and the second reports on the implementation of the Sustainable Use Directive early in 2020. And finally, I agree that having an ambitious strategy plan on the CAP is very important in order to deliver on our own ambitions. Now let me be absolutely clear: the Commission is determined to coordinate and steer a decisive European Union action to stop and reverse pollinator decline. However, the success of this initiative will, critically, depend on the strong engagement of all stakeholders in its implementation. Member States will have an indispensable role in the deployment of effective actions and monitoring systems on the ground, and we look forward to the European Parliament’s strong endorsement of this initiative and the crucial role of Member States in its implementation.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, echoing what you and the Commission have said, let me also conclude by recalling the importance of pollinators for biodiversity, for our food systems and for our well-being. I welcome this discussion today on this very important topic. It is clear that the current efforts on pollinators’ protection are not sufficient. We need to have a more holistic and coordinated approach on this issue, and there is broad support in the Council to increase the environmental ambition in the CAP – the common agricultural policy – reform, of course taking into account the situation of our farmers. Moreover, the relevant EU measures have to be stronger and properly implemented. I am, therefore, looking forward to the new Commission strategy, which will, hopefully, address the weaknesses of the current EU policies and will be accompanied by appropriate monitoring and enforcement mechanisms to improve their effectiveness. Thank you very much for this important discussion.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 December 2019. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The survival of the European bee population is under increasing threat year after year, as is the increasing number of wild pollinators threatened with extinction. The main causes of this worrying trend are human activity, based on the consistent conclusions of related scientific research. The EU pollinators initiative was an important milestone in the process of identifying the problem. However, the measures have not yet proved sufficient to protect pollinating species. More ambitious steps are therefore needed, for three reasons. On the one hand, it is a moral responsibility to pass on to future generations the environment that we inherited from our forebears in at least the same quality. On the other hand, 75% of European food production depends on bee pollination, so strengthening the European beekeeping sector is of paramount importance. Finally, without further measures, quality products from European beekeepers are unable to compete with cheap imports, which may further reduce the european Union's self-sufficiency. Overall, the European Parliament's resolution seeks to find a solution to these factors, so I support it.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – The number of pollinators threatened with extinction is constantly increasing and in many cases human activity is behind it. In addition to the drastic reduction in the number of wild pollinators and their animals, the mass extinction of honeybees is also a problem in Europe year after year. The beekeeping sector is an integral part of European agriculture and provides income for more than 600 000 EU citizens, but the European Union is only semi-self-sufficient in honey products and needs hundreds of thousands of tonnes of imports a year. Hungary honey power, the EU's third largest honey producer, exports around 90% of its exports to EU markets. It is therefore important to strengthen the EU beekeeping sector and stabilise the honey market. In my opinion, therefore, additional resources should be allocated to research into the causes of the decline in bees. Thus, the protection of pollinating species and bees is not only environmentally beneficial, but also has economic potential.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on animal welfare conditions during transport to third countries (2019/2944(SDR)). I would remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that you can request the catch-the-eye procedure and the blue card using both standard registration and the electronic system directly from your workstations. Instructions are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, we have all been struck by the news a few weeks ago about the capsizing of a vessel which led to the drowning of more than 14 000 sheep. I’m sure that we all agree that everything must be done to avoid a similar tragic accident happening again.  Animal welfare remains a serious concern for European citizens; 82% of respondents to a Eurobarometer survey on this issue said that improvements are badly needed in farm-animal welfare, and most of them considered that the EU should do more to promote greater awareness of animal welfare, including at international level.  The Council regularly discusses matters related to animal welfare. Over the last six months, the Finnish Presidency has worked very actively on the preparation of Council conclusions on animal welfare. And ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to confirm that the conclusions were adopted by the Council yesterday.  In these conclusions, the Council emphasises the importance of good animal welfare as an integral part of sustainable animal production, and notes the improvements already achieved in the EU. At the same time, the Council acknowledges the need to continue improving the welfare of animals, including during transport over long distances.  On the issue of transport, as a first step, the Council encourages the Commission and the Member States to continue their work on the effective enforcement of the existing legislation, in particular through improved exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States, and more active cooperation between different competent authorities in Member States and third countries.  As a further step, the Council invites the Commission to review and update the existing transport legislation to take into account current practical problems and experience of Member States in its enforcement, as well as more recent scientific knowledge and technical developments.  Dear friends, we are all aware that various sensitive issues such as the transport time or the sustainability of trade in live animals may need to be discussed in this context. These are very important questions which certainly deserve thorough consideration in different fora with the contribution of all stakeholders involved.  Finally, regarding international aspects, the Council reaffirms the importance of promoting the welfare of animals globally, given the competition that EU farmers are facing in global trade.  Discussions with our trade partners, and in particular negotiations on free-trade agreements with third countries, offer indeed an excellent opportunity for this. Naturally, this goes hand in hand with our continued efforts at multilateral level to develop standards, guidelines and other activities aimed at achieving good animal welfare practices worldwide, including during long-distance transport, for instance through the World Organisation for Animal Health. Thank you very much, Mr President, for your attention and for this very timely debate.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, like you, I was terribly shocked by the news on 24 November that almost 15 000 sheep had drowned when the ship transporting them capsized in the Black Sea port of Midia. It is, after all, our responsibility to ensure that animals are safe and protected during transport. Animal welfare must remain an overriding consideration in our work.  The information provided by the Romanian veterinary authorities who approved the vessel for livestock transport and supervised the dispatch of the animals, was that available space requirements set out in the EU law were fully respected; but, of course, this is of little comfort as we reflect on the losses sustained on that day. The transporters clearly failed in their primary responsibility to protect the animals in their charge throughout the journey. This is a requirement specifically set out in EU legislation and which must be respected. They failed to take adequate precautions to prevent this loss and to protect the animals from the pain and the distress that they suffered before they perished.  This is about the ethical values of our Union. The Commission is working with Member States to improve the conditions of animals during transport. In recent years, we have taken action to improve the situation, particularly at the border between Bulgaria and Turkey, a well-known hotspot for animal welfare issues. Since 2017, we have dedicated staff and resources to tackle this particular problem. Although more can, and must, be done, the results are encouraging. By working closely with veterinary authorities in exporting Members States and Turkey, and with the cooperation of NGOs, we have dramatically reduced the number of consignments that cross the borders during hot periods. Last summer there wasn’t a single incident reported at the border linked to the road transport of animals.  This does not mean that all issues have been resolved. It is nonetheless a signal that we are at least on the right track. We need to maintain a constant dialogue with Member States and stakeholders through the network of animal welfare contact points and the animal welfare platform, and we need to ensure that this dialogue leads to concrete results and actions. Actions on sea transport have also been taken. In the last two years we audited official control arrangements for sea transport of livestock in four Member States, including Romania. For these audits, we saw that the situation is quite worrying. Many arrangements seem to fall well below the standards established by EU law. Our auditors found particular shortcomings concerning the approval of vessels by the authorities. I am well aware that the supervision and approval of vessels for animal transport are indeed challenging tasks. Specific and extensive training is needed to adequately perform them – specialised training that differs from that provided to most veterinarians. The recent incident makes it abundantly clear that even ensuring that facilities are suitable to accommodate animals is no guarantee that the vessel itself is seaworthy, or that its crew is properly trained.  There are also currently no arrangements to inform veterinarian authorities of problems detected by inspectors in other EU countries, and this is something that we are actively working on with the European Maritime Safety Agency to allow for better sharing of information regarding livestock vessels. We have also worked with Member States to improve their checks on livestock vessels, and this process has brought out some improvement in the inspection systems for these vessels.  A further initiative that we have taken is to engage with the countries receiving live animals in order to get information on each consignment. This will provide valuable feedback on the conditions of the animals on arrival, and promote continuous improvement, and of course, as is usual, we have issued recommendations following our audits. We will closely monitor how these are addressed by Member States.  This is a matter that I will follow closely and I will raise with ministers on every occasion. They all need to take action to prevent incidents like the one that happened in Romania from happening again, and I can assure you that I will work with the same focus to improve the conditions of animals transported by sea, as we did to improve the conditions of animals transported by road under the previous Commission.  I can also assure you that I will look at animal welfare as an important part of the Farm to Fork Strategy that I will be presenting in spring 2020 as part of the European Green Deal, and this includes a critical look at the existing rules, including animal transport.

name: Herbert Dorfmann
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the The demise of Queen Hind and the loss of thousands of animals is undoubtedly more than regrettable. But I also expect to hear from the Romanian authorities: what actually happened? Why did this ship go under? Was this ship suitable to transport so many animals? Was it overloaded? Have current animal welfare rules been broken? After all, it does not help if we are constantly calling for new rules on animal welfare and the transport of animals, but on the other hand – and I am very right about this, Commissioner – if we still have situations where the existing law is not sufficiently implemented. I believe that we must call on the Member States to ensure that the right that exists today, which is sharp in Europe, is implemented. The transport of live animals cannot always be prevented. For example, we have to transport farm animals, there are animals that go to the final mast and they have to be transported alive there. But there are already situations in Europe where animals are carved through half of Europe in search of the even cheaper slaughterhouse, and then the carcasses are transported back. Such nonsense, I believe, should be looked at.  I believe that we should transport carcasses wherever possible and non-live animals. We should also do this where special slaughter, in this case slaughter, is demanded by customers. There, too, we must contact the states that then buy these animals, so that we can deliver carcasses that are not live animals, but effectively slaughtered carcasses.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, although European animal health and welfare standards are among the most advanced globally, we are still discussing accidents that are no longer acceptable when transporting animals. It is clear that this Parliament's efforts to achieve ambitious objectives, of which we must be proud and which we must defend, are often frustrated. We need, Commissioner, a careful analysis of what action is needed for the full and uniform application of our animal welfare standards in all Member States. As the Committee on Agriculture, we have already decided to go down this road, not only to reduce the distorting impacts of the possibility that producers within the Union can translate non-application of the rules into competitive advantages. Our farmers, in complying with European standards, incur much higher production costs than their competitors outside the Eu ropean Union, finding themselves victims of unfair competition. We can no longer accept this happening within the single market as well.

name: Elsi Katainen
text: On behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I hope that this serious accident in Romania will make us understand the importance of transport conditions for the treatment and welfare of animals. Unnecessary stress and incidents are fixable by legislation and a general change in attitude, if there is a will to do so. There are ways of finding ways, from education to legislation, and the commitment of the Member States is of paramount importance here. Improper handling of animals, such as long journeys, cramping and heat, can be avoided if the animals are in the hands of responsible operators.  Transport to third countries must be under particular surveillance. The starting point must always be that transporting a live animal would be the last option. Sick and injured animals are, of course, a special chapter of their own, and it is transport fitness that is one of the measures of animal welfare. Quality is more important than quantity, as even two hours of poor transport can be harder than double the amount of transport in good conditions.  That is why the density of the slaughterhouse network must also be an issue that is considered, especially in countries with long distances. Animal welfare must be made the main objective of transport, it must be promoted more strongly in finland, and therefore the same standards must also be respected from the slaughterhouse, regardless of the country of origin. We in the EU therefore have every opportunity to make responsible transport a strong competitive advantage in the world food market as well.  In legislation, we must pay attention to two things. Firstly, the existing rules on the transport of animals must be fully implemented in each Member State. Secondly, the updating of the Animal Transport Directive must also be strongly included in the Farm to Fork strategy and the Green Deal.

name: Francisco Guerreiro
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are gathered to witness the failure of European policies to protect animal welfare. On 24 November, more than 14,000 sheep drowned in the Black Sea after a live animal transport ship sank off Romania and this tragedy was expected because a 2018 report by the same Parliament already denounced the serious shortcomings of European legislation and the systematic failure of several Member States to comply with Community regulations.  Furthermore, reports from various non-governmental organisations show that there are no animal welfare conditions on board these vessels, such as plant health guarantees which, in the countries receiving these animals, mostly in the Middle East, are often non-existent. In sum, trade around the brutal and inhuman exploitation of these animals can only be regarded as an attack on any so-called "developed" society, so there is no other way but to end the export of live animals outside the European Union. And the question I ask the new Commission is whether you have the courage to end this barbarism now?

name: Julie Lechanteux
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, let me denounce here the hypocrisy of this institution on the issue of animal welfare when transporting to third countries, a hypocrisy which consists in giving such a crucial place to such a crucial debate at such a late hour, when the Chamber is empty, precisely to prevent any public discussion on the halal slaughter regime. Religious slaughter, therefore, is the reason why animals are transported alive for thousands of kilometres. As we know, these countries require living animals to be able to slaughter them according to a specific religious ritual according to which the animal must be conscious, not dizzy. These long journeys of several days, with endless queues at border crossings outside the European Union, there are inevitably many breaches of the most basic needs of these animals: the inability of animals to drink, lack of food, overloaded trucks and faulty ventilation during heavy heat, litter stained with feces, sick animals that are dying and dying of exhaustion, dehydration and stress , all without any veterinary control from one Member State to another and from one country to another. During transport by boat, sick or dead animals are thrown into the sea once their identification loops are removed, so that there are no traces if the carcass of the animal runs aground on a beach. I would remind you that the current conditions for transporting live animals from the European Union to third countries take place in total illegality, in complete violation of the European regulation, which nevertheless provides for very specific rules in this area. Article 3, however, makes it clear that , and I quote - "no one carries or transports animals in such conditions that they are at risk of injury or suffering unnecessary suffering". Well, fifteen years after this regulation came into force, nothing has changed, Mr President, because this institution does not have the courage to debate the real issue that is problematic, that of religious slaughter.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, this is a list of all the ships that have departed from the port of Midia to the Middle East and North Africa this year. We are talking about 200 ships, or millions of animals. Ships such as al Shuwaikh, which transported more than 70,000 animals to the Middle East last summer in temperatures of up to 46 degrees. Ships such as the Queen Hind, which recently capsized in the Black Sea, killing 14,000 sheep. When will infringement proceedings be initiated against Romania? These are not incidents. Animals are transported every day in Europe in ships, trucks and aircraft. These animals are mistreated and put together in small spaces and often succumb to the extreme temperatures. It is unacceptable that European rules have been broken for years. The European Parliament must set up a committee of inquiry as soon as possible to investigate the failing legislation and enforcement. Finally, I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Ann Widdecombe (NI).
text: – Mr President, I very much associate myself with many of the remarks that have gone before me, but I would like to ask a more fundamental question – not so much what the measures should be to give a greater guarantee of animal welfare during live transport, but why is it necessary to have live exports at all? One of the big benefits of Brexit will be that we will no longer be tied in the UK to the single market rules which actually prevent individual States from banning live exports. Following an incident in the English port of Ramsgate in which 40 sheep died, the local council did impose a ban, and that was ruled unlawful under EU law. Defra in the UK has now announced that it is considering a ban, and so I say that on 31 January all the animals in the UK will be cheering.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before giving the floor to Mrs Buda, I would like to take this opportunity to wish you all a merry Christmas and a happy New Year for this 2020 that awaits us.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the death of the more than 14 000 sheep in the Black Sea is, without question, a tragedy. This is clear evidence that human error not only leads to aircraft crashes, to road traffic accidents, resulting in the loss of human lives, but behold, human error can also happen when we talk about animals taken to the slaughterhouse.  Even though the loading conditions were complied with and the state authorities, in partnership with the NGOs, intervened immediately, under difficult conditions, only a few animals were rescued from the raging waters.  We are therefore obliged to consider identifying measures to develop slaughtering capacities for animals as close as possible to the place where they grew up. Based on the reality that Arab countries only want live animals, it is necessary for Member States to ensure that, throughout transport, their welfare standards are met.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The recent incident in Romania shows once again that Regulation (EC) No 1/2005 simply does not fulfil its purpose of protecting animals during transport. I repeat the date: we have been aware of this regulation since 2005. Now is the time to rethink. This year– 2019 – the European Parliament, in an implementation report, called on the Commission to develop a strategy to promote the transport of meat and carcasses, to move away from this old promotion, to transport live animals – in short, to change a trade model. I am now asking the Commission, and I am looking forward to the answer, but the whole Group Animal Welfare is also looking forward to the answer: when can the Commission inform us and, above all, how is the Commission finally taking up work to put in place an instrument for the conversion to trade in meat and animal products, in order to make it clear that we should transport meat and carcasses or transport seeds, but no longer live animals? I would like that answer from you.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam President, we all saw those heartbreaking images last month. Other images have taken place on other occasions in other European ports, in Portugal, in other European countries. During the transport of live animals, inside and outside the Union, they often suffer from thirst, hunger, exposure to excessive heat or lack of space. Yes, trade in animals is important, meat is an essential commodity, but we must think constructively, because we must defend animal rights and European legislation. That's why I want to remind you of Regulation No 17. 1/2005 and the interpretation of the European Court of Justice, which it gives, and the provision, from the point of origin to the destination, of the Relevant European rules.  We need to act a little more firmly in this area and help the Member States achieve this. At the same time, I want to tell you that it is necessary to provide farmers with strong financial mechanisms to encourage them to choose the preservation of live animals within the Union and to move towards the export of meat, and this can be done through the common agricultural policy.  I want to bring you another matter in this discussion; is the issue of international treaties. It is the European Union that has the competence, in international trade treaties, to impose high standards of animal protection on the other countries with which we trade.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every year in Europe, several million animals suffer appalling transport conditions: they are locked up, exploited and abused. We can no longer turn a blind eye to animal abuse. Animals have the right to respect, to benevolence, just like human beings. Last year, several NGOs showed that 70% of the trucks inspected at the Bulgarian border did not comply with EU law. We need to shed light on these practices. That is why we are calling for a commission of inquiry. But we should go further. Europe needs to be concerned about animal welfare, and that starts with reducing the maximum travel time and banning EU animal exports to third countries. Animals are sentient beings, living beings; they are not things, they are not objects. Thus, the European Union must now give them its full attention, its commitment, so that they too deserve to be a priority.

name: Annika Bruna (ID).
text: Madam President, the stranding of a Palau-flagged vessel carrying nearly 15,000 sheep in a Romanian port last November reopens the debate on the conditions under which live animals are transported. This disaster follows the scandal of the transport of thousands of sheep in the heatwave this summer by a ship flying the Tanzanian flag, in violation of all the rules theoretically imposed in the Union. But how could it be otherwise when controls and sanctions remain theoretical, since the main objective of the Union is profit at all costs, especially at the cost of animal suffering? Even if the one billion animals transported every year to and from the Union were transported in optimal conditions, what about the terrible conditions of survival on the ground and the appalling conditions of slaughter in the recipient countries? It must be said that many countries of the Union, including my own, France, have no lessons to teach in this area. They prefer, for electoral reasons and under the pretext of tolerance, to please certain religious and financial lobbies, and thus condemn the animal to die in unbearable suffering.
