Our continent must reverse its priorities: respecting life more than profit. This awareness is paramount; it is a civilizational marker, because placing the profit over alles makes the nest of the despicable. These are not sterile whining that animals need and that Europeans concerned about the animal cause want, they are strong and immediate acts. Compliance with transport rules must be systematically monitored, which are still largely inadequate. The animal, even intended to provide the sustenance of man, is not an object, it is a being gifted by God or nature, according to our convictions, of sensitivity. Those who deny it for financial reasons only see the animal as a source of profit, they must pay the high price, that of the immediate and definitive prohibition of their activity of breeding, transport or slaughter. The rest is just chatter and hypocrisy.

name: Martin Buschmann (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, not only the politician, but also the man Martin Buschmann speaks to you. A person who wants to open your eyes to how wrong it is, what we do with our fellow creatures – the animals. Queen Hind left Romania on 24 November. It was loaded with almost 15,000 sheep, the target being Saudi Arabia. Shortly after she was able to set sail, the ship got hit and capsized. 14,400 animals drowned, were crushed, trampled each other in panic or dawned half dead several days before. Then came the rescue workers of the animal welfare organisation Four Paws, which they were eventually able to find and recover. For the animals, this means untold suffering. This is not a state of affairs. This cannot and must not remain the case under any circumstances. We must make political sure that these crimes do not continue to take place.  I appeal to your sympathy, ladies and gentlemen of Parliament. Animal welfare must finally arrive in the European Parliament. We must stand up for the fact that we cannot continue to expose sentient beings to such hell.

name: Eleonora Evi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thirteen years after the entry into force of the reference regulation, violations continue to be the norm rather than the exception, and millions of animals are forced to travel hell every year, crammed without food or water, with temperatures sometimes exceeding 40 degrees. A real Far West, as certified by the Commission's audits. It may be for this reason that over time they have decreased so drastically, in 2017 you have made seven, in 2018 four, only one in 2019 and it is not yet clear if there will be any in 2020. I therefore hope that the new Commission will remember its role, which is to ensure that European law is properly applied throughout the Territory of the Union and therefore acts accordingly. However, given that this has not been the case up to now, it will be up to the European Parliament to remind you of this with the creation of a committee of inquiry which will investigate cases of maladministration in the implementation and enforcement of the standards and rules laid down in European law, which I very much hope will finally see the light of day shortly, because tragedies announced, such as the one that took place off the waters of Romania only a few weeks ago , never happen again.  I will end with three specific questions to the Commission, which I hope will be answered. How many audits do you intend to conduct in 2020? When could we see the adoption of a strategy for a transition from the transport of live animals to that of meat and carcasses? And finally, when do you intend to revise the regulation to finally put an end to long-term travel?

name: Andrzej Halicki (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Attitude towards animals is a testament to our humanity. Of course, animals feel, suffer, fear death just like us. And we are talking here about the transport of livestock, but I would like to say that in Poland a month ago we had a great scandal and rescued from the death of tigers that were transported from Italy to Azerbaijan. This also applies to animals transported to circuses. Personally, I am in favour of a total ban on the use of animals for such frills, for our dubious pleasure. Before Christmas, fish are transported without water. They suffer too. So we have rules, but they have to be enforced. Detailed and frequent checks are needed, travel logs need to be enforced, education and information are needed. All this is in the hands of the services that must be active, and for this we must force our services to really pay attention to it. Let us remember that animals are living beings and we must strengthen their rights.

name: Clara Aguilera (S&D).
text: – Madam President, without a doubt, what has happened to this sheep boat in Romania is a terrible disgrace that no one of us here likes. It is therefore good to ask Romania for explanations and to demand, of course, that the legislation be complied with. But I have to tell you, Commissioner, that I believe that the Commission is in the right field. States must be required to comply with current regulations. We have a regulation which the Commissioner has said is not being complied with, which is usually not being complied with. Then, before we ask for another one, we will demand that those regulations be complied with. Promotion campaigns are also needed in third countries on animal welfare; we could promote them. But, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is in the debate within the platform of animal welfare that we must continue to move forward, and it is a breakthrough to introduce animal welfare into the green deal. And finally, ladies and gentlemen, animal welfare is much more, much more, than transport to third countries, and we never talk about it.

name: Jan Huitema (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am very concerned about this issue. I grew up on a farm where we were waiting day and night to treat our animals well. If you sell your animals, you assume that they are treated the same way elsewhere. My stomach therefore turns when I see animals being transported and treated at borders with third countries. Eyes are poked out and animals are beaten with iron bars and dragged by their horns. There's no way. We can still remember the recent incident in Romania, in which a ship full of sheep capsized and the animals were left to fend for themselves. This is the kind of practice we must take a hard line on. We, as the European Union, are entirely responsible for this, and I am deeply ashamed of that. If we cannot guarantee that animals will be exported in an animal-friendly way, then we should not allow them to do so either. After all, rules are there to be followed.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What has now happened to the 14 000 sheep is the culmination of a permanent scandal. Every year we see the reports from the Bulgarian-Turkish border. We know, so to speak, what happens to the transport of animals through Europe, because a cheap slaughterhouse is being taken somewhere. None of this is new. I am annoyed that every year we have the debate here, that we adopted a report last year, but apparently nothing is happening at all. I am afraid that nothing will happen again now, because simply the Member States do not carry out checks. The Member States are looking away in a targeted manner. And I must also say that, unfortunately, the Commission is not looking closely either. How can this happen, that we have laws that are systematically not complied with, that we in Parliament are calling for tightening up, but which the Council also seems to be completely ignored? This must not happen again. But it is also due to an export-oriented system of agriculture, where surpluses are exported to animals just so that we can sell them somewhere cheaply. That, too, is a cause of the scandal.

name: Aurelia Beigneux (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the question of the fate of animals exported from Europe to third countries is not trivial and only confirms the Ideological compromises of the Commission. If there is a stated desire to care about animal dignity, we can see that animal dignity is willingly sacrificed in the face of electoral and financial interests. To a written question tabled in November concerning ritual slaughter, I was told, and I quote: 'the European Union must take full account of the requirements of animal welfare and implement certain European Union policies, while respecting in particular the practices of religious rites'. With this response, the Commission therefore yields to reasonable accommodations and community and religious pressures. In reality, the majority try to spare the goat and cabbage. On the one hand, with fellow Europeans who are mainly committed to animal welfare and on the other hand, with the interests of financial and religious lobbies, for whom this issue is secondary when it is not prohibitive. The truth is that some countries of destination of our meat production do not respect the basic health or moral rules and that no account is required in this context. The weakness with external partners is ultimately just another manifestation of the European Union's weakness in the face of internal pressures. We remain convinced that the export of our animals must be done on the condition of their well-being and dignified transport conditions.

name: Dan-Ştefan Motreanu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Romania is only one of the countries of the European Union from which live animals are transported to third countries. For Romania, animal husbandry is an important economic activity, but as countries that only accept trade in live animals, animal welfare has been a constant concern for us, including when we held the rotating Presidency of the Council. Most of the measures in Regulation No 17 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 1999 on the common organisation 1/2005 are already implemented and Romania will introduce additional standards to this Regulation, such as increasing the area per animal by 20%, the presence of a veterinarian on board the vessel, limits and daily monitoring of the temperature on the vessel. Today, the Regulation provides only temperature limits for transport only for road transport, not for shipping.  Currently, in Romania there are two legislative proposals in the Romanian Parliament, carried out together with NGOs and international transport experts, which will very strictly regulate the authorisation of shipping vessels. The accident in the port of Midia was a tragedy, it is regrettable, but Romania... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... has solid legislation and the most important thing is to strictly enforce the law.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Madam President, what happened in the Black Sea port is undoubtedly a tragedy and we must take all measures to ensure that this does not happen again. At the same time, however, I do not believe that the Romanian farmer should be the one paying because, in this incident, he has absolutely no fault. On the contrary, the Romanian farmer raises his animals according to the highest standards imposed by the common agricultural policy and not only that, but his subsidies are conditional on this.  Secondly, I assure you that no farmer in the world who has invested energy, time and money in raising their animals sends them to export with the thought that they will end up in dire conditions. Thirdly, the Romanian farmer often encounters insurmountable obstacles when trying to sell his products on the European market or even in hypermarkets in his own country. That's the way it is, states outside the European Union are, at the moment, his only chance of survival. The solution, therefore, is not to stop the export of live animals, but to tighten the rules that we impose on third countries, especially when it comes to long-distance transport, to closely monitor compliance with these rules, to ensure and encourage the slaughter of animals in the country of origin, because we have the marketing of meat, which would also bring more benefits to the farmer, and to the livestock sector, and to the country.

name: Martin Hojsík (Renew).
text: – Madam President, thousands and thousands of animals are exported from the EU every year to third countries, under conditions I cannot imagine even in the Middle Ages. But it's not just these transports, it's not just a ship in Romania. Transports, which also walk around Europe, are experiencing conditions in them that I find difficult to imagine. It is an ordeal that animal conservationists have been pointing out for decades. Despite the fact that this House has dealt with this many times, despite the new promises we have received, despite public pressure across Europe, the Stop The Truck campaign is still not doing enough action. We miss change. We need to limit transports within the European Union to a maximum of 8 hours, and when it comes to exports to third countries, we must or should ensure that our standards are respected or simply prohibited for live animals.

name: Grace O'Sullivan (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, as animal welfare groups beg us not to buy puppies for Christmas because it stresses animals in this frantic season, please spare a thought for the daily trauma suffered by animals being transported overseas. The recent incident where over 14 000 sheep drowned is not unique. The practice of live exports is barbaric, inflicting needless suffering on living sentient beings.  As an Irish woman, I’m ashamed to say our cattle are being shipped as far away as Libya and Turkey, journeys of up to 12 days, where animals travel flesh on flesh over often treacherous seas, regularly becoming seriously ill, injured and dying. Even more shameful, the bulk of our cattle exports are unweaned two—week old calves taken from their mothers’ sides, herded on board vessels into cramped conditions where they suffer deep distress. Not only is this unacceptable by any animal welfare standards, it is unacceptable by moral standards.

name: Juan Ignacio Zoido Álvarez (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, more than 4 million head of cattle, 4 million sheep heads, 4 million sheep heads, 28 million pigs and 250 million birds are transported to the European Union every year. This gives us the real dimension that animal transport is a fundamental element of livestock and the European economy as a whole that needs to be protected. The death of the 14,000 sheep on the ship that sank off the coast of Romania in November is a very unfortunate fact and that must be thoroughly investigated. But it is an isolated fact that in no way represents the reality of the sector. Fortunately, the European Union has the regulations that best protect the welfare of all transported animals. Citizens can be sure that animals transported in the European Union are protected, but in this line they will have to follow the Commission and demand compliance with all current regulations.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his We humans are sentient beings and intelligent beings. It obliges. We have a responsibility for the animals. And every year millions of animals are transported from the EU to countries outside our borders, including the Middle East and North Africa. The aim is to slaughter the animals or sell them alive, and we know that these transports are often hell on earth for these animals. The animals are often dehydrated and hungry or are crushed to death in these journeys. We also know that suckling animals, young animals in need of their mothers, are involved in these types of transport.  The previous Commission said that priority should be given to animal welfare. Nevertheless, countries are escaping this, controls are not being complied with and we did not see clear progress with new animal rights rules. I very much hope for the new Commission, that you will be more capable of action and that you will feel with the animals and take the moral responsibility that we humans have.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The humanity of a society can be seen by the way it treats its animals. It is not acceptable that cattle, sheep or pigs are sometimes crowded for more than 20 hours, do not receive water in high heat, and receive no food, that they are transported in the most pitiful circumstances. As the cattle fight for religious rites when slaughtering, their eyes are often pierced enough and their tendons are severed. Such abuses are unworthy of the EU.  I find it absurd that animals are sometimes transported more than 1 000 kilometres simply because live transport is cheaper than refrigerated transport. The citizens are fed up with this animal cruelty under the toleration of the European Commission. We have to put an end to that.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must agree with most of you. Every animal that is transported suffers so much, even if it is a short distance, let alone thousands of kilometers. Of course, I also consider it absolutely unnecessary that thousands of kilometres, i.e. to third countries, animals should be brought live instead of chilled meat. I think that's a practice that should be abandoned by now. Very strict standards apply on the territory of the European Union, and yet what happened is that 14 600 sheep died in a Romanian port. It is quite certain that the carrier did not comply with the conditions, otherwise such a disaster could not have happened. I would join those who say here that we are not calling for new regulation, but really consistently enforce existing regulations and think about really restricting animal exports to third countries. Although I know it is big business, and I wish farmers to have the income they need, but this is disproportionate and let us try to support our farmers in a different way.

name: Juozas Olekas (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Honourable President. Honourable Commissioner, representative of the Council, honourable colleagues, animal welfare in Europe is an important priority. However, an important role in the Community export structure. The recent events in the Black Sea therefore call for immediate action. And it cannot be limited to tightening even more rules, and perhaps even an impractical solution that is in the interests of farmers, but we must look to the rules that exist to comply with them. As a rule, the most damaging to animal welfare is not the journey itself, but its negative aspects, extreme temperatures, lack of food, water and rest. We therefore need to take a coordinated horizontal approach to a problem that not only focuses on compliance with standards, controls, but also covers other areas such as the installation and procedures of EU border crossings. We must therefore be forced to comply with our standards.

name: Benoît Biteau (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I am a breeder myself and I am ashamed; I am outraged by such transport conditions. It is an insult to the bond between breeders and animals, and this link first elevates the breeder. How can humans be perpetrators of such horrors, for economic reasons alone, to the detriment of animal welfare? However, far from me the idea of sinking into the idea that we must abolish livestock farming, which is sometimes necessary, often necessary, if not always necessary for the balance of certain territories. We must therefore build alternatives to these transport situations and transport itself, based on local slaughterhouses, based on mobile slaughterhouses, based on on-farm slaughter, which would achieve a situation acceptable to animals, breeders and consumers.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the issue of poor animal welfare during transport to third countries has been debated intensely. I think everyone in this room is aware of the suffering these animals endure. However, time and time again, independent reports showed the non-compliance and inconsistencies in enforcing existing rules. The recent case of tigers being transported from Italy through Europe to Russia is just an example. We all have heard about the tragedy of more than 14 000 sheep in Romania. I therefore call for limiting animal transport outside of the EU to no more than eight hours and banning transport of live animals to third countries if their standards do not match the EU standards. Our target should be a total ban of transport of live animals as such.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, every year we talk about how appallingly we treat animals, while receiving reports on animal welfare, we are talking about welfare. When I see these cases – and this case of 14,000 dead sheep is a testament to this – the way we treat animals, I feel tremendous shame. It's not true that we don't need a rule change. We need to change the rules, because the existing ones, in my opinion, are not being respected firstly and, secondly, they are not sufficient. What do we need to focus on? Exporting mainly animals for slaughter, that is, already dead, slaughtered animals, slaughter meat, this is a priority for the transport of slaughter meat, not live animals. If live animals are to be transported, it must only be at a certain distance, for a certain period of time. If live animals are to be transported to third countries, the standards we are talking about here today must be met. If third countries want European live animals, please pay for it.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to refer once again to the problem of wildlife transport that has already been raised. In November, public opinion in Poland was appalled by information about the transport of Bengal tigers transported on the Polish-Belarusian border in scandalous conditions from Italy to Dagestan. From Italy, this transport went without any obstacles to the Polish-Belarusian border. In tragic conditions – tigers were in cramped cages, starved. Of the ten animals, one died and the other was tragic. And only thanks to last-minute intervention, thanks to the action of the employees of poznań zoo in cooperation with the organization Animal Advocates managed to save these animals. With this in mind that such things are repeated, I wanted to ask the Commission why the existing provisions of the 2005 Animal Protection Regulation are being disregarded and what does it intend to do about it?

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, millions of citizens saw the gruesome pictures of the ship carrying 40 000 sheep sinking off the coast of Romania. This is not the first time, and I’m afraid it will not be the last time, that this has happened. But let’s be honest: would the alternative for these sheep have been any better, being stuck on a cold ship for weeks in their thousands, left in their own dirt and thrown overboard when they die of hunger or exhaustion? Whom are we kidding here? The mass export of live animals will never be able to guarantee good animal welfare conditions. We need to stop this absurd and cruel business model. Let’s stop subsidising intensive animal agriculture, which produces so many animals, we don’t know where to ship them any more. Let’s work towards a ban on the transport of live animals to third countries. The EU’s inaction is growing more and more obvious by the day, and we need to act fast if we don’t want citizens to lose all faith in us.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am very disappointed with your speech. You didn't tell us more or less anything. For five years, we have been trying to enforce a ban on the transport of live animals to third countries in the last parliamentary term and to set a clear time limit of eight hours for the transport of animals within the European Union. This is the only way to help poor animals. The incident in Romania is only the tip of the iceberg, with animals suffering in thousands of transports across Europe. We, if we want to do something about it, and you are the Commissioner in the Commission, who has a green deal here and wants to be environmentally friendly, then really put through a radical change that will help animals. Controls and soft measures do not solve the situation. The situation is getting worse, more and more animals are being exported to third countries, and the situation is catastrophic, and only a ban can solve it. Common sense says, let's bring meat, not live animals. Please do something about it.

name: Petra De Sutter (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, every year one billion poultry and 37 million bovine, sheep, goats and horses are transported within the EU and to third countries – often over great distances and for a long time, and a lot of these animals do not survive. Yes, there is regulation, but there is poor implementation and enforcement.  Certain Member States – such as Romania – do worse than others and continue to organise through that transport. This has to stop. I fully endorse my colleagues’ call to ban the transport of live animals. For too many of us, animal welfare is an unimportant subject. It was Ghandi who said that the greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated. Let us hope the EU can be a great continent with high moral standards in this regard.

name: Ioan-Rareş Bogdan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I understand your concerns and support the support for the establishment of slaughterhouses in particular in areas where they are lacking. I would like to ask you what the short-term consequences of banning the transport of live animals from the European Union would be.  First, this would mean famine in certain parts of the world—and I say this clearly—famine because of the lack of certain products. On the other hand, it means the bankruptcy of farmers, who would no longer have outlets. Recent data have confirmed to us that these phenomena - bankruptcy and hunger - lead to desperate gestures, whether we are talking about suicides by farmers or migrants stranded in the Mediterranean.  I believe that, in addition to animal welfare, we must stand a rational position and also give priority to the interests of human beings when making any decision. Let's check the carriers, how live animals are transported across the sea because otherwise Australia, New Zealand, Argentina... (The President interrupted the speaker)... can't wait for the release of markets in the Orient... (The President withdrew the speaker's word).

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, now, I’ve listened closely to your interventions and I want to try and address at least some of the points raised. Concerning the question on Romania: no definitive investigation of the circumstances leading to this accident have been completed. Initial investigations point to problems with the stability of the ship, and Romania is undertaking an independent investigation in accordance with maritime safety rules. The services of Commissioner Vălean will be monitoring the outcome of this investigation. I also carefully listened to your concerns on the transportation of live animals, and I promise to speak with my colleague, Commissioner Wojciechowski, on this – on how to create better conditions under the CAP. Now, concerning imports: yes, we do need to continue to work with trading partners and international organisations on animal welfare, and on campaigns in third countries. Colleagues are regularly sent to third countries under the ‘better training for safer foods’, and this will be continued. Finally, in response to the questions posed by MEP Hazekamp: I want to be absolutely clear that we have no doubts that all Member States must fully implement our rules as well as assure the welfare of our animals, and this is the only way to have a level playing pitch. Now, over the past three years, the Commission has audited Member States on road and sea transport to non-EU countries, and, at the request of my predecessor Commissioner Andriukaitis, the Commissioners’ services carried out an audit in Romania at the end of September specifically on animal welfare during sea transport. The audit report is currently being drafted and will be published on the Commission website once it’s finalised, and we’re absolutely going to be transparent on our findings. We will, equally, be transparent on the follow-up, and we will ensure that our recommendations are acted upon. And if we are not satisfied by the actions taken, I can only assure you that we will use all the means at our disposal – including legal proceedings if necessary – to address this problem. I have said from the very beginning that almost 15 000 sheep perishing in the sea is a shocking failure for our ethical values. When we take charge of animal destinies, we have a responsibility, and there is no room for shortcomings. These are sentient beings and they suffer when they are mistreated. When we transport animals, we must treat them with care and respect, and this is our duty and our responsibility. By working together, we can improve transport conditions for animals leaving the European Union by road, and by working together, we must now improve conditions for animals transported by sea. To this extent, we acknowledge that there are issues, and in my view, revision of the legislation needs to be considered in the context of farm-to-fork. Together we must prevent similar tragedies from happening, and we must exert all our efforts together in order to promote animal welfare.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank you for this very useful debate on animal welfare conditions during transport to third countries. We are sure that the conclusions on animal welfare which the Council adopted just yesterday will make a meaningful contribution to further discussion on this very important issue. I’m convinced that there will be a lot of added value to the future discussions on animal welfare. Finally, let me also emphasise that the Council very much welcomes the assessment of the 2012-2015 EU animal welfare strategy which is due to be published at the end of next year. We look forward to this publication and invite the Commission to work on a new strategy in light of the outcome of this assessment. Thank you very much for your commitment to this very important matter. We will certainly continue work on this field.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Some people wonder if animals have any rights. We, the people of 21st century Europe, are convinced that they certainly have the right to human responsibility for their fate. This conviction commands us to treat them humanely.  The EU prioritises animal welfare, recognising the difficulty of applying its requirements outside the Community. Rules on the transport of animals outside the Union are the competence of national institutions. Millions of animals are transported over long distances between Member States and to third countries each year. Just stop at the border to see the animals crammed there, waiting for hours for their turn to inspect documents and vehicles, in the sun, thirsty for water, rafting each other. Sick, injured and dead animals are found after a few days in the destination countries.  It is justified to take legislative action that will lead to bilateral agreements or a ban on the transport of animals if the standards of the country concerned do not comply with Union law. At border crossing points there should be places where animals can be insted and fed. Suspension of transport in summer can be considered. It seems sensible and advisable to switch mainly to trade in meat instead of transporting live animals, or to limit the transport time to eight hours. Research indicates that this could have positive economic effects.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on Enabling the digital transformation of health and care, by Bartosz Arłukowicz, Sara Cerdas, Frédérique Ries, Margrete Auken, Luisa Regimenti, Joanna Kopcińska, Kateřina Konečná, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000042/2019 – B9-0062/2019) (2019/2804(RSP)).

name: Sara Cerdas
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, digitisation in health is a constantly changing process. We want a more digital Europe and it is crucial that digitisation also passes through the area of health. We need to encourage the use and development of digital media in different approaches to health care and have an integrated vision for improving health care and outcomes in the different Member States and across the European Union. In view of this, the ENVI committee raises some questions, because of their relevance and importance, which should be examined by the Commission, in particular, what does the Commission intend to do to ensure that healthcare professionals have the appropriate digital skills and qualifications? And how does the Commission intend to assist Member States and their regions in disseminating the necessary knowledge and skills by citizens and patients using digital resources in the field of health? How does the Commission intend to ensure patient confidentiality at each stage of the process, and how will it ensure the safety and independence of eHealth and mHealth software? Does the Commission agree that people "should be at the heart of the health system" in the course of the changes generated by the digital revolution? And what measures does the Commission intend to take to ensure that citizens have safe access to their data in the decision-making process of healthcare professionals on therapeutic choices and care?  Ensuring the quality of health care and access to health for European citizens is of utmost importance for the European Parliament and, in particular, for the ENVI committee. Health systems currently face major challenges, such as an ageing population, the increased need for health care and the reduction of available resources. Digitisation is thus an ally in responding to these challenges. In the motion for a resolution on the digital transformation of health services and care services, 23 commitments were agreed between the different political groups in close cooperation work. Therefore, we warn against ensuring interoperability, systems must communicate with each other for an improvement in information, time and the guarantee of the support of health professionals and citizens themselves. Currently we have solutions that do not communicate with each other and that reduce the efficiency of the health system.  Cybersecurity is an essential pillar. With the potential of scanning, important security, privacy and data protection issues are raised. Health data are sensitive data and, in this sense, we consider essential a strong focus on the protection, security and privacy of the data and the confidentiality of the data, where the informed consent of citizens is ensured.  In this sense, we consider that anonymization and pseudoanonimization are crucial for the use of health data. We have the opportunity to optimize scientific research, which will allow us to develop policies based on scientific evidence and a better response to the health care provided. It will also contribute to the early detection of threats to public health, resulting in more timely and efficient responses.  But none of this is done without investment. We need investment in better equipment, better networks, better infrastructure, that meet digital needs. It is important to support Member States in the process of digital transformation and modernisation. We need an effective focus on digital solutions, solutions that should meet the real needs of citizens and health professionals, contributing to the accessibility and quality of health care in urban and rural areas. In addition, training should be guaranteed to the different links of the health system, from citizens, patients, caregivers and health professionals, providing easily understood information without leaving anyone behind. I conclude, Madam President and Commissioner, recalling that, for the success of health digitisation, a political commitment is needed at all levels, local, regional, national and European. Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow I count on your support by voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank everyone for the opportunity to have this very important discussion.  We need to have the right means to keep our citizens healthy. Digitalisation can be a game changer in this respect, because it can bring concrete benefits to patients and to healthcare professionals. It has the potential to provide cost—effective, high—quality healthcare and to reduce inequalities. All of us here are committed to fostering the digital transformation of health and care in a way that is inclusive and places the patient at its centre. Health data and how it can be securely shared, in full respect of EU protection standards, is critically important to achieve this transformation. For the patients, we need to ensure that Europe has a framework that supports them and their health providers directly, ensures that citizens have control over their personal data, facilitates research and supports the development of digital medical services, diagnostics and services. You can all rest assured that the creation of a European health data space to promote data exchange and support research will be an important part of my health agenda. To this extent, I will be working closely with the Commissioner for the Internal Market, Thierry Breton, as well as Executive Vice—President Margrethe Vestager and Vice—President Schinas to move forward in this endeavour. The Commission’s vision was first set out in the 2018 communication ‘Enabling the digital transformation of health and care in the Digital Single Market’. The aim is to encourage Member State action on e—health, while ensuring that citizens have secure access to their comprehensive electronic health data everywhere in the EU. Since then, important progress has been made. Earlier this year, for the first time, five Member States began exchanging e—prescriptions and patient summaries through the eHealth Digital Service Infrastructure, supported by the Connecting Europe Facility. Over 5000 e—prescriptions have been dispensed so far, and this clearly shows that we can have continuity of care across boundaries.  The Commission also adopted the Recommendation on a European Electronic Health Record exchange format to improve the ability to share data between systems and enable citizens access to their own electronic health records. These actions will continue as we move ahead with the creation of the EU health data space, supported by the proposed digital Europe programme. Whilst data is a key enabler for digital systems’ transformation, we also need to be aware that it does present a number of challenges. It is essential that data protection and cybersecurity considerations are built in from the design phase, in order to protect patient confidentiality, enable them access to their data safely, and protect the integrity of systems. The Commission has taken a number of important steps on this.  Firstly, patient data is protected and secured through the requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation. Secondly, health is one of the key sectors covered in the EU’s first cybersecurity legislation: the Directive on security of network and information systems. Earlier this year, we recommended that Member States develop national digital health networks to bring cybersecurity and the relevant expertise into their digital health systems. Thirdly, we encourage Member States to put in place secure electronic identification or authentication approaches for the health sector. Collectively, these measures will help build trust—based systems. The Commission proposes to underpin them with major investments, and EUR 2 million is foreseen for developing cybersecurity in the EU – including the health sector – as part of the Digital Europe.  Another major challenge that you have mentioned is skills development. Digitisation must reduce inequalities and not create a digital divide. Under the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the Commission is proposing EUR 700 million under Digital Europe for developing advanced digital skills. This will support training for healthcare professionals and help citizens develop digital literacy. The European Social Fund and research programmes will include important projects and programmes to support this. So empowering citizens to manage our own health is a key priority of the digital transformation agenda, and over the next five years, I hope to be working with Member States to ensure that Europe makes real progress on digital health. Finally, our progress on digital health and data exchange and research under the European Health Data Space will be important for the successful delivery of our other health priorities, such as our Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan. I hope that you will be here with us, because we will be launching this plan together on 4 February 2020 with you in the European Parliament. We are therefore fully committed to supporting this transition and making the most of the potential of e-health. I really look forward to working closely with you on this important issue.

name: Stanislav Polčák
text: for the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your rather comprehensive speech, it was very stimulating. I agree with you, if we allow the digital transformation of health and care in the digital single market, then we will take the quality of healthcare and also the availability of health services in the European Union to a higher level.  Of course, there are a number of related issues to be remembered when it comes to privacy, security and data protection. I consider the idea of creating a European health data area to facilitate the transfer of health data and to support research into prevention, treatments, medicines and shared outcomes to be very beneficial. We want to support patients more effectively, provide them with better information and help them to better orient themselves in the health system, their rights and also in the health services provided. In this respect, an appropriate way of ensuring access to and sharing of personal health data should be found, facilitating communication between health service providers and other organisations in each Member State. Commissioner, it is important that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States and the relevant regional authorities, also focuss on educating citizens on the use of digital healthcare. To this end, it will be necessary to improve the interoperability of the healthcare system and to further develop this theme with the help of European funding instruments, such as, of course, the European Structural and Investment Funds, the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Biljana Borzan
text: On behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear Chairman, there is consensus that digital technologies have the potential to significantly improve European health. Nevertheless, health institutions find it difficult to decide on changes in procedures and business. Furthermore, many healthcare professionals view digital technologies with suspicion, fearing that they will increase their workload or lead them to misdiagnoses.  On the other hand, patients show far more enthusiasm for new technologies, but this does not apply to all demographic groups. IT literacy is an indomitable barrier for a large part of the elderly population. Statistics show that 14% of adult Europeans did not use the internet in 2016, while a third of adults said they did not know how to access the internet via mobile phone.  Despite the progress and wealth of the European Union, a significant part of the population is not IT literate, which certainly contributes to skepticism towards digital solutions in health care. Furthermore, this also opens up the possibility of misuse of data and other unintended consequences. As a doctor, I had a case where a patient fainted with shock and fear because a misplaced digital blood pressure gauter showed her blood pressure was 0.  In conclusion, I believe that raising IT literacy among healthcare professionals and users is key to the successful digitisation of European health.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, you are right to point out that it is crucial for the European Union to have a strategy to support digital transformation in the health field. The digitalization of health systems allows considerable progress in many areas: the field of prevention, with connected objects; the field of care, with telemedicine; public health, I am thinking, for example, of the management of shortages, and the problem of research, particularly in the area of cancer. Our group wishes to stress, in the field of digitalisation, three essential points: data privacy, data sharing and interoperability between the different Member States and, of course, the ethical dimension. However, these three ambitions are not necessarily very easy to combine. For example, we need to find the balance between the anonymization of data, on the one hand, and their sharing by different health actors, on the other. The balance must be struck between data protection and the absolute need for scientific research to dispose of big data. A very sad illustration of this was given by the sale of medical data to GAFAM from poorly secured sites. Commissioner, we expect a lot from the European health data area to help us solve this problem. The balance must be struck between decision-making algorithms and the need to preserve the human dimension of medicine. We have to find the balance between a certain empowerment of patients, you mentioned, but also the weakening of patients vis-à-vis infox. Finally, and above all, as the previous speaker pointed out, it is necessary to ensure that what is technological progress for some does not become a pitfall for others, because they are too old, too isolated or have too poor a level of education. We are counting on you to be vigilant on these points.

name: Petra De Sutter
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we all agree, I think; I will not repeat what has been said about the added value of digitalising our healthcare in the domain of rare diseases and in the domain of research, to increase the efficiency of healthcare and health promotion and prevention. But – there is a but – data is the new gold, and we have just heard that there are some things we need to be careful about. Selling data is not acceptable if we talk about health data, and we know that some patients are really worried about that. If we talk about data sharing – and you have said that you will do everything possible to make sure that these data are protected; we have the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which has implementation problems – we know that informed consent is important, and let’s not just go for opt-out systems. Let’s anonymise data for research. But whatever system you put in place to have your European health data space, please build trust into the systems by design.

name: Nathalie Colin-Oesterlé (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with the digitisation of health and care systems, the stakes are high. The aim is to promote health at European level, to prevent and combat diseases, to help meet the unmet needs of patients and to facilitate equal access to high-quality care for citizens through the judicious use of digital innovations. Health issues are part of the national policy of each Member State, of course, but if we want the systems to be interoperable between Member States, it is necessary for a single European format of computer data exchange to be developed. This includes patient records, electronic prescriptions, laboratory results, medical imaging, hospital discharge reports. In order to make this Europe of health, we must first of all provide financial assistance to Member States which do not yet have sufficient digital development, set a timetable and concrete objectives, and improve the information of the European patient on the price of medicines in the European Union. This is all the more important for patients with rare diseases who need treatment in a Member State other than their own. Finally, ensure - and this has been said - the protection of private information so that it is used in the exclusive interest of patients. The digitisation of health and care services is a real opportunity for European citizens and for the Europe of health, which must become a reality.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in the previous mandate I worked on this question in this resolution, which defined the European Parliament's priorities on the central theme of digital transformation and its impact on health care. And I now greet my colleague Sara Cerdas, who is taking on this task and with whom I have made joint amendments to the resolution under discussion. Digital transformation is a huge opportunity to improve the quality of services provided, to focus response systems on users' needs and to provide more universal access to health services and, in particular, to more advanced technological and scientifically advanced responses. It is a priority to develop inclusion networks that form and endit users with the knowledge and tools necessary for universal and informed participation.  Access systems must therefore be easy to use, interoperable and protected through mechanisms and tools provided or regulated by public entities. Another priority is to promote data sharing securely in the cross-border context. More data allows better responses for more people. The progressive digitisation of many health response processes and systems is also an opportunity to improve the effectiveness of partnerships between the various actors in the system, including between private actors and public actors. The European Union should launch the ambitious generalised training programme, crossing accessibility to high definition networks with skills for their use. It is a priority to ensure a model for capturing and making data available in a safe manner for research, ensuring a fair distribution of the gains made from this process.  Health promotion will increasingly interact with the development of the digital single market. Regulation must be made with clear priorities in the defence of citizens and the quality of the services provided to it, while valuing all the professionals involved. This resolution makes an important contribution to the path I have just pointed out.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Kyriakides, the digital transformation of healthcare must start from the patient. We have a duty to ensure that the patient remains the central brick of digital health, that he has discretionary access to his own data. For Romania, cross-border medical treatment has become a common reality due to a considerable part of the population living, studying or working in the European Community.  The patient's electronic medical record, containing the entire medical history, from the childhood vaccination scheme to the last cold, would be a big step forward. Digital history could prevent misdiagnosis or delayed diagnosis of diseases, real diseases that are sometimes not even detected, such as primary immunodeficiencies. So I want to encourage you with the digital electronic projects that you are carrying out and especially on the electronic health infrastructure side.

name: Liudas Mažylis (PPE).
text: – Thank you Madam President, the ambitions to enable digital healthcare in the single digital market offer opportunities, respond to patients' expectations, but at the same time pose challenges such as standardisation and unification. The digital healthcare system provides opportunities to develop the use of artificial intelligence and computer learning. New technologies adapted to the healthcare system can help to better understand hard-to-treat diseases and other health conditions. Those benefits are inseparable from the challenges that arise. The security of personal data and the legitimate disposal of personal data are an important problem. Confidential use of data from the health system could contribute to health policy. The creation of a common framework to harmonise the collection and retention of health data and their use in the European Union would improve the quality of the services provided, develop research and improve the availability of data. Especially since it would turn to the increasing expectations of patients to monitor their health. This requires harmonising, unifying health systems in the Member States, improving interinstitutional cooperation and public eHealth digital infrastructure. In addition, it is also necessary to pay attention to the solutions mentioned in the resolution to the problem of territorial exclusion, which I believe must be developed. Thanks, good holidays and good health.

name: Susana Solís Pérez (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we need to improve the efficiency and efficiency of our health systems, and digitisation is essential. Technologies such as artificial intelligence are key to accelerating research, to advance early prevention of diseases such as Alzheimer's or, for example, the diagnosis of breast cancer. But for that we need a great deal of data and for Member States to cooperate in the implementation of an interoperable information system between europe's various health centres. And we must also ensure the confidentiality and safety of patients. Because this is the most important thing: we must put the patient in the center and that, in no case, digitization involves dehumanized attention, but quite the opposite. It has to make it easier for us to provide new care services that improve our quality of life and give us access to personalized treatments. And for that we need to digitally train patients, caregivers and healthcare professionals.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the digitisation of healthcare will undoubtedly contribute to more patient-centred and personalised healthcare. Last week I visited a Flemish start-up dedicated to the digitisation of health care. In this way, by measuring brain activity more efficiently, it can be made more quickly to diagnose epilepsy and to be given the right medication more specifically. These are examples that convince me of the added value of digitising health care. The possibilities are many: artificial intelligence in medical imaging, robotic surgery, telemedicine, precision medicine. As the European Union, we can be at the helm if we join forces, including in the field of data protection. However, we will only be able to really move the tables if each new development is aimed at improving the quality of care and the affordability and accessibility of health care, including for vulnerable groups.

name: Lídia Pereira (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, digitisation of the health sector enables access, processing and data analysis of hundreds of millions of Europeans.  Through careful monitoring of patient health indicators, we can act preventively and prolong the lives of citizens with quality and well-being. Personalized medicine and massive use of data using data will enable better diagnostics and medical procedures and open doors to greater efficiency, benefiting citizens, the state and industry organizations. But it is important to ensure that the creation of the European Health Data Area is not mortgaged by lack of public investment by governments or that citizens' privacy is forgotten.  Promoting the public health of Europeans cannot compromise their fundamental rights. Technology, also in this field, is advancing faster than public policies. The adoption of this data sharing strategy and the corresponding regulation deserve to be among the priorities for 2020 because it will allow significant gains in the quality of life of each of us.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is very clear that the sustainability of health systems in the European Union, financial sustainability is an increasingly important challenge. On average, 9.6% of the GDP of the entire European Union is invested in health systems, with a major discrepancy between different countries of the European Union. It is an increasingly clear signal that health systems need a transformation that guarantees patients access to health services as well as optimisation of health services.  I believe that, in order to really put the patient at the heart of health systems, to make systems more efficient, we need to make the widest possible use of new technologies, be they the electronic health record, electronic prescription, telemedicine systems. We need to increasingly integrate and use artificial intelligence into health systems and support innovation in the health care sector.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, today the changes in health care are obvious. These are major, tectonic changes, caused, on the one hand, by the changed demographic structure of the population in Europe, and the development of new technologies, which make Member States' health systems more difficult and more difficult to sustain. Of course, this new technologies and digital technology can play a role, both through the use of artificial intelligence to predict health conditions, i.e. prevention, through diagnostics, using european reference networks based on Directive 2011/24, as well as the use of new technologies for self-treatment of patients. Of course, there are many challenges, there is the question of research and certain ethical problems related to this, there is the problem of privacy protection, i.e. protection of information, but also investments in basic infrastructure that, unfortunately, is very much behind in some countries that are less developed than the European Union average.  In other words, the European Union has instruments to address this, it has regulatory instruments, it has financial instruments through cohesion policy, through horizon, and I believe that with the political atmosphere we have today we can really make a step forward in this regard.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, digitalisation in health can, of course, contribute to improving health care, and we are counting on it. But it's confronted with a lot of risks. Some of them have already been listed here. A major step forward is the Data Protection Regulation, which, among other things, protects patients' health data and regulates their sharing. If we want to create a single cross-border digital health system, we must promote interoperability of the system, such as patient health records or the sharing of health data between Member States.  Digital health can therefore partly address the shortage of medical staff, but it should be taken into account that not everyone has the same digital literacy and not everyone is able to use digital technologies. Therefore, it is necessary to think about retraining the medical staff who must be able to use these technologies. Despite the considerable advances in digital technologies, the patient's relationship with the doctor needs to be maintained.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Cybermoor is a social enterprise located in Alston, a remote rural community in my North West Region. Initially established in 2002 to provide broadband and computers to improve access to services and overcome isolation, Cybermoor initiated the Alston Health Care project in 2007 focusing on telehealth and telemedicine services for the local community.  They’ve delivered the successful implementation of a heart failure telehealth project and provide video links between hospitals to provide remote assessment of patients. They work closely with the local NHS Partnership Trust and with Cumbria County Council social services and they’ve got links with NGOs across Cumbria such as Age UK. Always innovating, they work with other NGOs to recruit test users for new projects such as home monitoring by informal carers. The cyber more team have been involved in several EU projects including E10 which supports the deployment of trans-European e—services in the public interest. Demonstrating the value of partnership working.  I know that remote and peripheral communities such as Alston will be hard hit by Brexit as they’ve benefited enormously from the EU’s close attention to the outermost regions.

name: Patrick Breyer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, information on our health is about as sensitive as it can be. It includes data on our mental disorders, on our sexual health, including HIV, on reproductive disorders, etc., so certainly using this information for other purposes such as research and care can have benefits, but the Commission’s communication and the proposed resolution we are to vote on tomorrow do not acknowledge that the patient should be in control of this information on their health and should not be forced to give up control by feeding this information into centralised and interconnected databases. We fully know well that a decentralised storage on unconnected devices is much safer and also, Madam Commissioner, 62% of respondents to your consultation said they want to share their health data for research purposes only if it cannot be tracked back to them. That means anonymised data, not just pseudonymised data. Information on our physical and mental health must never be regarded as a commodity for industry to exploit but is a confidential and integral part of our personality.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I’m representing the Dutch Party 50PLUS. Half of the population is 50+, and it’s nice to know that the other half is eager to become it. But, for my voters, health and care is very, very important, as you may be aware. I want to add some following points. Preventive healthcare is key to lowering the cost of healthcare systems. I want to know if the European Commission is prepared, with regard to the free movement of services, to oblige Member States to allow all forms of preventive healthcare. Secondly, the right food is your best pharmacist. Is the European Commission willing to make it easier to get medical health claims on fresh foods? With the digital revolution, we can give better and more information to help people to live more healthily, and that makes life easier.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’ll be very brief – I took longer in my opening remarks, so I’ll be brief now. We all know that the digital transformation of healthcare can be a game changer, and I’m just going to repeat that the Commission is committed to this. We are also aware that we need to leave no—one behind: we need to provide skills training and we need to protect data, and I think this is very important. We need to build trust-based systems. The digital transformation of health and care and the development of the European health data space are ambitious goals, and by the end of 2020 the Commission will come up with a data strategy which will include health data. So we’re very much at the beginning of this journey, and it is important that we all build this digital health future together. In ending, may I also extend my best wishes for the coming festive season.

name: President. –
text: And thank you, Commissioner, we wish you a very good Christmas and indeed New Year. I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule136(1) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 18 December 2019.
